As I've said multiple times in this write-up, I don't necessarily share the theological beliefs underpinning this, but the idea that a garden gives us an arena for cultivating not only plants, but also spiritual virtues, and that it is worthwhile to reflect on how our own little piece of carefully-tended nature mirrors the wider cosmos tended by the divine ("as above, so below") still hits home for me. Unluckily, I'm a rather bad druid-in-training, and I don't have a garden right now, for all the usual reasons - busy, overly fond of words and abstractions, wanting to keep my soft, white hands free of dirt and calluses, and so forth. This bit was a nice reminder that maybe I ought to do change that.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

[Book] Thoughts on How to Pray the Rosary and Get Results

Date: 2024-November-03
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

This short book by "Brother Armatus Divino Auxilio," Brother ADA, looks at how to pray for hands-on goals using the Catholic Rosary. Clearly, I don't mean to make use of it "as is", but when I was first getting started working on the Heathen Rosary undertaking, an online friend said I ought to check this book out and I quickly added it to the stack of books I meant to read as I put it together. Well, now I've at last gotten to it, and I'm glad I did. It slightly blurs the lines between magic ("the art and science of causing changes in consciousness in accordance with will," to borrow a definition) and religion, which I'm okay with, given my leanings, but I'd add in a few warnings around consent. I also wasn't the biggest fan of the "no-nonsense tough guy" tone, but I get why Brother ADA takes it, so I can't grumble too much. Otherwise, I'm glad I read this book, as it packed a lot of helpful stuff into a short length. If you're into the Catholic Rosary itself, you'll get a lot out of it, if you're into some kind of praying with beads, most of all if you want to pray "for" things, you'll likely also find it rather helpful, and if you'd just like to learn more about prayer overall, you might find it somewhat helpful. If none of those things grab you, you can likely give this one a pass.

Getting Clear on Your Goals

The main idea of this book is that it's good and right to pray for hands-on things right here in this earthly life (so long as you're guided by a religious understanding of what your life ought to be), and that the Rosary is a helpful tool for making those prayers more likely to get you what you're after. Brother ADA says that the heart of how to make any prayer (in this book, the prayers of the Rosary, but the way he handled this led me to pick up his broader book The Magic of Effective Prayer) more likely to work is to have a goal and get as clear on it as you can. This 100% lines up with what I've learned of magical or occult techniques - if magic is about changing consciousness in accordance with will, a sharply-aimed will is the weightiest bit of this. Brother ADA gives some helpful tips on how to get clear on your goal and bring that into your prayers - state your goal clearly before beginning to say the Rosary, link up your goal with the spiritual fruits of each mystery, add in a short phrase to each "Hail Mary" to strengthen your goal (more on those two below), a short prayer when you finish that says again your goal and asking Jesus and Mary to help bring it about, and so forth.

This strikes me as good thinking and fairly ready to work into the Heathen Rosary, and so I've already added it into my daily prayers, though I'd add a few more thoughts. First, before you settle on an goal, you should be sure it's clear, sharp, and a good idea for you and your religious leanings. To get clear and sharp, thinking through the goal, and what its earthy outcomes would is a good start. To know whether it's a good fit for you and lines up with the will of the Gods, prayer, bethinking, and divination are helpful tools. In the magical paths I've followed so far, all of that is a given for any magical working, and this is at root a magical working with the Gods' help (see the next bit below), so I'd do the same kind and amount of work ahead of time here that I'd do for any other way of changing consciousness through will.

Use of Magical Techniques

I already said that Brother ADA somewhat blurs the lines between "magic" and "religion" here, which is not so shocking from what I know of his background (Christian ceremonial magic seems to be his "deal"). With a few words of warning (spelled out below), I think this is overall helpful. Namely, his way puts together sharpness of goal, and thus will (talked about above), visualization, ways from affirmations, and symbolism. Put these together, and you should have a pretty workable bundle. We went over sharpness of goal and will above, which brings us to visualization. Brother ADA says you ought to visualize what you and your life will be like when your prayer comes true, and even goes so far as to say you ought to give "pathworking" a shot (what he teaches sounds to me like what I would call "scrying," but that word might scare off Christians). For this, he say to settle yourself into bethinking, visualize a symbol that stands for one of the mysteries, and then step through that symbol like a door into the scene of one of the mysteries, and then speak with those there, most of all Jesus and/or Mary if you can. Call it "active imagination" if you like, but this kind of semi-guided visualization is a core technique of the kinds of magic I'm learning, and the thought of bringing it to bear on the Rosary was at first unlooked-for, but struck me as helpful. Even if you don't have a hands-on goal in mind, you could use this to greatly deepen what you get out of the mysteries, which again, strikes me as very helpful indeed. He gives a couple of tips that, again, strike me as making good sense with what I know about scrying and other magical techniques: don't do the scrying/pathworking right before praying the Rosary, wait at least a few hours, and don't scry more than three or four times a week (I might even take that down to one or two).

From here, Brother ADA spells out a handful of steps that I knew from how to craft affirmations: say the affirmation as already done, stay away from negatives (not "I am not afraid," but instead "I am brave"), make the wording of the affirmation as crisp as you can, take hands-on actions to further the affirmation, then repeat it a lot. If we set aside what outcome such ways might have on our interactions with the Gods, all of this is at least good rede (advice) for interacting with your own subconscious, which always plays a weighty role in what happens in your life. The subconscious doesn't seem to "get" negatives, it likes cut-and-dried things more than abstractions, actually doing things that you can see further your goal will clearly make it more likely to happen, which will win over the subconscious to help, and it takes a lot of repetition to get things to sink in. Though I didn't exactly set out to do this, it strikes me now that the bedes I've written so far happen to follow this rede rather well for the overall spiritual goals of the Heathen Rosary - forthright, positive statements, grounded in concrete images, said over and over. How about that?

For symbolism, the main technique given in the book is the use of colored candles/candle holders. Candle magic is an evergreen in folk magic around the world, worked out thoroughly in African-American Hoodoo/Conjure (not to be mixed up with voudoun or "voodoo," which is an Afro-Carribean syncretic religion with its own techniques, spiritual powers, and so forth). Brother ADA gives a list of links for colors that I haven't yet taken the time to set beside the work on candle magic I know best, but some of the broad threads are the same - green for money, white for spirituality, and so forth. Lighting a candle with a symbolic link to your goal, with a short prayer saying that goal, before you start your longer prayer strikes me as easy and likely helpful, and not hurting anything in any case, so I'm thinking I'll give this one a try sometime soon (so far, I've only said the Heathen Rosary with the plain white candle I use for daily prayers at my Godshelf lit). Of course, both the Catholic and Heathen Rosaries have all kinds of symbolism woven into the prayers, number of beads, images in the mysteries/riddles, materials of the beads, and so forth, so all of that likely adds symbolic weight as well. Once again, whatever metaphysical outcome these symbols may or may not be having, they at least have a bearing on your subconscious, which is nothing to sneeze at - they subtly strengthen the thoughts, and more weightily, moods that you bring into the bedes.

Applying the "Spiritual Fruits" to What You Want

Somehow in all my reading on the Rosary so far, I had missed the thought that each mystery has a specific "spiritual fruit" to go with it, which seems to be fairly basic stuff. Chalk it up to another shortcoming of my non-Catholic upbringing that I'm having to make up for. If, like I was, you don't know this thought, at bottom, each of the 15 (or 20, if you truck with Pope John Paull II's "Luminous Mysteries") mysteries of the Rosary has a good spiritual quality that goes with it that bethinking on that mystery is supposed to foster in the bethinker. For example, the first of the Joyful mysteries, the Annunciation, is "humility." The idea is that Mary takes on the honor and awful burden of carrying and birthing God given human form, and that takes humility. Further, Brother ADA gives an overarching thread for each group of mysteries - for example, the Joyful Mysteries all seem to deal with times where an emotional low leads to a spiritual high.

So, first off, the thought of "spiritual fruits" is a helpful one I will likely want to bring to bear as I work out which "riddles" (the tentative name I'm giving to the threads for bethinking to be used in the Heathen Rosary) to use with the Heathen Rosary, and how to share them. I think this will be both clarifying for me ("what kind of thews ought the Heathen Rosary develop?") as well as helpful to anyone else who takes it up ("what am I getting out of thinking about this myth, anyway?"). Clearly, myths are deep and bethinking on them can have many "fruits" beyond one specific virtue to cultivate, but it's a nice bit of focus nonetheless.

More straightforwardly linked to the ends of the book is his talk about how to link the spiritual fruits to whatever intention you might have while praying. To keep on with our example above, when bethinking on the Annunciation, you might link up what "humility" has to do with reaching your goal. I thought this discussion was helpful, with a lot of specific ways to bring the spiritual fruits to bear when it's less-obvious (humility is ready to apply when you're trying to get over your overgrown ego, less obvious when you're trying to stand up for yourself, for example).

The "Expanded Method" of Praying the Rosary

Maybe the most helpful thing from this book against others, that you couldn't put together on your own with some basic knowledge of folk magic, is his "expanded method." For it, he takes a thought from Louis de Montfort's The Secret of the Rosary that I passed right over as not bearing upon my work, and turns it into something that grabbed me after all. De Montfort gives an option for saying the Rosary where you add a short phrase to each "Hail Mary" that puts weight on the mystery you're bethinking on. So, to keep on with our earlier example, while you're bethinking on the Annunciation, you might add "incarnate" after "Jesus" (for "Blessed is the fruit of thy womb, Jesus incarnate.") Brother ADA gives a list of phrases he worked out for himself for this end, that worked better with him. This alone strikes me as likely helpful for the "main" goals of the Heathen Rosary, but adding further words is, of course, tricky, if I want to keep to the poetic meter I've set myself for each of the bedes. I'll have to give some thought to whether the upsides to this way of doing things outweigh the downsides of bending the rules a bit.

From there, though, he does something truly interesting. Instead of using these add-in phrases to deepen the focus on the mysteries and their standard spiritual fruits, he says to add in a phrase specific to your intention. So, if you are praying the Rosary with the goal of getting help getting fit, you might put in a phrase on just that. Here, again, Brother ADA draws on the ways of affirmations and says you ought to craft a phrase that characterizes your wanted outcome as having already happened, so for our fitness example, you might say "Jesus, who made my body strong and healthy" or something of that kind. I really like the bendsomeness (flexibility) and potential efficacy of this way of doing things, but again, it runs into some hang-ups with meter and some of the hang-ups I go into below.

There's also a more deeply-rooted challenge here. In Christian theology, Jesus is the one and only God (yes, I know, one of three distinct persons of that God, in a mystery that can't be understood intellectually, but you get the point). As such, adding something that sharpens your goal as an epithet for Him covers your bases - everything flows from the creator of all things, so whatever it is you're after, you can call on Him and be good. For a polytheist, things are trickier, and for the "Hail Idun" as we have it, it's trickier still. For one, not all Gods handle all things - if you called on Thunor for soothing and calm, He's likely not the best help there. Which leads to the challenge with the "Hail Idun" as written - it only calls directly upon Idun, and alludes to Her husband Bragi. So, if we have a goal for our prayer that's not really in Idun's (or, I guess, Bragi's) wheelhouse, we don't have a "slot" to put it into, and even if we do, we have the same metrical issues I brought up above. One maybe answer would be to make the change to the "All-Father," since Woden has a broader range of things He deals with, and is overall about "making what you want happen," but the downside there is that you only say four "All-Fathers" in one round of the Heathen Rosary, against 36 "Hail Iduns" in the four ninefolds (you don't change the bedes linking the token with the medal). On the other hand, even if Brother ADA is right that the Catholic Rosary is well-fitted to prayers of any rightful goal, the Heathen Rosary might not be quite so many-sided, calling as it does upon a narrower range of divinity. I guess I'll just have to think, bethink, pray, and divine on whether and how to bring this in.

A Word on Consent, the Gods as Vending Machines, and the Difference Between Magic and Religion

Something I've held off until this bit, but that I've hinted at a few times before, are a few worries I have with Brother ADA's way of coming at, or lack thereof, some ethical issues I've learned to take very seriously in the traditions I'm working with - consent, asking the Gods for goodies, and the (admittedly, sometimes blurry) line between magic and religion.

First off, Brother ADA doesn't talk at all in this short book about consent, which is a shortcoming I've found to be common to a lot of Christian writings. What seems to be the typical thinking of Christians is that Jesus loves all and knows best for all, so it's okay to pray for just about anything you think is good for someone else. The magical and religious paths I've been working with for the past few years are much less cavalier with cares about whether it's okay to pray for something someone else might not want and put far more weight on the self-rulership of every soul to work out what's best for it and to have a say about that. As a Christian, you might see it as your duty to try to bring others to the true faith, but for someone who doesn't share your beliefs, it might be quite an unwelcome intrusion for any psychic or spiritual oomph to be put into converting him. Less obviously, even seemingly less intrusive goals, like wishing blessings upon someone might not be welcome - some souls don't want to be helped, even if maybe it would be better for them, and who knows, maybe they need whatever that lack of help is giving them - whether to learn self-reliance, burn off karma, or just to get to the point that they recognize the need for help and change their mind. So, if you're going to go off and start working these ways into your prayer practice, I beg you, give some thought to whether you have the consent of the other person to pray on his behalf, and if not, strongly think over not doing so - at least, add in a caveat to your goal something like "if he welcomes it and in whatever way is best for him" and trust in the Gods to sort out whether to answer your prayer and in what way.

Even if you stay away from praying for others, there's another hangup that might catch you that Brother ADA doesn't get much into that I found to be a shortcoming in this book: the temptation to see the Gods as on-demand givers of every damn thing you might want. To be fair, it seems that Brother ADA is coming at this trying to go against the also common, but opposite, leaning found among a lot of folks - the fear to ask for anything at all from the Gods, whether out of a feeling of inadequacy, sheepishness, or whatever else. My own thinking here is a bit nuanced - asking the Gods for things can be good and wholesome, but it has some obvious pitfalls. I talked a bit more about this before, but to give a short recap: asking the Gods for help can be a way to acknowledge that we need help for everything, as, after all, "no man is an island," it can help to sharpen what you truly want and whether it's good for you ("I will only pray for this once I'm darn sure it's worth bothering the Gods about"), and it can help you better come to know what strengths and thews a given God is most linked with, and to be thankful for the gifts that can flow from that. To give an example of all three points, when I ask for Thunor to watch over my girls, it helps me be more aware that the world is a risky stead, and nothing I do can wholly take that away, that keeping them hale and whole is one of the weightiest things to me and I think that's a worthwhile thing for me as a man and a father, and it deepens my understanding of His role as a warder and father Himself. So, while it's true that the Gods can and do give you things, they are not for giving you things, and your bond with them should not treat Them as such.

Lastly, the book is a bit lax about treating prayer as "just another tool in the toolbox" (or, in the "tough guy" language I grumbled about earlier, a "weapon") for getting the kind of earthly things all of us want - better health, happier bonds, more fulfilling and better paying careers, and so forth. Can all of those be worthy things to strive for? Of course. After enough thinking it over, can it be wise and effective to use magical ways to help in that striving? Again, of course. Should you reach for prayer as one of the mainstays of your magical toolbox? Here, I think it's a bit less clear-cut. To my mind, prayer is first and foremost about deepening your bond with the Gods that you worship. Building that bond can and should be a goal for anyone serious about spiritual practice. Getting things that you want here, now, in this life, might help with that goal, but then it might not. Maybe you need for your business to crash and burn to learn some lesson that will make your soul better and stronger. Maybe you need to be poor for awhile. Maybe you need to be sad and lonely for a time. If so, praying for these things to end, and bringing magical ways into those prayers with the goal of making that outcome more likely, might hinder the spiritual development prayer is meant to further. All of which is why I earlier recommended using the ways of working out whether a goal is right before jumping feet-first into using magical ways to go after that goal. Maybe you need to be sad and lonely for awhile, but maybe you need to pull yourself out of it, and magic, or magical prayer, is just the way to (help) do it! I don't know - and you might not either, but if you pray, bethink, and divine on it, you might get an idea.

Wrap-Up

As I said up top, this book will be very helpful to some, somewhat helpful to others, and not all that helpful to still some others, and you likely have a good idea which bucket you fall into. I found it rather helpful for my own idiosyncratic ends, and I'm glad I gave it a read. If I had to get it into one, short, thought, it'd be that this book gives a lot of tools for linking the "what" of praying the Rosary with the "why" of whatever you might be trying to make happen in the world. If you're on the fence about whether this book might be helpful to you, it's very short - ~100 pages in a small size with a fair number of pictures, so you can read it in an evening or two to work out for yourself whether you can make use of it or not. So, if any of that grabs you, give it a go.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

First Pass at Saying the Heathen Rosary

Date: 2024-October-21
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

As I said last time, with the "All-Father" written, I now have enough bedes to make a practice out of saying the Heathen Rosary, and I've been doing so daily for the past week or so. Since the bits that make it up have been posted here and there on this webstead, I thought it might be helpful to bring them all together, along with some hands-on steering for making a strand of beads to keep track of your bedes (a rather lame bit of wordplay, since bead and bede have the exact same etymology - beads got their name for being used to keep track of saying bedes, just as we're doing here. How about that?).

The Beads

Though you could likely keep all of the below in your mind without the help of a set of beads, one of the main things that drew me to this undertaking was the very putting together of spoken word, thought, and something to do with your hands. So, if you'd like to have a set of beads to help you keep track, here's what you'll need:

  • One token of your overall belief in the Gods (a Thunor's Hammer token would be fitting, but I found this lovely remake of an Anglo-Saxon pendant that divination suggested was right for me)
  • One bead that represents Woden (I found this one of his ravens)
  • 39 Beads for "Hail Iduns" (I used yew beads, drawing on the symbolism of Yggdrasil as a great yew)
  • One "medallion" that goes where the main loop meets the short string of beads for the starting prayers (I will be carving in a yew disk a woman standing in the shape of the Algiz Rune, with her arms becoming branches, and her feet roots, to stand for Idun)
  • Three beads of different size and/or feel from the 39 "Hail Idun" beads for the "All-Fathers" and "Marks of the Wells" (I used three lapis lazuli beads found at a local bead shop to stand for the water of the Wells)
  • 43-45 Spacer Beads (I used very small dark green beads, I believe a kind of jade, to stand for Idun's apples. The variable number is depending on whether you want or need spacers before and/or after your Woden bead)

To put these together, in the main loop, you should have four groups of nine "Hail Idun" beads with spacers between, and between them, the "All-Father"\/"Mark of the Wells" beads. At the bottom of the loop, you should have your medallion (so, between the first and fourth grouping of nine "Hail Idun" beads), and hanging from the medallion, a short length of three "Hail Idun" beads, with spacers between, the Woden bead, and then your token at the end. For hands-on help on how to make one of these, you'll find Pagan Prayer Beads by John Michael Greer and Clare Vaughn (pen name for his wife, Sara) very helpful.

The "Hammer Token"

Much like the Christian "Sign of the Cross," this short bede works as a blessing for all ends, but most of all warding from evil, and can be said to make yourself holy for prayer and to open yourself to the Gods.

By Thunor's (touch forehead)
Mighty (touch solar plexus)
Hallowing (touch left shoulder)
Hammer (touch right shoulder)

The "Tree Deeming"

This "deeming" (statement of belief, creed) takes the stead of the Christian "Apostle's Creed," something you say right at the start to come back to and strengthen what you believe and why you're doing this. Here, we lean less on things our Gods ask us to believe happened or are true about the world, and more on the trust we put in Them and Their worship, the things we do to show that, and what we hope will come of doing so.

Hallowward we have  our hearts fore-turned,
To give worship  to wealsome Gods,
Watering anew  that nut life-bearing.

Bright with holiness  our hearts become
As troth we give  to trustworthy Gods
In fair trade  upon Tree life-binding.

Shining with happiness  our hearts should be,
For steering will be given  by steadfast Gods
To bless us  with blossoms life-healing.
Alu

The "All-Father"

This bede calls upon Woden as the "All-Father" who shows us how to seek after what is most worthy, even when it is very hard. The goal here is to awaken our own will to strive and win what our souls most need.

All-Father, || who art in Fallhall,
Welcome is Thy call || to win a spot therein.
From barrows cold, || Thy benches we seek.

Worthy we deem it || on to that windswept Tree
To boldly climb up, || cleaving to Thy might,
To watch through all hardship || those worlds nine-fold.

There teach us by Runes, || wrested from nethermost Well,
To weave Thy Craeft || into our wyrd evermore
That our mind-stock stand || steadfast beyond death.
Alu

The "Hail Idun"

The heart of the Heathen Rosary, this bede calls upon Idun, known from myth as the keeper of the apples that allow the Gods to stay young and living beyond the span of mankind here in this world. In writing it, I have drawn both on the thoughts of others (such as Maria Kvilhaug) and my own gnosis of Her to link her with (one of?) the holy drink(s) of Germanish myth, seeing Her as the keeper of the very prize Woden pushes us to seek. As such, while the bede to Woden stirs us to strive and work for what we seek, this one acknowledges that we can't get it without help, and asks the kindly Goddess to give us that help.

Hail Idun,
Yggdrasil's Seed,
well-spoken wife of wordcraft,
wreathed in blessed blossoms.

Holy Idun,
open our hearts
with ale's dearest drink
to awakening of everlasting life.
Alu

The "Mark of the Wells"

In the Catholic Rosary, the "Sign of the Cross" and the "Doxology" run together a bit, but for this Heathen Rosary, saying the same bede at beginning and end didn't feel right to me, so I wrote this one, which names the three Wells from which the World Tree draws its life, as well as the Tree itself. Where the "Hammer Token" calls down the strength of the Gods to make us holy, this bede draws up the life and drive deep within Being and affirms the holiness of what grows out of that. I like to think of it as a reminder that what we do grows outward into our lives and the world, like a tree, and that holy work, like praying, can help the tree we grow be a worthwhile one.

From seething hwer, (touch belly, about 2 inches below navel)
Woden's drink, (touch forehead)
and Wyrd's holy well, (touch heart)
Mighty tree unmatched. (look upward)
Alu

Putting these Bedes Together

So, with all of the building blocks, how do you "do" the Heathen Rosary? Like so:

  1. Take a tick, settle yourself, and if you have an intention, set it in mind before you begin saying the bedes
  2. Holding your token, say the "Hammer Token" and then the "Tree Deeming"
  3. Move your fingers to the Woden bead and say one "All-Father"
  4. Move your finger to each of the three main beads before the medallion and say one "Hail Idun" for each
  5. At the medallion, say one "Mark of the Wells" - you've now done the core of the Heathen Rosary in miniature
  6. Still holding the medallion, say one "All-Father"
  7. Move to each main bead in the first group of nine (Ninesomes? I need a word like the "decade" in the Catholic Rosary), and on each one, say a "Hail Idun"
  8. When you reach the first Well bead, say one "Mark of the Wells" - this wraps up the first group of nine
  9. For each following group of nine (three more, for four altogether), say one "All-Father," nine "Hail Iduns," and one "Mark of the Wells"
  10. When you get back to the medallion and say the "Mark of the Wells" there, you are through

Above, I've erred on the side of over-explaining. Here's a short rundown that may be more helpful once you have the overall gist:

  • 1x Opening
    • 1x "Hammer Token"
    • 1x "Tree Deeming"
    • 1x "All-Father"
    • 3x "Hail Iduns"
    • 1x "Mark of the Wells"
  • 4x Groups of Nine, each of which is made up of:
    • 1x "All-Father"
    • 9x "Hail Iduns"
    • 1x "Mark of the Wells"

What Is Left?

One bede (the "Closing Bede," likely to Ask and Embla, the first man and woman) is left to write, which will be said upon getting back to the "medallion" (so, after all four groups of nine) and besides that are the "riddles" (what stand in the stead of the mysteries of the Catholic Rosary). Once these are done, the Heathen Rosary will be more-or-less done, as far as I know, but I've been saying the above for about a week now, and it seems to have some "oomph" as is. If you wish to hold an intention while saying these, you might consider praying on behalf of not only yourself, but also all those who say the Heathen Rosary and welcome the blessings of others, or maybe the dead, to help them find their way to whatever their souls' next steps might be.

If you give this a shot, do kindly let me know, as so far, other than very helpful feedback on the wording of the bedes, I've been feeling this out wholly on my own, and I'd like to know if anyone else gets anything worthwhile out of it.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

[Heathen Rosary] Last (?) "All-Father" Bede

Date: 2024-October-13
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

Since I last posted on it, I've worked a few more drafts of the "Allfather" bede ("prayer"), though much of that time has been letting it stew in the deep bits of my mind (at least, that's how I choose to think of letting it sit without any clear work done on it). Luckily, yesterday morning I sat down to push through some drafts one way or another, and I was blessed with a few things clicking, and I think I've got it now. I'm very thankful to everyone who shared thoughts on those drafts I shared before, but most of all I have to thank K.A. Nitz for the insight that a bede to Woden should have more of a feeling of "heroic imitation" than of submissive praise. Coming at it this way let this bede better take on its role of the masculine pole to balance the feminine of the "Hail Idun", not to mention better stringing together the many threads I wanted to fit in. The other thing that helped this one take shape was starting with the end - in the earlier drafts, I had been unhappy with how I closed it, so this time, I wrote the last stanza first, and then worked backwards (though you may mark that the first stanza didn't change much). We'll see how actually saying the bede goes, but I'm very excited, as this now means I have everything I need to say the Heathen Rosary, at least in a prototype form (I'm still working out whether or not to have closing prayers like the Catholic Rosary does).

Without further ado, here's the bede:

All-Father, || who art in Fallhall,
Welcome is Thy call || to win a spot therein.
From barrows cold, || Thy benches we seek.

Worthy we deem it || on to that windswept Tree
To boldly climb up, || cleaving to Thy might,
To watch through all hardship || those worlds nine-fold.

There teach us by Runes, || wrested from nethermost Well,
To weave Thy Craeft || into our wyrd evermore
That our mind-stock stand || steadfast beyond death.

Even though, as I said, I'm pretty happy with it, as always, your thoughts are most welcome.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

[Book] Thoughts on the Deities Are Many

Date: 2024-October-02
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

This was a lovely, short book packed full of great thoughts, both scholarly and personal by Jordan Paper, a professional anthropologist who also happens to actively participate in Chinese traditional religion (he married a lady from Taiwan) and certain American Indian Traditions that he's been initiated into. I have a medium-to-long term project to get up to speed on "polytheistic theology," and when I asked around for works to look into, this book was near the top of many folks' lists, and I can see why. I'd say it's likely about as useful to practicing polytheists looking for some ways of thinking about divinity in the world and how to shape their beliefs as to outsiders looking for a more "anthropological" take on a handful of polytheistic traditions. If that sounds at all interesting, I recommend you check it out - it's only about 150 pages in a small, digest-size format, and it has a wonderful "further reading" section, with very helpful commentary from the author on what he thinks about those sources (something of which I'm very fond indeed).

Just What the Heck is "Theology" Anyway?

Paper points out in the introduction that the term "theology" has some problems, but that it nevertheless seemed like the best word for what he was about with this book. If you go to a university (or these days, more likely a seminary) and look for professors of theology, or classes on theology, they will overwhelmingly be about Christianity, with maybe a handful nodding toward Judaism or Islam, but with crickets for anything polytheistic. In large part, of course, this is due to historical circumstance. For the last thousand years or so in the West, the only religious study that you could do at all was about Christianity, so of course theology was about Christianity, and today's institutions have inherited this bias. Another, more interesting wrinkle is the fact that monotheism, at least the flavors of monotheism dominant in the world today, is constitutionally predisposed towards "theology," whereas many (most?) polytheistic traditions are not. As their common label implies, the "religions of the book" are all based on an authoritative written document which is believed to contain most or all of what you really need for the religion, and all of them put a lot of weight on their followers believing what is contained in their respective books as literally correct truth-propositions. Yes, yes, I know, there are all kinds of esoteric interpretations and non-literalist schools of exegesis out there, but fundamentally, Christianity, Judaism, and Islam all ask their followers to believe that certain things about the world are and must be true, and to shape their beliefs, values, and behavior to those propositions. Within this framework, you can see how a rigorous, logical, even "scientific" study of religion could not only arise, but become an important pillar in the overall religious undertaking.

Most polytheistic traditions, on the other hand, put far less weight on doctrine and episteme, and far more on gnosis. In a sense, it's more empirical, in the plain meaning of the word: we do some stuff, observe results, and go with that, without necessarily working out an explanatory theory behind it. This is not a universal rule, of course, as is made obvious by works like Proclus's Elements of Theology, which was exactly the kind of rigorous, logical, "scientific" attempt to analyze and understand the nature of divinity that I said comes so naturally to monotheism, but to say that that approach was/is not the norm among polytheists would be an understatement. Most polytheistic approaches to religion are shaped by custom, tradition, personal experience, and other such fuzzy, human variables far more than syllogisms grounded in bedrock premises taken from an authoritative text or philosophical reasoning.

Which brings us back to Paper's project with this book. If the kind of "theology" that the word usually refers to is alien to most polytheistic experience and belief, what might a book of "polytheistic theology" even be doing? He addresses this in a characteristically polytheistic way by stressing that any theology will, of necessity, be personal, because all religion, even religion of the book, is deeply personal, if it is to be alive and vital at all. So, the Summa Theologica is not the "theology," it is "Aquinas's theology," and by the same token, The Deities are Many is "Jordan Paper's theology." This stance has the benefits of being broadly defensible and consonant with the general ethos of most polytheistic traditions, but is, of course, a touch unsatisfying. If you're at all like me, and maybe this is just the weight of a thousand years of cultural history speaking, you want "the" theology: a definitive, reasonable exploration of what we do and can know of the nature of divinity and whatever Being or Beings embody that divinity.

I suspect that the best we can do, unless we accept the premise of the religions of the book, that this written source truly is authoritative, is something pretty close to Paper's approach here, as unsatisfying as it may at times feel. Perhaps if more of us could have the depth and breadth of experience he has had, reflect on it as thoughtfully as he has, and share it with each other, we might be able to arrive at some kind of tentative synthesis that gets closer to "this is the way divinity is," rather than "this is what my experience of divinity has been," even if the furthest we get is "this seems to be what divinity is usually like, for most folks." So, if that sounds like the kind of thing you could or would do, do please get on it - we'd all appreciate it.

The Weight of the Personal and Experiential

As I mentioned above, Paper intentionally and forthrightly grounds most of what he has to say in his own experiences, giving the book a very gnostic flavor (note the lower case here, not "Gnostic" like the Nag Hammadi library, just meaning "based on knowledge through personal experience more than knowledge from books or doctrine"). Considering both his profession (an anthropologist of religion) and his personal experience (having participated in and/or been inducted into various American Indian, African-Diaspora, and Chinese practices), this turns out to be extraordinarily rich. I think I mentioned back in my review of The Idea of the Holy how there's some worth in approaching religion from the "inside" as a believer, and some in approaching from the "outside" as an observer (but likely more to come on this once I can get my thoughts in order), and Paper nimbly leaps back and forth between these stances, sometimes in discussing the very same event. Among the advantages of this approach is that he strikes a pretty good balance between systematizing, categorizing analysis and nuanced, organic discussion of particular ceremonies, beings, practices, and so forth. I have to imagine this particular approach would be wildly useful if you yourself were mainly interested in American Indian and Chinese traditional practices, with a smattering of African-Diaspora experiences, but the downside, of course, is that those of us operating outside of these traditions find much less that is directly useful or applicable. I know, I know, as an American Heathen with Revival Druid and Platonist leanings, I can't expect anyone to map to my weirdo beliefs 1-to-1, much less erudite and clear-writing scholars, but a man can dream, can't he? Instead, what I have to settle for here is a model of how to approach religious practice and myth, respecting local variation and specificity while still being alive to commonalities and linking threads. Luckily, Paper gives an excellent model for this, and I expect to come back to it again and again as I make sense of my reading and experience.

A Few Tidbits I Liked that Didn't Fit Elsewhere

There were a few bits and bobs in the book that I liked and wanted to call out, but didn't seem to fit into the broader strokes I was painting with this overview, so I thought I'd jam them in here. For one, Paper talks about the entertainment value, especially humor, especially especially scatological humor, in many traditional tales, giving some examples from American Indian myths with which he's familiar. Why do stories of the holy have poop jokes? Well, because one of the ways stories of the holy persist and get passed on is by telling them to children, and kids love poop jokes. Likewise with older audiences and the more salacious elements of myth (this idea was first introduced to me by a memorable passage in Neal Stephenson's Cryptonomicon, where a priest with a classical bent tells the myth of the conception and birth of Erechtheus, the first king of Athens. NSFW). Thus, these stories "stick" and get retold, and whatever lessons or insights about the holy they have to convey pass on through the ages, not despite the poop jokes and sex, but because of them. I thought that was pretty cool. Another interesting bit to me was the role of what is usually called "automatic writing" in the West in traditional Chinese religious traditions, where it is known as "spirit writing" and is very old and very well respected. Apparently, there are mountains of texts purportedly written by various Gods and spirits via human mediums in China and Taiwan, and they're still going strong on cranking them out. These have the strength of being (apparently) direct communication from the focuses of worship Themselves, but of course, the downside of being hard or impossible to verify here on the material plane (take a look at the track record of prophecies via automatic writing sometime if you want to get a feel for how much salt you ought to buy before taking on texts of this sort). One tidbit where I was excited to read, but ultimately disappointed, was his treatment of the Sun and the Moon as deities, and Their genders. See, in Germanish belief, Sun is female and Moon is male, but in most other bodies of myth (including those of most other Indo-European folks), these genders are flipped. He talks about how a female Sun is more common in polar regions, with a male Sun more common in temperate areas, but alas, he offers no way to metaphysically reconcile these, and keeps with his emphasis on the particular human experiences of different groups. Another bit I found useful was the nitty-gritty detail given on ancestor veneration as practiced in Chinese traditional religion, far more than I got in The Ancient City - hopefully by putting these two together, I can get a better handle on what to do with such practices in my own work. Speaking of Chinese religion, I also rather enjoyed his description of local temples, which begin dedicated to one God, but end up with images of whatever Gods locals bring there, and act not only as centers of worship, but also as places to gather, be entertained, and even store grain. They work as community hubs in more ways than one, and are run by a neighborhood committee, not a distinct class of religious specialists. There's a lot more of this ilk in the book, but I'll leave it at that for now.

A Handful of Weaknesses You Might Expect - A Bit Overly Hard on Monotheism and the West Overall

As much as I liked this book, it does, of course, have a few shortcomings, as any book will, but they were mercifully few and detract very little from the overall worth of the book. To me, the most glaring was Paper's antipathy to monotheism throughout. While not as strong or caustic as you might find in, say, books from the Wiccan end of the height of the Neopagan fad, it is there, and I think it weakens his overall take on humans' interactions with the divine. Sure, monotheistic religious experiences are different from polytheistic, and this book is about the latter as distinct from the former, but for better or worse, many of the most profound religious experiences of the last one to two thousand years for large swaths of humanity have been within a monotheistic context. To write these off as wrong or broken somehow strikes me as the same kind of closed-mindedness that Paper castigates monotheists for. Along similar lines, Paper peppers in the kind of denunciations of patriarchy and colonialism you might expect from an anthropologist working around the turn of the 21st century, sometimes with some justification, other times less so. Given some of the biographical details he shares, none of these are that surprising, and strike me mainly as an artifact of his time and place, but as such, they're also less helpful and universally-applicable than much of the book. In my own experience, I find I have far more in common with fellow believers, fellow theists of whatever stripe, than I do with non-believers, whether we worship one God or many, and the kind of needling found here strikes me as undermining that. Overall, though, that's a fairly minor quibble in a generally excellent book.

Last Word - You Should Likely Read This

I know that I'm usually much more equivocal in my recommendations for these reviews, but really, if you're reading this blog, you'll very likely like this book quite a bit, it's not all that expensive, and it's quick. So, just go read it yourself, and let me know what you think!

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

[Book] Thoughts on The Ancient City

Date: 2024-September-15
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

This book's been on my radar for awhile, but after the third or fourth mention of it in a short time, I was like "okay, okay, I can take a hint!" and decided to go ahead and read it. I'm glad I did. It's not overly long and the prose is admirably clear and to the point, with very little of the dryness you might look for from a late 19th century academic. On the other hand, as a book, it's a bit of an odd duck, and it might not be one that everybody needs to read. The main thread is readily stated fairly briefly (see the next bit), and most of the book is "receipts" to back up that thread, so if you hear what the book is about and say "sounds legit," then you might not need much more from it. On the other hand, if it touches on a particular area of interest of yours (as it does for a handful of mine - ancient history, ancestor worship, comparative mythology, politics, anthropology, and so forth), then you might get something out of diving into the nitty-gritty, as I did. Still on the fence? Let's dig in.

The Main Idea - Worship of the Dead was the Groundwork for Society

The main thrust of what Fustel de Coulanges is putting forward is that the oldest kind of worship among the folk we would today call the Indo-Europeans (the then-current word, "Aryan" has some issues, of which the connotations it has gained in the last 70-80 years are not the smallest). He comes to this position by looking at the earliest Greek, Roman, and to a lesser extent, Indian writings about custom and religion and noticing remarkable similarities, specifically around the worship of the dead from whom they came (ancestor veneration). He goes on to argue that much of the Roman and Greek world, especially early on, doesn't make sense unless seen through this lens, and that many of the upheavals these folks went through can best be understood as this early way of seeing their role in the world breaking down or changing over time.

A quick word on words, here: when I can, I try to use words that come from Germanish roots, rather than Latin, Greek, or elsewhere. Mostly this is a taste thing, but it has the strength of often making me say things more simply and concretely. I do this even more with religious words, as there's some worth in using less-familiar words to talk about the numinous. In some religious traditions, there are fine gradations between "veneration," "worship," and other words that are nearly synonymous in everyday speech. Here, I'm using "worship" thanks to its Germanish stock, though in today's English it tends to have a stronger weight than "veneration," and might at times be a touch misleading. The Romans, Greeks, and Indians of elder times may or may not have seen the honored dead as "of the same level" as the Gods (Fustel de Coulanges seems to imply such, but I lean towards the thought that the Catholic and Orthodox distinction between dulia ("veneration," as for saints) and latria ("adoration," for the holy Trinity only) comes from an earlier analogous distinction amongst pagan Romans and Greeks, which is common amongst folks who still perform rituals in honor of their dead while also worshiping more than one God). If it helps, you can remind yourself that "worship" means "to give worth to" and so is a fitting word for any kind of acknowledgment of greater strength and holiness - that's how I square it, anyway.

So, with that out of the way, back to Fustel de Coulanges. He notices a few key things about Roman and Greek religious writings and law, links them together, and draws reasonable inferences from them, tracing their influence through historical events and changes. In the very earliest writings of both of these folks, we find that law was mainly understood as something religious - the Gods and spirits have given us things to do, ways to be, and rules to follow, and it's the priests' job to remember them, and later write them down, so that we don't screw it up. Among these commandments are several regarding the proper treatment and maintenance of the familial dead and their altar, the hearth. These duties fall upon the eldest man in a household, leading to the paterfamilias (the Greeks had a similar concept, but uncharacteristically, no special name that has come into English). It worked like this: dad died, so we bury him on our land. Since he was a powerful and respected man in life, we keep on honoring him in death. Different families work out different ways of how precisely to do this, leading to a specific family cultus (usually rendered in English as "cult," but I'm using the Latin here to emphasize that I don't mean a small, socially rejected and possibly abusive religious sect, but rather a specific set of religious practices, which is the common usage of "cult" in classical and religious studies writings). Despite the variation between families, there were certain things common to all: keeping the grave clean and nice, regular offerings of meals, asking for help in earthly things, acknowledging that help when it comes, and so forth. Okay, so far so good. So, dad's buried in the backyard, and the oldest brother has learned from him this family's ways of worshiping him (and his dad, and his dad, and so forth). His wife, his brothers' wives, and all of their kids, give this worship every day - saying prayers on re-kindling the still smoldering embers of the hearth each morning, readying just the right foods and wines every so often for the grave feast, casting lots or reading the signs of the birds to understand what the forebears are telling them, and so forth. A whole little religion, just for this family. That's the foundation for everything else that follows.

Since this grave and this hearth are sacred sites for this religion, you can't just move or, forebears forbid, sell the land. Which means that the Greeks and Romans developed a sense of land as property much earlier than other Indo-European folks, but not "property" meaning "your own thing to do whatever you want with," but rather meaning "something that no one else has a right to infringe on." Further, since the eldest man in the family is the high priest of his own religion, and only his eldest son can become the next priest, that man gets special status, respect, and powers. The right to approve marriages, tell the kids (and siblings) what to do, and even, if things get bad enough, the power of life and death over everyone in the family. So, you have these self-contained, inviolable little units, literally sacrosanct from the intrusions and interference of the wider society. Law, including what we would think of as "secular" law, reflected this - in most things, it was left to the paterfamilias to decide, and even if not left wholly to him, he was largely deferred to by the courts and magistrates.

But speaking of society, what of other families? How might men and women come together into larger groups? Well, over time, a family tree does tend to branch, and if every generation has 2-4 sons, the backyard is gonna get pretty crowded. So families split into new families, but remember where they came from. You might have a different paterfamilias than me, but if we recall that some time back we had a shared forebear, we can come together to worship him. Now we have clans, or as the Romans called them, gentes (singular: gens). Daily you worship the dead of your family, but once a year or so, you might get together with a few other families to worship the common dead of your gens. Alright, well, after a long enough time, what of multiple gentes with a forebear common to all? That's where the titular "city" comes in. The founder of a city becomes the ultimate forebear of every gens, and thus every family. Beyond this, everyone is an outlander, whether they speak the same tongue, look roughly the same, or even worship the same Gods (more on this in a tick). How might this city work out what it should do? Well, obviously, ask the head of each gens, who might ask the head of each constituent family what they think. From these seeds grew the shapes we came to know as the republic (from Latin res publica, the "public thing," which in light of this book, has an evocative contrast with the private things of the family and gens).

All of this is neat and tidy enough, but obviously it didn't last for the whole of classical history. If the only way to get into a family, much less a gens, is to be born there or marry into it, what about folks who move to the city to make a living? Or who spring from a distant enough branch to have lost the trunk from which it sprang? In this original conception, there's no room for them. In both the Roman and Greek worlds, these folks ended up as clients of the families with land, names, and rites/rights. In Rome, they came to be known as the plebeians. Remember, law and rights were originally expressions of what was commanded or guaranteed by religion, and religion as we've spoken of it so far only came with membership in these families, so outsiders had none unless they could get one of these families to act on their behalf. Well, if you're one of these outsiders, this kind of sucks, especially if you're an "outsider" who was born in the city, and your own forefathers were born here, back as far as anyone can remember. Oh, and what if you're rich? And the fancy, ancient family next door is poor? You might feel a bit of dissatisfaction, to put it mildly.

Fustel de Coulanges outlines some workarounds that were added as the plebeians started to demand more and more recognition. At first, they were allowed some amount of participation in the gentes of their patrons, and eventually were put into "artificial" gentes. The need for plebeian participation in the army drove a lot of this. Fustel de Coulanges also argues that as time went on, more weight was put on the temples and worship of the Gods held in common by everyone in the city - the familiar "great" Gods, like Jupiter, Venus, Minerva, and so forth. Their worship was public and shared, and so it was easier to fold in the plebeians. As they became more important economically, politically, and militarily, worship that included them became more prominent. This is one area where I think Fustel de Coulanges might be a bit off. He subscribes to the common view of the late 19th/early 20th century that these Gods were "only" the Gods of natural phenomena - Jupiter is the thunder, Venus is the attraction between men and women, Hephaestus is the volcano, and so forth. While not wrong, I think this view is overly simplistic, due to being overly materialist. Sure, Jupiter is the thunder, but He is not only the thunder. I would instead say that the thunder is one manifestation of the bigger sphere owned by Him. I also think that Fustel de Coulanges over-commits to his (real, legitimate) insight on the importance of household worship, which leads him to downplay how important the Gods of the pantheon always were. The comparative mythological evidence for these Gods among Indo-European peoples is too strong for them to have been added late or lacking in importance from a very ancient date. This doesn't necessarily undermine the historical and political ramifications he spells out for worship within the household, most of all of the family's forebears, but I think it means that the impression he gives of what ancient religion "felt" like is somewhat off, which is clearly of more interest to folks interested in religious reconstruction than those of a more traditional historical bent.

What I Wanted Out of It - A Thorough Rundown of Worship of the Dead

That brings us to what I was most hoping to get out of this book, which was a deeper and more granular understanding of Roman and Greek forebear worship. Having read the book, that was clearly secondary to what Fustel de Coulanges was up to. For him, the forebear worship was mostly interesting as a factor in shaping the worldview of the Romans and Greeks that showed up in how they organized politically and interacted with the wider world. So, I want to give full credit to him for doing a great job on what he set out to accomplish. That goal just wasn't what I was most interested in, especially since I already felt like I had gotten a good feel for that from the reviews I had read/listened to on the book. My own religious practice features forebear worship, but it's a part of it where there's a lot less to go on from the historical and mythological sources we have for pre-Christian Heathenry (Germanish polytheism) than we might like. As such, today's Heathens have to look to other traditions that include forebear worship to get ideas. Many of these traditions, like Chinese traditional religion or the African-diaspora religions, spring from very different cultural and historical milieus, and so might have limited value as relevant inspirations. While the Greek and Roman religions incorporated a lot of different influences than the other Indo-European religions, they're at least coming from common roots, so there might be more directly relevant insights there. I've talked before about the mixed role reconstruction has in my own practice, but it is a factor. As such, I was excited for what this book might have to teach me.

On this front, I'd say it was a mixed success. There are a few evocative details of what day-to-day forebear worship was like, but time and again, Fustel de Coulanges's focus on what this behavior means for the social and political world of the Greeks and Romans takes precedence. He also takes what I might characterize as an absolutist position on such practices: he stresses the absolute secrecy and exclusivity of the family cult, the unyielding precedence of the eldest male family member, the impossibility of changing ancient ways of doing things. To a certain degree, this makes sense, as a way to counter our too-ready tendency to project our own mindset and way of seeing the world onto folks in the past, but I think he pushes it too hard. The very fact that he outlines several changes to what he describes as the ur-religion shows that some amount of flexibility was there over time. I suspect that all along these practices were more flexible than Fustel de Coulanges presents them.

If you're willing to go a bit "out there" with me for a tick, there's an added wrinkle that builds on our discussion of the planes. In The Secret of the Temple and Monsters, John Michael Greer talks a bit about something he's expanded on in comments on his blog here and there. According to the traditional beliefs that have informed modern occult philosophy, the etheric body separates from the physical body at death (the body of life-force leaving the body of meat is, in fact, what defines "death" in this model). Under normal circumstances, without a physical anchor, this subtle body dissipates within a few days, especially as exposed to etherically charged phenomena in the natural world, most of all sunlight. If you look at various ancient tales and at the archaeological record, though, at some point, you find cultures that built elaborate tombs for their highest-status dead, and along with this, where we have writing, descriptions of these dead having some continued presence and influence, hopefully to the benefit of their folk. Occult philosophy provides an explanation of what might have been going on here: by burying the body and applying certain preservation methods, you keep the physical anchor for the etheric body around. By burying it in a special way (mounds made of alternating earth and stone, or later, perhaps, pyramids), you protect the etheric body from the natural forces that would normally dissipate it. By giving it sustenance in the form of offered food and drink (which contain etheric energy) and certain forms of worship (which transfer etheric energy from the living to the dead recipient), you could keep this etheric body around and active for some time, and it would be able to keep on acting on the etheric plane to do things like bless crops, heal illness, and so forth. Folks being what they are, though, at certain times in certain places, the fear of death and desire for power came to dominate the pro-social ends for which this practice was developed (or so the story goes), and you started getting individuals kept around through these means that were less concerned with the blessing and healing, and more concerned with holding on to their place in this world, no matter what. As their influence became more obviously baleful and less and less wealful, you got hungry ghosts roaming about looking for etheric energy wherever they could get it, like from spilled blood or drained from the unwilling living, and returning to the protection of their graves to hide from the destroying sun. Why, yes, that is, in fact, what we call vampires. Speculative, I know. Out there, I know. But intriguing, and consistent with the teachings on the subtle world I'm working with right now.

I bring this up because it raises some pretty serious questions about the practice of forebear worship. Is "maintaining the etheric body of specific dead indiviudals so they can (hopefully) bless us, the living" the only thing it's for? If so, then it has little to no value for those of us who don't bury our dead in the backyard, un-embalmed, in natural coffins, and then offer them meals and prayers on the regular. Further, even if we did somehow manage most of these practicalities, outside of a culture and context that prepares us for it, in life and after, might we inadvertently create literal monsters of our loved ones? That's horrifying. Much of what Fustel de Coulanges describes seems consistent with the "keep the etheric body alive" school of forebear worship, but luckily it's not the only game in town, and not all of Greek or Roman practice can be explained in these terms. Besides the possibility of a lingering etheric body, occult philosophy also says that we spend a certain amount of time hanging out on the astral between lives, processing how the last one went to get ready for the next one, and after enough incarnations, we stop incarnating all together and start spending all of our time on the astral and above. This allows for souls who still care about their material descendants to hear prayers, give guidance through dreams and feelings and the like, and to otherwise help in non-material ways. Also, though I don't have a good explanation for this just yet, many (most?) traditions that include ancestor worship also allow for worship of "the ancestors" as a group, as distinct from any worship given to individual forebears. Is this "just" an egregore? A convenient astral "label" that various souls can rotate into and out of? One or more Gods that take on that role? I'm not ready to say.

Altogether, I didn't get as much practical out of this as I might have hoped, but it did help to give some feeling for what hearth and forebear worship would look like as a day-to-day practice, and what role it might play in comparison with worshiping the "great" Gods of myths and public rituals.

Some Strengths and Weaknesses of the Book - Thorough and Respectful, but too Materially-Focused

I've hit on most of these already, but I thought it'd be helpful to call out what I saw as the greatest strengths and weaknesses of this book in its own section. As I said before, Fustel de Coulanges is very careful to stress how strong a role these beliefs must have played for those who held them, and to spell out how different they were from the beliefs most of us hold today. He also takes great pains to emphasize that no, really, the ancients actually believed this stuff. Amidst the growing atheism of his time, there was a tendency among academics to look back on the religion of the Greeks and Romans, notice how it favored the upper classes, and assume that it was a cynical ploy to control the masses. This allows him to very effectively counter the tendency to see the ancients as "just like us," which is a helpful corrective. He also shows a phenomenal command of primary sources - almost everything in the book is backed up with quotes from ancient sources, which is nice to see. Put these together, and you see Fustel de Coulanges draw the implications of his core argument through disparate sources over long stretches of time. It's all very convincing and very carefully done.

On the weaknesses side, Fustel de Coulanges shows some of the biases of his time, such as the particular combination of scientific materialism and casual, default Christianity particularly characteristic of European intellectuals of the late 19th century. His remarkable command of the classical sources also doesn't include what we've come to know since through a century of comparative Indo-European study. The few comparisons he makes with early Indian sources were groundbreaking for the time, but our picture these days has been enriched quite a bit. I think this contributed to the lower weight he put on worship of the Gods of nature (which was also undoubtedly a response to an over-emphasis on the neat, tidy impression of the Gods of myth as "the whole religion" that was common from the Renaissance through the 19th century). Also, though Fustel de Coulanges stressed that the ancients actually believed what they said they did, his "reasonable" late 19th century frame can't help but assume the reasons they believed these things were all psychological in nature, or due to mistakes (since, obviously, some combination of science and monotheism was the real truth). As such, the idea that they believed these things because there was something to them (like, say, your crops actually growing better when you performed the rites the way you were supposed to) doesn't seem to cross his mind. Fair enough, from his frame of reference, but disappointing for those of us who don't share it.

Some Strengths and Weaknesses of the Talk About the Book - Acknowledging a Need against Over-Focus on "Social Technology"

I mentioned above that I had read and listened to some reviews about this book before finally giving it a read. While I enjoyed these and found them valuable, they also all came from various standpoints of not really buying that the Greeks and Romans were right to worship their dead. Instead, most of these commenters have focused on how useful believing such things seems to have been. In fact, it was in response to some of these reviews that I wrote my post on social technology. It's not that I disagree that the social technology side of these beliefs wasn't real or potentially useful - besides social and cultural continuity, it also fostered an extremely strong attachment to decentralized decision-making and power that I can't help but admire. Since each family was its own little religious community, and the law was (largely) based on religious strictures, each family was also its own little political entity. This aspect of things was extremely persistent, even through major upheavals in the social and political structure of society - even the rather late law code of Justinian, compiled after Rome had become an empire, lost its western half, and even become Christian, reflected the ancient weight put on families as the building block of the body politic. So, I sympathize with those who read this book and say "wow, it sure would be nice if we had something like that today." The trouble is, I don't think you can just decide to start worshiping your ancestors for the purposes of social cohesion or stronger political decentralization. Especially if, as some of these commenters assume, that society ought to be mostly or entirely Christian. It's putting the cart before the horse. It's not just a technology you pick up or put down as it's useful. You worship your forebears if you believe it's a religiously meaningful thing to do, and if enough folks in your society agree, then you get a society with these strengths.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

[Book] Thoughts on The Idea of the Holy

Date: 2024-September-08
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

At this point, I can't remember what put The Idea of the Holy by Rudolf Otto on my "to read" list, but I'm glad I got to it. It's a pretty quick read, it's a building block for a lot of later work (I get the impression Eliade especially draws on its thoughts), and it's actually very readable, whether due to the original German prose or the expertise of the translator (John W. Harvey, who worked closely with Otto to put together the English version), I can't say. Otto, like Spengler, seems to have been one of those products of turn-of-the-20th-century Germany who showed much of the best of the German soul - widely read, analytical, but with a sense for and appreciation of the subjective and qualitative. As I'll go over in a bit more detail at the end, I'd say this book is well worth reading if you're interested in understanding what religion is and how it works, maybe slightly less so if you're laser-focused on practice, but with a few helpful insights there nonetheless.

The Mysterium Tremendum, Numen, and Numinous

The beating heart of this book, and the reason that it has remained central to the field of religious studies for over a century is Otto's identification and naming of the concept of the Mysterium Tremendum, and that which engenders that experience as the Numen, which can be described as "numinous." If you've read anything in the field, it might surprise you to learn that these terms are so relatively new. I know it did me. On the other hand, if these terms are new to you, let me break them down. Otto contends that religion is not merely about logically-arguable propositions or developed theology, but instead an essential component is direct experience of something other, something weird - the Mysterium Tremendum or "Tremendous Mystery." Something that folks can feel very deeply, but not fully understand or describe. He goes on to say that whatever it is that produces this response is the numen, a Latin word that meant something like the power and/or mind of a divine being, the special something that a God has that lesser beings lack. The adjectival form of this word is "numinous." So, to put all of this together: when a man encounters the numen, that encounter is numinous, and the feeling he experiences is the Mysterium Tremendum. Are we good on these terms? Good, because they'll be coming up a lot throughout this review and in later posts.

Otto touches on a few interesting things in discussing this facet of religious experience. For one, he points out that some English words better convey it than his native German (which is especially interesting to encounter in an English translation) - take the word "awfulness." As you may or may not have reflected on, the original meaning of "awful" is "full of awe," though, of course, these days we use it to mean "very bad." How did we get there? Well, imagine sitting on a surfboard looking up at a monster wave looming over you, or standing at the top of a sheer cliff with nothing between you and a few seconds of regret before a hard landing but whistling wind. Such immensity inspires awe, but it is also dangerous, which we usually see as a bad thing. Over time, the danger came to be emphasized over the awe, and so now awful just means "pretty bad." Otto's point is that this original mixed response to something utterly beyond us pretty well captures what a raw, untaught response to the numen feels like - a sense of something big and thus worthy of respect, but also wariness. Many other instances he cites as less refined experiences of the numinous have an element of fear - the creepiness of a ghost story, the thrill of overlooking a canyon, that kind of thing.

Another of Otto's points I found especially interesting is how he distinguishes this religious experience from the merely subjective. He talks about how the experience of the numinous is felt as an encounter with something obviously separate, and obviously there - something objective, not merely subjective. This jives with my own experiences so far. A religious experience doesn't feel like "just" a feeling, it feels like an encounter with something else, which produces certain feelings. This is one of those things where Otto's sensitivity to the kinds of things empirical materialist rationalism tends to ignore shines through, I think to his credit.

The Rational and the Non-Rational

Speaking of Otto taking seriously those things that rationalism tends to miss, a central thread running through the book is the importance of both the rational and the non-rational in developed religions. He has a lovely metaphor for this: the rational is the warp of religion, and the non-rational the weft, woven together into a full tapestry, but each incomplete and unstable without the other. He's careful to distinguish between the ir-rational and the non-rational: whatever is irrational goes against reason and is undone by it, but some things are not properly subject to reason (love being the canonical example, of course), and these are simply non-rational. Not against reason, but merely inadequately understood by it. In the realm of religion, the heart of this non-rational field of experience is the encounter with the numinous.

The numen is something experienced as somehow "supra-mundane": Otto uses the word "supernatural" to convey that it is qualitatively different from meeting something awe-inspiring, but wholly understandable in material terms (like a majestic mountain or an apex predator), but I prefer to avoid that term about spiritual things, because I don't believe that Gods, spirits, magic, and all the rest are "beyond" "nature." Rather, they are parts of nature far beyond our mundane experience, in part because they partake of other planes of being than the more familiar material. Because these decidedly non-ordinary experiences are outside of what our senses and reason can confidently handle, we have trouble explaining them, giving them an "ineffable" quality. In this way, such experiences are somewhat akin to subjective judgments like sublimity or beauty, but are still distinctly something else. One set of metaphors you encounter over and over again in attempted descriptions of the numinous is a quality of "void" or "emptiness." Otto had what I considered a very worthwhile insight here, which I think came from the sensitivity to qualitative factors over slavish devotion to the rational that I've been praising throughout. When you consider the objective quality of the numinous mentioned above, then it's obviously nonsensical to consider the "void" to mean actual, literal "nothing." Instead, it's an attempt to describe the utter lack of the familiar, a loss of presence or significance of all of the mundane perceptions and concerns that usually so occupy us. I rather liked this, as it helps me put a lot of spiritual writings I've always found somewhat off-putting, like much of Buddhist and Taoist teachings, in a wholly different light, whereas before I'd always picked up a sense of nihilism from my potentially naive reading of terms like "void."

One of the reasons Otto insisted on cooking up a new terminology, and that everyone since has found it useful, is that words like "sacred" and "holy" (despite the name of the book) have become less helpful due to acquiring connotations that cloud the perception of the core idea. Specifically, these words have come to have moral weight in addition to describing the sense of the "other" and "mighty" that the numinous imparts. Otto tries to deal with the complexity of this, and has some good insights, but this was one area where I felt his own religious beliefs intruded on clear-eyed analysis (more on this in a moment). Basically, he highlights the fact that many, maybe even most, experiences of the numinous include a sense of at least desirability, if not outright goodness. Something about an encounter with the numinous makes folks (at least, some folks) want more of it, to the point that some end up devoting their whole lives to it (monks, mystics, and the like). Coming at it the other way, the immensity of the numinous can also often instill feelings of smallness, inadequacy, or even unworthiness. Often, the nearest experience that folks who have encounters like this can compare to is that of being unclean in the midst of something pure.
