More Rough "All Father" Prayers

Date: 2024-August-14
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

As I mentioned the last time I posted some drafts, I'm having some trouble getting this one right, but I'm starting to feel like I'm getting closer. As a reminder, this is for the Heathen Rosary undertaking, and this prayer structurally takes the place of the "Our Father" in the Catholic Rosary - you say it once before starting a group of Hail Iduns, and is meant in some ways to contrast and complement with what's expressed there. Overall, I'm not very happy with the density of mythic references/kennings (too low!), and though I've found a few spots of rhythm that work, I can't quite stick the ending on any of these.

So, even moreso than usual, I welcome any thoughts or feedback as I keep on trying to craft something worthy of Him for daily practice.

Draft 3

This one loosened up the "three stanza" format I tried with the previous ones and also breaks all the rules of Anglo-Saxon long lines on line two, but it has a few more mythic references than other versions, and I mostly like its rhythm.

All Father, || who art in Fallhall,
Welcome us with mead, || as our forefathers before us
From barrows cold || called on to your benches.
From plighted eye, || plucked fearlessly,
Share your drink || drawn from Meomer's Well
That we lose not || learning hard-won.
By Wyrd's dear Runes, || raven's whispers,
Let us rise up || and look full upon
Those worlds ninefold || with naught hidden from our sight.
Alu.

Draft 4

This one is another take on what I did with the Lord of Fallhall's Prayer - both are modeled very closely on the "Our Father/Lord's Prayer," though this one departs a bit more semantically, as I was mostly seeking to emulate the rhythm, and secondarily things like repetition and alliteration. Mark that this one doesn't follow any kind of Germanish Lay, but instead rests its poetry on evoking the feel of the familiar Christian prayer.

All Father, who art in Fallhall,
Welcome is thy call,
Thy wisdom taught, thy mead be shared,
On earth as it is in Fallhall.
Teach us this life your mighty Rune,
And open our inmost souls,
As we open our eyes to what's before us.
Let us not forget your teachings,
And make fast our mind-stock,
For thine are the worlds nine,
And the Tree on which they hang,
Forever and Ever.
Alu.

Draft 5

This one obviously shares a lot with Draft 3 - I was mostly trying to see if I could get more of a clear through-line with some of the same ideas.

All Father, || who art in Fallhall,
Welcome is thy call - || from cold barrows
To benches warm, || where beer freely flows,
Almost as stirring || as mind-stock there shared.
Wisdom you won || from Wells threefold:
Mighty was your thirst, || as Meomer well-saw!
Through worlds all-nine || naught is hidden to you,
With ravens whispering || rede overheard,
Kindly teach to us || the ken you have learned.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

A (Beginner's) Manual of the Planes

Date: 2024-August-04
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

(The name of this post is a D&D joke, by the way. As much fun as the planes are as imaginary worlds to have exciting adventures in, that's not what we'll be talking about.)

For awhile now, I've been meaning to lay out my current thinking on a concept I've learned through occult philosophy that has come to shape my way of approaching the world rather a lot, but was wholly alien to me only a few years ago. I'm talking about the planes of existence, and even if you don't truck with all this woo-woo metaphysical nonsense, they're a concept I think you'll find interesting and potentially helpful for making sense of the vagaries of human experience.

So, what do we even mean by "planes"? First off, I don't mean the geometrical or astronomical concept of a perfectly flat, two-dimensional expanse. Nor do I mean alternate dimensions that you can bodily visit and duke it out with demons. And mechanical flying devices are right out. Rather, think of phrases like "he operates at a higher plane" or "on the plane of thought." According to the teachings I work with, all of the planes are always and everywhere simultaneously present. They are discrete, not continuous, but they meet and influence each other at certain points of contact (such as the human body and consciousness). Different experiential phenomena happen on different planes, even if you experience them at the same time. Imagine yourself sitting on a porch, enjoying a lovely day. Gravity holds you in your chair, you feel the wood of the chair and the air of the wind against your skin, the warmth of the sun keeps you from getting too chilly, and with all of this going on, you call to mind another, similar day and the feelings it kindles within you. Right here in this simple scene, we have gravitational force, matter, radiant energy, and thought (whatever that is), and you're simultaneously experiencing all of them. Our understanding is that these phenomenon are importantly distinct in their actions and how we perceive them, even if there are certain ways they influence each other.

That's much closer to what an occultist is getting at when he's talking about the planes than what your buddy has in mind when he's going to run a Planescape campaign. I mentioned above that I think this concept can be useful even if you don't buy it as a literal explanation of how the world is put together metaphysically (at least most of it). One of the most useful habits of thought I've picked up from these kinds of studies has been the way that Dion Fortune explains the point of her masterwork The Cosmic Doctrine - these ideas are to "train the mind, not inform it." In other words, if you approach the world and your experiences with this model, you just might find certain things make sense to you and you can solve problems ways that you might find hard or impossible to do otherwise. So, if you find the fires of skepticism rising in your breast as you read this, try to consider what I'm saying as "merely" qa potentially fruitful metaphor. The very nature of what we're discussing precludes slam-dunk, independently-verifiable experimental proof, so who am I to say "this is the way things really are," much less to try to convince you that you should think so? So, with all that out of the way, let's take a short tour through the planes and what we know about them, with a few thoughts on why they make for a helpful model.

The Material Plane

We'll begin with the plane most obvious to us with the least controversial existence - the material. This is the realm of experience that includes matter and energy, the one that materialists claim is all there is. The scientific method is our species's great triumph in interrogating and understanding this plane, and we have learned much by assuming that things ought to be explainable on this plane, and setting about clever ways to work those explanations out. See all of 19th and 20th century physics for a hint at how far exploration of only this plane can take us. I don't think I need to say much here, as most of us have a pretty good grip on what the material world is like and how our experience is shaped by it. Our senses give us certain information about the world around us, certain forces and laws that can be observed and measured influence us, and what we can accomplish is limited by certain constraints. Straightforward enough.

Some practical tips for the Material Plane: If you want to explore this plane, the first and most important thing is to pay attention (this will be a running theme). Spend some time observing very closely what your senses are telling you. Get curious about things you usually take for granted. If you want to go deep, science is your greatest tool, with some helpful assists from philosophy, art, and history. For your material body, do all the stuff you already know you should be doing to take care of your health: eat a good mix of real foods, get a decent amount of moderate exercise, sleep enough, and so forth.

The Etheric Plane

As we leave the familiar material plane, we run into one of the bits of planar lore that you might find confusing if you decide to do some reading of your own, which is the seemingly fundamental concept of "how many planes even are there? and what are they?" At first glance, it looks like a big, ugly jumble with little to no agreement amongst occultists of various stripes and times, which might lead you think it's all mularkey. Careful attention suggests an alternate explanation, though: different thinkers and explorers have drawn the borders at different places, some lumping together fields of experience, others parsing them more precisely. But when you actually dig in to what is described, you find a great deal of agreement, albeit with different categorization, which isn't so surprising when you consider we're talking about fields of experience that are not so amenable to experimental and shareable verification as material experience. The model of seven planes that I currently work with comes from John Michael Greer, and is drawn largely from late 19th and early 20th century occultism, which is itself a distant descendant and rebirth of Renaissance occultism, which was a descendant of traditions reaching back to ancient Greece and Egypt ("Hermeticism" is the usual word for this throughline, as Hellenistic (and maybe earlier) explorers of the esoteric traced the tradition back to the Greek God Hermes, syncretized with the Egyptian Thoth). The seven-fold division is something you'll find all over the place in occult literature, and it most likely derives from the seven classical "planets" (luminary bodies visible to the naked eye that move through the sky in different relative positions, rather than keeping fixed positions like the stars - the Sun, the Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn). This puts this system farther toward the "fine distinctions" end of things, as opposed, say, to some Revival Druidry teachings I'm also working with that settle on three planes, clustering these seven into broader categories (Physical for one, Etheric + Astral + Mental for two, and Spiritual, Causal, and Divine for the last).

Anyhow, as for the Etheric itself, this is the plane of the "life force" that is commonly experienced and understood by just about every culture ever except for the modern industrial world. Think of Obi-Wan talking about the Force, and you're not too far off. One clear, if fairly harsh, way to understand what the etheric plane is about is to find yourself looking at a fresh corpse, especially one of a pet or loved one. If you've ever had this unfortunate experience, it'll have been obvious that this collection of matter is not the person or animal that was there a few hours ago. A materialist might say that this sense comes from picking up on subtle physical cues like the lack of breath or subconsciously-noticeable movement, but the occult explanation is in some ways more straightforward: something that was there before is now gone - the etheric body that gives life to dull matter. Another common way we experience the etheric plane is when we go to a place and get a sense of its "vibes" - are there some places where you just feel good, and you don't really know why? Or where you feel unsettled and want to leave straightaway? A large part of that is likely what's going on there etherically. More personally, any time you feel alert, alive, and full of energy, your etheric "body" is likely doing well, and any time you feel drained, sluggish, or unhealthy, it's likely not.

I mentioned that this plane is one of the first where you get into disagreements about how many planes there are and where their borders are, because some folks consider the etheric the least-obvious part of the material plane, others the "most physical" part of the astral plane, and still others call it a plane of its own (as this system does). The different categorizations stem from the fact that the etheric plane interacts pretty strongly with both the material and astral planes. Ever gone for a run or done a hard lift and walked away feeling strong and alive and on top of the world? You just charged up your etheric body. On the other hand, if you've done one of those and come away drained and exhausted, you maybe pushed your etheric body too hard. Alternatively, ever found yourself stirred and driven by an inspiring story or uplifting song (maybe before or during that run or lift)? Here, the astral has woken up the etheric body. The point is, if you pay close attention, you'll start noticing that this feeling of energy is correlated, but not 100%, with what is going on in your body or your thoughts and emotions.

One rather dramatic illustration of this struck me a few years ago. I teach at a university, and in the spring of 2020, we had to go from teaching in person to teaching via Zoom. From one week to the next, I went from giving a lecture to a room full of students to giving the exact same lecture to a computer screen. Before that, I had never understood what folks meant when they talked about getting "energy" from a crowd while public speaking, but this made it very clear. After a lecture in person, I'm usually a bit tired, but I feel good, satisfied. After giving a Zoom lecture, I felt completely drained and foggy, like I needed a nap. Another, slightly spicier case - have you ever found yourself surprised to feel attracted to or aroused by someone? When I was in college, there was a girl in one of my classes, and every time I was around her, I was distractingly turned on, but if I thought about her when she wasn't around, I was like "she's cute and seems nice," but that was all. Looking back, I suspect that something about our etheric bodies was compatible, but less so astrally, in which case my imagination would have been more inflamed (of course, it might also have been something physical, like pheremones, but either way, the difference was very striking).

Some practical tips for the Etheric Plane: Most of what you do to explore the material world can help in exploring the etheric plane as well, but you'll have to pay attention to some different things. For me, I most strongly feel what I believe to be etheric influence as a tingly feeling of "energy," mostly in my chest and belly, but sometimes in my arms or the back of my neck. From what I hear, something like this is fairly common, but other folks experience it different ways - some see colors or flows of energy, some just get an intuitive sense of things, others feel some physical movements as easier or harder, so there's a lot of variation. Pay attention to how you feel at different places and see if being around certain people perks you up or drains you. As for taking care of your etheric body, all of the physical stuff will help, but add to that regular doses of clean, fresh air and sunlight. Intentional breathing exercises, like pranayama or Wim Hof breathing, can help to cultivate etheric energy and the health of your etheric body. Cold water can also be helpful, though you don't have to go full polar bear - even a washcloth of cold water rubbed all over your body can have a remarkably invigorating effect. Sex is another place you can learn things: when are you turned on? When are you not turned on even if your mind says you "should" be? How do you feel after having sex? What about after getting yourself off? All of these can be useful clues about how these experiences are not only mediated by raw physicality or mental images and emotions.

The Astral Plane

This is the plane that almost every model of the planes includes as its own thing, in large part since it is where most occult work takes place. The Astral Plane is the plane of concrete thoughts and emotions - images, sounds, words, and all of the feelings that go along with them. Whenever you daydream, whenever you read a novel and imagine what is going on, whenever you craft an argument in your head before saying it out loud, you are operating mostly on the Astral. Maybe our purest experience of the Astral Plane is when we dream. That being said, most of what consider "thinking" happens on the Astral (more on the exceptions when we get to the Mental Plane). The Astral has a funny relationship to time and space - it has some kind of association, which you'll notice if you have a favorite place to read or study, or if you've ever felt certain thoughts or feelings stirred by a place where something important happened, but it can also clearly ignore typical spatial limits, as when you find yourself thinking the thoughts of an Athenian from more than 2,000 years ago by reading his works, or the way that in a dream you can be in a room that is simultaneously your childhood bedroom and a library.

If you give any credence to the more woo-woo way of taking this model, this is where things start to get really interesting. The Astral Plane provides the causal mechanism for most phenomena we call "psychic" or "magical." If you are a materialist, there are some ways to assume that these effects might be possible with some kind of physical intermediation, even if its non-obvious. For example, if I vividly imagine an emotion I want you to feel and focus all of my mental effort on "putting it on you," and you end up feeling that emotion, the occult explanation would be that I've influenced you via the Astral Plane. A materialist would likely look for some means of physically transmitting that intention - words spoken between us, subtle body language cues, pheremones, or something of the kind. Whatever your beliefs, I ask you for a moment to consider what I think is one of the most interesting (and sometimes alarming) implications of the occult model. In the occult understanding, most thinking is more akin to an act of perception than production - you are accessing things that are "out there" in the astral. In some sense, as you direct your thinking, it is less that you are "making" your thoughts as you are steering from one to the next, an act of exploration rather than of creation. Now, my current understanding is that this isn't 100% the case - there is some amount of creation involved, but it gets fuzzy and hard to tell what is creation and what perception. As far as I know, most occultists don't believe that every thought, imagination, or feeling that will ever be conceived is pre-existing and just waiting for us to find it. But most thinking, especially the kind that involves concrete imagination of sights, sounds, smells, and so forth, is built out of our stock of experience. I have a much easier time imagining a newly-made-up tree for having seen a lot of trees in my life - something of all of those trees is in the new one. If I had lived my whole life in a desert or out on the steppe, I might not be able to conjure an image of a tree at all! Likewise, none of us is an island, and we grow up surrounded by the stories, images, and other accoutrements of our culture. We likewise draw on these when we imagine things. Another example is that if you've ever collaborated with someone on a creative project, you've also no doubt had the experience of describing things to each other, each of you adding on to what the other puts out there, and ending up with something that neither of you could have made on your own.

The point is, the occult view is that the products of these imaginings are now "out there" in the astral - the more thought, effort, and emotion you put into coming up with it, the more sturdy the new image. If you repeatedly come back to the same imagining and each time invest it with as much vividness as you can, over time, it might start surprising you with some amount of independence - think of the way authors of fiction talk about a character "taking on a life of his own" or letting him know that "I wouldn't do that." So far so good, but the really freaky implication of the occult model is that these constructs are not "just in your head." "In your head" is not a real place, it's just the part of the Astral where you have the greatest perception and control. But everything you put into the astral is now out in the realm of experience shared by all conscious beings. If your thinking is at least as much "finding" as it is "making," that means so is everyone else's, and if something you made/found/shaped is out there, then others can find it too. And more freaky still, "your" thoughts might not always be as wholly your own as you like to think. The more time you spend with the thoughts of others, the more they become your thoughts. The more time, effort, and energy you put into certain kinds of thoughts, the more your astral life will happen in the kind of neighborhoods where those thoughts are at home. In other words, spend all your time thinking hateful thoughts and around hateful folks, and you will find it harder to have any other kinds of thoughts or feelings. And so will the folks around you. Scary stuff.

Some Practical Tips for the Astral Plane: To explore the Astral, find various "creative" ways to use your mind. Daydream. Draw. Write fiction. Fantasize. Make music. As you do, pay attention to what feels like hard work and what just "comes to you." Pay attention also to what kind of stuff you spend your time with - what shows do you watch? What social media do you read? What music do you listen to? Do you find yourself having more or fewer of certain kinds of thoughts when you spend more time with certain kinds of media? Or people? Discursive meditation and basic ritual are also great ways develop your astral awareness, if you want to jump in with both feet. As for keeping your astral body healthy, here, "you are what you think." Try to pay attention to how you think, what you think about, and especially what you vividly visualize or fantasize about. Is that what you want your thoughts to feel like? If not, find some ways to start avoiding the kind of thoughts you want to indulge in less. For example, I tend to get pissed at other drivers for doing things that inconvenience me or that I don't understand. In the grand scheme of things, that's kind of a stupid thing to get mad about. So when I catch myself feeling that way, I try to remind myself that this person is not necessarily an idiot or an asshole, but rather they just did something that I wish they didn't, and it's me reacting that is causing the anger. A word of caution here: I don't think you'll have a very good time trying to overly-constrict your thinking, for example by trying to think nothing but happy thoughts at all times, squashing forcibly any anger, grief, or other "bad" emotions. Those feelings, or at least the tendencies toward them, are just as much a part of you as the "good" ones, and a certain amount of exploration and acceptance is helpful. That's one reason meditation and ritual are so helpful - they help you develop a better sense for when you are in the grip of some feeling and it is steering you, rather than when you are feeling it or trying to understand it.

The Mental Plane

Things get a bit tough with the mental plane, as we have only very limited direct access to it. All through this post, I've been mentioning "bodies" on each of the planes, so I suppose I ought to talk a bit about that. In the teachings I work with, we exist on more than one plane, and the part of our existence on each plane can be referred to as a "body." On the material plane this is, you guessed it, our literal, physical body, the thing even the staunchest materialist acknowledges as existing (well, unless you run into some real weirdos like the brain-in-a-jar folks that helped inspire The Matrix). On the other planes, these "bodies" are a little different, and they don't map exactly one-to-one with our physical body, though there are important points of overlap. Chakras, meridians, and other systems of energy centers are various attempts to map these subtle bodies out, but then so are auras. Being the closest to the material, your etheric body is the most like it and most closely linked to it - it fills and interpenetrates everywhere your body is and extends a few inches beyond it, though it's capable of interacting with things beyond that range. Your astral body, what is often called your aura, extends up to a few feet vaguely in the shape of an elongated sphere or egg, though the area around your head tends to be especially active and visible to folks with that gift either naturally or through hard work. The reason I bring this up now is because it's at the mental plane that things get a bit weird. Again, according to the system I work with, we don't really have a mental body yet. Instead, we have a far less-developed presence called a "sheath." We're able to experience the mental plane, but not as directly or with as much control as on the other planes. So, any description of it is necessarily tentative and vague.

With these caveats in mind (heh), the mental plane is the realm of meaning, pattern, and value. When you've been pounding your mind against a thorny math or philosophy problem and it suddenly "clicks," you've perceived something about the problem on the mental plane. When you infer a unity between disparate examples, you are getting at least a taste of the mental plane. As I said above, much of what we tend to consider "thinking" doesn't happen on this plane, despite its name, as most thinking is more concerned with the concrete: objects, forces, emotions, and so forth. In and of themselves, words are astral phenomenon, as they are concrete representations (in sound, text, or the mind's ear/eye) of the things they refer to, but our ability to use words for more than immediately referring to objects of sense experience comes from some link to the mental plane, and certainly words can be a vehicle for the kind of insights that come from there, but the essence of the mental plane is fundamentally ineffable. If you've ever learned another language, try to think about when a particular collection of sounds, or certain arbitrary changes to those sounds for grammatical purposes, started to mean something. It's the itch you get when you notice a translator has rendered arete as "excellence" and thereby lost some of its nuance, or when someone says "octopuses" instead of "octopodes" (mostly joking here). It's the feeling of "getting" something rather than merely repeating the arguments for it you've heard from elsewhere.

Some Practical Tips for the Mental Plane: As I said, we have far less capacity for direct experience of the mental plane than those discussed so far. Developing further is ahead of us, when each of us reaches a point of no longer needing material incarnation (oh yeah, the teachings I work with also assume reincarnation as a given, with eventual incarnation into non-physical forms). In the meantime, we can get some intimations of the mental plane through the kind of work that grapples with meaning and value, especially of the abstract, hard-to-concretize kind. Studying math or philosophy can do it, but the very best practice is discursive meditation on a variety of subjects symbolic, philosophical, and spiritual.

The Spiritual, Causal, and Divine Planes

Remember how I said the mental plane is where things get vague? Well, beyond that, things get downright obscure. Above the mental plane, we do not even have a sheath, and so we have no direct experience of these planes in the ordinary course of things. Instead, only the divine spark that accumulates the means to experience and understand each of the planes - the soul - touches these planes, and due to the lack of a body or sheath, only in a very vague, you might even say "sleeping" way. From this comes your consciousness - the part of you that notices when you notice something, for which one set of physical, etheric, astral, and mental stimuli differs from another. But as that implies, it mostly only does so through the mediation of the planes where we have some capacity for experience and control. Tastes of these planes might come through particular religious or mystical experiences, with the help of non-physical beings (in plain English: Gods and spirits). Thanks to this, our knowledge of these planes is theoretical and based on what is shared by folks who have had these kinds of experiences, or inferred from the kinds of meanings and values grasped in our tentative contact with the mental plane (which is, of course, reflecting something of these planes, just as every other plane is in its own way). Teachings of oneness, of impersonal and universal love, and of transcendence of all kinds come from these experiences, and these notions of transcendent unity underlie the system taught here. At the very top is the source of all rules, causality, and goodness (this system derives largely from the Platonic, which likely drew on teachings from Pythagoras and he claimed to get most of his stuff from Egypt, so this may sound familiar if you've encountered those).

Some Practical Tips for the Spiritual Plane: Here we mostly leave the realm of DIY experimentation and get into the realm of religion. If you want to gain experience of the Spiritual, Causal, and Divine Planes, you'll very likely need some higher help. Regular prayer and worship of some kind are the traditional approaches here, but the good news is that it seems like just about every religion ever practiced by mankind will work (you'll just have different experiences and learn different things along the way). If you are especially drawn to this kind of exploration, those paths usually called "mystic" most directly try to approach this realm of experience. In the West, that mostly means some of the weirder ends of Christianity, but some work has been done to cast light on non-Christian approaches, and in the Mid- and Far East, there are many traditions of mysticism appropriate to their religions. Admittedly, at this point, we've likely left behind where this model can be thought of as a helpful, materialist-friendly metaphor, as this level and above posits things pretty much wholly outside of material experience, but even if that is where you started, perhaps your explorations of the other planes will give you some cause to consider the value of religion.

Wrapping Up

So, there you have a very quick and very incomplete survey of the planes of being. I've set them out here as much to solidify and test my own understanding as to teach, but I hope you'll find this helpful nonetheless. As I said, I have found this a useful lens for understanding my experience, most of all what has come from spiritual practice, so hopefully you might as well. I also think that having a post to refer back to will come in handy for some things I want to share down the line, like "are Zeus and Jupiter the same God, or what? What about Dyeus Phater of the Proto-Indo-Europeans?" Of course I'm happy to answer any questions, but I'm still very much learning, so I can't claim any authority and I encourage you to do your own research. If you have any knowledge or experience that contradicts any of this, I'd love to hear about it. Otherwise, happy exploring!

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

[Book] The Search for Odhinn

Date: 2024-July-28
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

I've now read two of the the three books of Shani Oates's "Odhinn Trilogy," skipping over the second for now to get to the third one, which has more to do with what I'm working on: The Search for Odhinn: From Pontic Steppe to Sutton Hoo. The very short version is that it shares many of both the strengths and flaws of The Hanged God: lots of research and links drawn, but unclear or incomplete in the argument it seeks to spell out. Taking a very contrarian approach, it argues Odhinn is mainly a medieval literary creation, and that claims for His ancient worship and near-universality among the Germanish folks is mistaken. This stance might be a helpful corrective to what you'll find in most works, most of all those written by and for today's worshipers, but overall, I didn't find it that convincing. Let's dig in.

First off, the book itself.

Again, this is published by Anathema Publishing, and like all of their other hardcovers I have, it's a nice book with sturdy binding, good-looking type-setting, and lovely thick paper. Unluckily, some of the typographic inconsistencies keep on, such as using the letter 'ð' (eth) where a 'd' ought to be, but it seemed less egregious this time - but maybe only since there were fewer Old Norse words, and thus fewer chances to mix them up. Long story short, if you like books that look and feel good, check out their catalog and see if they have anything you might want to pick up.

As for what the book says, it's a very wide-ranging look into the evidence that has been claimed for Odhinn/Woden/Wotan from very early times through to post-Conversion Iceland and Scandinavia. Oates's main argument, which as far as I can tell is building mainly on Philip Shaw's 2002 thesis "Uses of Wodan: The Development of his Cult and Medieval Literary Responses to It," is that the conflation made by most scholars between Scandinavian Odhinn and continental/English Wotan/Woden is mistaken, and that most claims for evidence of this single God are better understood as references to a diverse set of heroic, ancestral, and tribal figures rather than the head of a neat pantheon in the Greco-Roman style. First off, let me say that I think the heart of the idea is right: Heathen worship and belief were almost certainly not uniform, over time or across lands and folks, and the fairly tidy account given by Snorri has likely given us a simplified view of this messy past. Further, I think Oates's is likely mostly right that modern scholars and reconstructionists alike have underrated the role of local land spirits, tribal totems, specific ancestral figures, and less-anthropomorphized divine powers. However, I feel like she takes her argument against this prevailing wisdom overly far. She seems to believe that an anthropomorphic, organized "pantheon" was wholly an invention of the Greeks and Romans, later adopted by classically-educated Christians and applied to poorly understood earlier Germanish beliefs, and so any take on those beliefs with named, personalized Gods with mythic biographies is some kind of outside imposition. Given the remarkable parallels in specific myths and Gods between far-flung children of the Indo-European diaspora, I think the burden of proof is on folks who want to say "naw, they didn't really have 'Gods' as we think of them," and I don't think Oates comes anywhere close to shouldering that burden.

Okay, so with that overall rundown out of the way, let's drill down a bit more, and in the spirit of charity, let's begin with what's good. As I said, Oates goes over a lot of material - archaeological, literary, historical, and so forth. She looks far and wide (maybe sometimes too far, but more on that in a bit) for parallels and comparisons to zero in on what are clearly Germanish themes and what might just be common to folks with similar lifestyles and stages of civilizational development. For example, one of her critiques I found more convincing than others is the over-readiness with which antiquarians, archaeologists, and today's heathens have jumped on depictions of wolves or birds of prey as traces of Odinic myths. Eagles, in particular, can be found as representations of might, majesty, and kings all over the place - Assyrians, Scythians, Romans (obviously), Germans (of course), and elsewhere. As such, just because you find a carving of an eagle doesn't mean you found a representation of Odin winning the mead of poetry, or Thjazi stealing Idun, or what have you. It might just be an expression of glory and might. Likewise the equation with wolves is likely made too readily (though, here, the well-attested affinity for wolves among Indo-European folks going way back makes some inferences justified, I think). Oates also carefully parses Runic or other written references to names/words/figures that been equated with Odhinn/Woden, spelling out problems with even reading the Runes/letters (common in the early archaeological finds of Runes) as well as difficulties with what sound was represented by scribal conventions across languages (for example, if a piece of Latin writing uses a 'v,' it might mean any of the sounds we today write with 'w,' 'v,' or 'u'). These and other challenges are often glossed over by scholars who adopt a modern anglicization, such as "Odin," and then blithely refer to "references to Odin," whether talking about a Runic inscription to Uthin, a Latin passage about Godan, or even more ambiguous evidence. She's also keen to point out where sources we're relying on were written way after the fact, or had an axe to grind, or otherwise should not be taken at face value without thinking, and what other historical and cultural context we ought to take into account when looking at these things. Altogether, for me, the biggest strength of the book is the wide range of evidence looked at and the skepticism she introduces for all of it, which as I said, is a helpful corrective to the romantic urge to find far-ranging correspondences and long-lasting continuity.

On the other hand, as I also said, this book has some of the same weaknesses as Oates's other book I've talked about here - namely, it is poorly organized and hard to follow. There's less nonsensical word-salad where I go "what the hell are you even saying?" but I did still find myself spending much of my time going "where are you going with this? What do you even mean?" Further, she blithely asserts things as proven when it doesn't seem like she's engaged with them much at all. She also selectively applies arguments and methods of analysis that support the point she wants to make. In one part of the book, she'll confidently state that we can't take pictorial representations that predate written references to Odhinn by tens or hundreds of years as if they refer to the same figure or myths, and then later she'll talk about the obvious continuity between a pictorial representation and some later written reference to another God or myth, sometimes over even longer spans of time, like from the Nordic Bronze Age through to the medieval period. Also, as I said above, one of, if not the, key pillar of her argument is a separate etymology for Odhinn and Wodan, which is not the standard accepted by most scholars. Though she acknowledges a common proto-Germanic root for both of these, she argues there was enough of a difference in development between them to show they must refer to different figures. Even still, not even in the appendix about this etymology does she convincingly show why they should be treated as different enough that the two names must refer to substantially different figures. All taken together, it's maddening. I'm going to have to give Shaw's thesis a read and see if he makes a more coherent, step-by-step argument, because if it's right, it's very significant, but after more than 400 pages, I never felt like she made a good case that it is right - she just said it was and went from there, without even saying explicitly "go read this for a more detailed argument".

All of this, good and bad, would be much easier to incorporate into my own understanding if I had a clearer idea what she was even trying to do with this book. Unluckily, it's precisely here that her tendency to big-word-filled mumbo-jumbo, so admirably suppressed compared to The Hanged God, comes out the most strongly. For all that I complained about Maria Kvilhaug's interpretation of the myths, she was at least very consistent about that interpretation and why she thought it had worth - I can triangulate just as readily from a known point I disagree with as one I agree with, but I can't do that if I can't even figure out what claim a writer is staking out. To try to do so, I've had to resort to some speculation based on what I know about her work and background. Oates belongs to the Clan of Tubal Cain, which from what I've read seems to be a strain of non-Gardnerian Witchcraft. She frequently refers to "god-forms" in a way that makes me think she mostly assumes that the Gods worshiped and shown in myth are more-or-less human-created containers for a less-understandable divine power. My current understanding is that this stance has some truth to it, but is mistaken in assigning too much agency to humans and not enough to the Gods. Sometime soon, I'd like to talk through this thorny question in more detail, but to do it justice, I'm going to have to lay some groundwork from the occult philosophy I've been studying, which will have to wait for another post or two. To put it shortly, at least for now, I believe that the Gods truly are individual personalities with Their own independent being, but that our experience of Them is mediated by forms that are shaped by humans. One overly-simplified metaphor might be to imagine a movie. The screenwriter and director come up with a role and how it should be depicted, but some actors will be better suited to that role than others, and some will be wholly unsuitable (you don't want Winona Rider as your wise-cracking burly commando, but if you can't get Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone might work just fine). The myths and images that really resonate and last are those that are "written for" particular "actors," where casting the wrong one would be obviously wrong - to put it concretely, some folks likely tried to tell stories about Thor that didn't fit with what He is "really like," and those have been forgotten, but those that still land are somehow suited to His divine nature. Even this metaphor, though, gives more agency to the human side of things than I think is right, but it at least gets in the ballpark of what I'm trying to say. Oates's belief seems to be closer to the idea of a novelist - he can write whatever character speaks to him, and as long as that character reflects important aspects of the human experience, he'll "work" in the narrative. Under this metaphor, myth-makers can shape tales as they like, and as long as they're not wholly out-of-joint with divine reality, folks will respond to these myths and be able to craft rituals around them. From the conclusion to the book, it seems that Oates believes that acknowledging Odhinn as the creation of classically-educated medieval writers/antiquarians frees us up to better make use of this "Character" in religious and magical work, which I think puts too much in our own hands, and not enough on the "other side."

So, as usual, we'll close by trying to answer the asking we usually do: should you read this book? I'd say it might be interesting and helpful to anyone who has a deep interest in Odhinn/Woden, as I have, but you're going to have to put in a lot of work to get much out of it unless you're already closer to Oates's position. It's certainly not a "one-stop shop" on the history of this/these God(s) - for that, I might instead recommend Kris Kershaw's The One-Eyed God, or if it turns out to be as good as I expect, Stephen Pollington's latest, Woden. For a maybe overly-crude analogy, the usefulness of this book strikes me as similar to what a Christian might get out of reading a work of heresy - say, you're a Catholic and you read what you can making the case for Arianism. Not that I think Oates's book is heresy, which is both more pejorative than I mean and implies an attachment to dogma that isn't a part of my current religious views. Rather, it's that I think few practicing Heathens will find this book wholly in accordance with their beliefs or practices, but might find the perspective offered in its disagreements helps solidify and clarify them. So, if you want to give yourself a bit of work in fitting a dissonant view into your understanding of Odhinn, this will give you plenty to chew on. Otherwise, your time might be better spent elsewhere.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

On the Usefulness of Social Technology as a Metaphor

Date: 2024-July-21
Subscribe: Add me to the mailing list
Permalink: Link to this Post

An online friend posted an interesting piece on "real paganism" focusing mostly on what many revivalists/reconstructionists might be getting wrong. If your tastes run as mine do, you'll likely find it helpful, but in the comments, he and I got onto a bit of a tangent about "social technology" that I wanted to unpack more fully than was appropriate for a barely-on-topic comment.

First, some context. We got onto this term while discussing Fustel de Coulanges's The Ancient City and how it gets interpreted by those I've run into who have read it (to be fair, I haven't yet, so these are impressions of impressions, take at your own risk). Coulanges basically argues that much, if not most, of classical (Greek and Roman) religion began as specific family cults that were mainly ancestor worship. When one family rose to prominence, some of their cult became a public cult, and over time this accumulated into clans, tribes, cities, and beyond. Coulanges shows that these cults were passed from father to son, and that when a daughter married into another family, she literally left behind her family's Gods and ways and took up those of her husband and his kin. These practices would have included behavioral commandments and taboos, the most basic of which would be "have sons to keep our line alive!" As I said, this is a second-hand summary, and it's mostly to get us to the point of talking about "social technology," so please forgive any inaccuracies.

So far, so good. Well, as I said, I've seen threads in the discussion around this book, specifically amongst those who find it inspirational. The first of these is less relevant to this post, but for the sake of completeness, it's the notion that learning ancestor worship is the "real" basis of polytheistic religion somehow solves the trouble with authenticity. The fact that you exist is proof that you have ancestors, the fact that you have language and tools and houses and microprocessors and so forth is proof that they built things worthy of respect, and so, there ya go, rational basis of worship! Hooray! Unluckily, mark the utter lack of spiritual experience discussed here, and you can see why I don't find this compelling on its own. I believe honoring, even worshiping, forebears is an old and illustrious practice (I do so myself!), but I think it's reductive to say that the Gods are only those ancestors who were the most badass/socially relevant.

That brings us to the thread more relevant to what I want to talk about today, which is that many folks (sometimes overlapping with the first group) read Coulanges and notice that a part of his critique is that these super-tight-knit family cults with their strong behavioral drivers ("be glorious or your grandfather will wither your crops!") were the engines that drove the civilizational greatness of Greece and Rome, and that it was the breakdown of these cults that led to these folks losing the sense of destiny that allowed them to achieve what they did (if you followed along with my thoughts on Spengler, this may sound familiar. Apparently a lot of 18th and 19th century classically educated Europeans came to similar conclusions). Those who notice this often say something like "I want civilizational greatness! Maybe we should have something like family cults to drive ourselves to glory!" Depending on these folks' religious beliefs (they're often Christians, unsurprisingly), they may not exactly want "be great or grandpa will wreck your life!" but they want something with similar oomph in terms of what it can accomplish, and it was while discussing this desire to steer societal outcomes that I happened to use the words "social technology." My friend immediately responded to "social technology" as the toolset of cynical, self-interested manipulators, and in responding, I realized that while I did mean that, I didn't only mean that, hence this essay to work out what all I did want to say.

When I said "social technology," obviously I was leaning on a metaphor to give myself and others some insight into something messy and complex. It might help to talk about some of the other terms/metaphors I considered and rejected. "Praxis" is a perfectly respectable Anglicized-Latinized Greek word that comes from the same root as "practice" and "practical," and so means "the stuff that you actually do to accomplish things." Unluckily, over the 20th century, it took on explicitly Marxist connotations and now has a lot of baggage, so I set it aside. If I were to stick with my beloved Germanish roots, I might have said "craft," to draw on the metaphor of shaping something to a given end. On the good side, this brings to mind things like wood carving and weaving and other handcrafts that are both intentional and yet still somewhat organic, not cold and mechanical. On the bad side, when talking about folks interacting, "craft" very strongly implies lying, manipulation, even bewitchment. So I set that aside too. "Technique" has a similar set of connotations to "craft," but is colder and more mechanical, while still implying untruthfulness, so even worse.

What I wanted to get across was the idea of something structured, that produces certain outcomes, and maybe has some mount of intentionality associated with it. So I went with "social technology." It seems, though, that I'm not the first to arrive to this metaphor (shocking, I know), and that many of the folks who have used it have zeroed in on the "intentional" bit and its connotations of manipulation and lying when used in the human sphere. Consider the term "social engineering," which presumably is what one does to invent social technology, and the nearly universal negative cast given to it by anyone using the term (folks who believe in the kind of stuff that critics call "social engineering" tend to use different, more positive names for it). I was familiar with that and likely ought to have realized that "social technology" would be painted with the same brush unless I were careful to spell out what I meant. As such, I'm not really trying to "save" social technology as a term for more common use, but rather to explore what some more neutral meanings might show us.

Okay, so maybe it's about time we actually got down to discussing what I meant and why I think it's interesting. First off, I think the idea of consciously engineered social technology is almost always misleading. Short of a handful of more-or-less totalitarian projects or weird intentional communities, most instances of social technology don't get invented and imposed by fiat. In more complex societies, the intentionality tends to come about in fine-tuning something that arose organically, or when possible alternatives are proposed and folks advocate for one or the other of these alternatives in some kind of political process. A classic example: marriage might be seen as a social technology. It's structured and it's recognizable as a distinct "unit" of how a society runs. Given how widespread something that looks a lot like marriage is across very different cultures, the basic model almost certainly arose "of itself," organically. A man and a woman have kids, realize or are pushed by kinfolk into realizing that taking care of kids is better handled by both of them, and so live together with their kids and arrive at some rules that tend to minimize conflict between them, with their kids, and with each other's kin. As societies become more complex, edge cases arise, folks hash it out, and sometimes the ways they hash it out become more standardized (laws and courts to settle them are another example of social technology). As things get hashed out in a formal process, the originally rough, organic arrangement hardens into a more formal structure. No social engineer sat around and said "let's invent a way for couples to live together long term!" Somewhere along the way, though, it's possible that social engineer types get involved - should we even have marriage? Are some of its rules oppressive or outdated? Should it only be between a man and a woman? How does religion fit in? What about property?

Point is, these technologies will tend to evolve gradually, over time, to handle the specific circumstances faced by a given society. Some cultures have stabilized on polygamy, others on monogamy, and a very few on something more like polyandry. Evolutionary psychologists propose all sorts of interesting reasons for these arrangements and their variations, but in any given case, you have a cluster of behaviors, customs, laws, taboos, and expectations that can be identified, whether from within or without the culture, as its own "thing." Long stretches of time can pass without major changes to these bits of technology, and it's usually only when something about the situation has changed greatly that anyone bothers to fight about them.

Another example might be the whole sprawling edifice we are wont to call "capitalism." Over a long stretch of time, ways of thinking about property, means of pooling business risk, lending at interest, industrialization, and so forth have come together into a system that is very good at making and selling lots of stuff and for certain folks to accumulate a lot of money. After much of this had shaken out, some folks looked around and decided some of the systematic outcomes were not so great. Working in a factory kind of sucks (especially early factories). Being one of the folks pooling risk or lending at interest is a much better way to make a lot of money than working in a factory. Large businesses can accumulate enough money to bribe politicians and shape the political landscape in their favor. Or hire private security to go knock heads when the factory workers say they want a bigger piece of the pie. Again, over time, many of these critiques coalesced into systems that purported to fix these problems, with Marxism being the most prominent example (and having a lot more intentionality than, say, marriage). Since these systems took on political significance and became associated with societies in competition with each other, a lot of their content got much more formalized and systematized, and a lot more conscious social engineering entered the picture. Without the Cold War Capitalism and Communism (note the capitalization) might not have hardened and systematized into the formal, dogmatic systems of thought we now know with ideological advocates and technicians.

Which I suppose brings us back to Coulanges's take on classical family cults. Setting aside whatever spiritual reality may have been reflected in these practices for a moment, it sounds like Coulanges proposes a way to describe the organic development of one piece of social technology that the societies of the two major peninsulae of the Mediterranean found helpful in functioning as aggregate entities. As those societies became more complex, this technology got systematized and formalized (if I recall correctly, Justinian's law code had a lot to say about the potestas ("power," but with a lot of connotations) of the paterfamilias, which all ultimately derives from his role as the spiritual head of the family). Encounters with alternate ways of organizing things also contributed (many early Christians eschewed traditional approaches to family, but as Christianity became official, these were reconciled). At some point, much of the effectiveness of this technology to organize and motivate social activity faded away, and Fustel de Coulanges argues that contributed to the decline of Rome. I think it's helpful to be able to look at social arrangements like these family cults as a coherent framework that can be analyzed on its own. But obviously this isn't the whole picture. Any analysis is, by its nature, not synthetic (as in "the product of synthesis," not meaning an android). A lot of complexity, nuance, and humanity gets lost. It fails to take into account nearbyness.

And it is for this reason that I am deeply skeptical of those who look at one of these "technologies" as if it were literally a piece of physical technology that can just be slotted into some other society as readily as building a power plant or installing a telephone network. We might be able to look at the ways other societies have solved certain problems and get ideas of what works (or maybe more readily what doesn't work), and I'm all for that. But as with my approach to religion, I think we need to go into any such attempt to learn from others knowing that it won't work "as is" - there will be false starts, missteps, and a whole hell of a lot of tweaks along the way, and what we end up with will be unlikely to look all that much like what we started from.

So maybe "technology" is the wrong metaphor after all. Maybe a better metaphor would be a model - not like a tiny plastic tank or airplane, but rather a man or woman posing for an art class. If the artists are good, they'll capture enough of the model that someone looking at their drawings spread out in front of him will say "ah yes, that is the same woman," but not "these were drawn by the same guy."

I don't know about you, but I think I'd rather strive to be a social artist than a social engineer.

Post Footer

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Want to get new posts emailed to your inbox? Sign up here.

Let's Talk about LGOPs

Date: 2024-July-14
Permalink: Link to this Post

American parachutists… devils in baggy pants… are less than 100 meters from my outpost line. I can't sleep at night; they pop up from nowhere and we never know when or how they will strike next. Seems like the black-hearted devils are everywhere…

Taken from the diary of a Wehrmacht officer killed at Anzio, and the source of my regiment's nickname.

(This post is going up a day after the assassination attempt on former president Donald Trump, but is not in response to it. I've had the rough idea for a couple months, and I spent the last couple weeks working it up. I just don't want anyone going cross-eyed looking for some esoteric association here.)

So, as I've likely shared before, I used to be a paratrooper, specifically, an airborne infantryman. For those of you less familiar with military terms, let me break this string down for you. "Airborne" means carried by aircraft, which these days only refers to paratroopers (guys who jump out of airplanes with parachutes), but in WWII also included gliderborne troops (ride a glider to a hopefully minimally bumpy landing, and then walk out of the back of it on the ground). "Infantry" means "guy with a rifle who fights on foot." If you'll allow me a brief digression, part of why I spell all this out is some lingering chauvinism. You see, those in the infantry tend to look down on everyone else in the armed forces as not being "the real thing." When talking about the far larger body of men in uniform outside of the infantry, we tend to use a less than polite term that gained currency in the Global War on Terror - POG (pronounced "pogue," like the Irish-flavored punk band), which stands for "People Other than Grunts." If I'm being honest with you, and myself, much of this haughtiness is surely born of the recognition of how much more it sucks to be one of the "poor bloody infantry," and the perverse pride that comes from justifying that suffering. Airborne infantry get the extra luxury of looking down on "legs" - folks who don't jump out of airplanes - and so we're a cocky bunch. I explain all this so you can decide how much salt to keep on hand as I talk about one of the main threads of the airborne mythos: the LGOP (Little Group of Paratroopers, pronounced "ell-gop").

I didn't see it coming as I was growing up, but now that I look back, it seems somewhat inevitable that I'd end up a paratrooper. Starship Troopers in junior high, Band of Brothers in high school, and then a classical education that emphasized excellence, exceptionalism, and physical bravery in service to your land. It was something of a joke when I was at airborne school how Band of Brothers was required viewing to get accepted. Anyway, I bring it up not only because of the shaping influence it had on me, but also because it has a great depiction of our topic for today, LGOPs (in episode 2, the D-Day one). Now, if, like me, you have a fondness for military history, the allied airborne operations on D-Day are interesting in-and-of themselves, but the reason I wanted to write a whole post about one little piece of that sprawling, fascinating mess, is that I think LGOPs have something to teach us about the complex interplay of people, culture, mission, organization, and training that can take advantage of nearbyness to thrive in a chaotic situation.

Let's define just what the heck an LGOP is before we dig into why they're interesting. Unless you've watched a lot of WWII movies or shows that feature airborne operations, chances are very good that what you picture when I say "paratrooper" is a little off. In most movies where secret agents or commandos parachute in somewhere, they leap out of a plane impossibly high up, go into a spread eagle and free fall for minutes, and then open a parachute that they steer precisely onto the roof of the installation they're breaking into, and come to a running landing, ditching the parachute, and maybe shooting immediately. Special Operations troops sometimes do stuff like this, but that's not what "regular" paratroopers do. It looks more like this. You have a plane stuffed full of as many dudes and their gear as can be crammed in, they line up and jump out one after the other with only a second or two between, a static line pulls each of their shoots open without them doing anything, so it opens in about four seconds, they fall about as fast and hard as you would jumping off a second story balcony, and then hit the ground more or less like a sack of potatoes. If you're lucky, you hit like a sack of potatoes that rolls over a few times to absorb the impact, and hopefully you were able to drop your ruck and the leg bag with your rifle in it before hitting so that you are slightly less likely to break your legs. You haul in your ruck and leg bag with the tether attached to them, get your rifle operational, and then pack your shoot up and start looking for the muster point. It's messy. The round parachutes have minimal steering, and even though you're dropped low to both minimize how far you drift and how long the enemy has to shoot at you, the chance that you land exactly where the operation planned to put you are already pretty small. Throw in the typical (huge) amount of friction that you can expect in any military endeavor, and it's better than even chances that you land with only a vague idea where you are and how it relates to where you're supposed to be to accomplish your mission.

On D-Day, there was even more than the usual helping of friction, and things got real messy. Paratroopers got scattered six ways from Sunday, behind enemy lines, in the dark, in unfamiliar country. What ended up happening is that American soldiers used various recognition calls (like little clickers that sounded like crickets or challenge-response passcodes) to identify if the guy creeping around in the underbrush nearby was friend or foe. The friend you found, though, might not be from your squad, or platoon, company, or even battalion. But everybody was there to wreck some Germans' night, so pretty quickly, ad hoc little squads formed - Little Groups of Paratroopers, LGOPs. These LGOPs went out and did the best they could to accomplish their mission and link up with other groups, and by morning, most guys had found their way into some effective military formation, even if it wasn't the one they technically belonged to.

This might be a bit of a tangent, but something that I didn't fully appreciate before joining the Army is the full importance of units and organization. In many ways, the ideal of the modern soldier is as a highly trained and disciplined interchangeable piece, a cog in a machine that can be substituted in or out for any other cog. That leads to thinking that it doesn't much matter which squad, company, battalion, or whatever a soldier is put in. To some extent, this is true, and the more standardized the training between two units, the more true it is. In practice, though, what unit you belong to not only matters a lot, it is the primary fact of your existence. Besides doing actual training together, on off days, you spend all day smoking and joking with your squad mates, and then after work you go drinking with the guys in your platoon. You talk shit about the other platoons, and if you deign to talk about other companies, it is with contempt. You learn which specific guys in your platoon are fast, slow, aggressive, hesitant, good shots, hopelessly disorganized, or whatever. You compensate where you need to and lean on strengths where you can. You come to rely on the specific, individual humans you know and trust, even if when you first met, you just "relied" on them in the sense of doing some fairly-well-specified job. I bring all of this up to emphasize how hard it is to try to get things done militarily with randos that you've never met and don't know or trust, which makes the LGOPs all that more impressive and exceptional.

So, ever since D-Day, every paratrooper is inculcated with stories about LGOPs and what they accomplished, both to honor our illustrious past, but also as a model to emulate. Since we know it's hard to work with strangers, we make it a part of our self image and training that we can work with strangers. On routine jumps, we'd get a little taste of this, even though the operational area was usually smaller, the friction less, and communications better than they would be in the real thing. You land out in DZ (drop zone) Normandy in the dark, get your parachute turned in, and link up with whatever guys you can find as you make your way to a muster point, where usually you get sorted out and sent to your actual unit. In the meantime, though, you have to act operationally - move quietly, pull security, engage with any opfor (opposing forces) that might be out there.

Alright, so that's what LGOPs are. Let's rewind a bit to talk about their prehistory, and how they came to hold an exalted place in American military mythology. The first major airborne operation in history was the Axis invasion of Crete in 1941. Though it featured amphibious elements and regular troops were brought into airfields seized by the paratroopers, the initial push was almost entirely airborne. As interesting as the battle itself is, what I want to focus on here is how the great powers responded to it. The Axis (mostly Germany) looked back on this successful operation and said "holy crap, that was a mess, way too many casualties, way too disorganized, maybe this airborne thing isn't worth it after all!" and from that point forward, fallschirmjager (German paratroopers) were deployed as regular, if especially feisty, light infantry. The Allies, on the other hand, saw a major strategic island in the Mediterranean fall in a way previously thought impossible and said "holy crap, maybe there's more to this airborne thing than we thought!" The shape of the rest of the war to come was profoundly changed.

Though the Allies were not privy to the all of the internal messiness of the mostly-German side, they learned a few lessons from observing what had happened to the carefully orchestrated German plan on contact with the enemy. They saw that paratroopers might not end up where you expected, that communications would be crappy in the early stages, and that you couldn't rely on traditional battle lines and supply from the rear. As such, as the first airborne units were stood up and trained by the British and Americans, they incorporated these learnings and readied some contingencies. They made sure that paratroopers were given a wider understanding of the terrain and commanders intent than was normal for infantry at the time. They made sure that leaders down to a very low level had more specific orders about what they were meant to accomplish with whatever guys they could round up. And the need for explicit rally points to head for in order to get better organized was recognized and briefed to all troops before D-Day. Now, sure, eventually, the Allies would learn their own lessons about the challenges of huge, entirely-airborne operations in Market Garden, but for the supporting role given to them on D-Day, American and British paratroopers proved to be exactly the right tool for the job.

What made it work? Well, for starters, they built on the already well-established, time-tested model of military organization and delegation. As we talked about before, good militaries have long recognized the worth of having leaders down to even very small levels, and to empower them with broad authority within whatever scope they're given. This meant that when paratroopers found themselves huddling in a hedgerow outside of Carentan, there was no question of "who's in charge?" It was whoever had the highest rank there, whether that be a captain, lieutenant, sergeant, or even a private first class. Even if he's not your sergeant, you still know to listen to him. This clarity and unity of command is extremely important in combat.

As mentioned, these leaders also had some idea of what to do, even in the absence of higher direction. Before they even got on the plane, they had been briefed on what the overall purpose was, what targets were high value, and what the priority was on targets of opportunity. Just as the clarity of "who's in charge?" meant that individual soldiers in an LGOP could focus on executing well, rather than on figuring out what to do, so the leaders of these groups didn't have to agonize over whether they should sit still and wait for someone higher-ranked to show up, patrol around looking for others, or engage with any enemies they felt they could take. Pretty much all of them had orders that went something like "make your way to X rendezvous point with whatever guys you can police up on your way, engage any targets of opportunity you encounter, and overall, your goal is to cut off reinforcements from reaching the beach." Knowing why they were sneaking around hostile territory with guns and explosives meant that these leaders could focus on how to solve whatever challenges came their way.

Taking a still wider view, there's a certain paradoxical freedom that comes from being dropped into a country full of your enemies: no matter what direction you go, no matter what actions you take, if it's bad for the German military, you're helping. See some random soldiers out on patrol? Ambush them. Find a cache of weapons? Take them, or blow them up. Observe a camp that wasn't on your map that's too big to take on? Note it, and report it when you link up with a bigger unit. Find some private who's scared and confused by himself? "You're with me now, son, let's go fuck up some krauts!" (apologies to my German readers, but I wanted to capture the vibe). Complexity and nuance are the enemies of dealing with chaotic situations full of friction. Simplicity is a great blessing, even if it's the "gift" of knowing that anyone you meet with a gun who doesn't answer in English can probably be shot.

Lastly, many commentators, including contemporary officers, have pointed out a key cultural difference between Americans and Germans that may have made the former especially effective as paratroopers (the Brits also had this to some degree): rugged independence. We can argue about how much this is still the case, but it's always been part of the American character to think for yourself, do your own thing, make your own way. The "gift" of clear priorities that comes from being surrounded by foes can just as readily be paralyzing as empowering if you aren't ready to make up your own damn mind and do what seems best to you with what you've got. German soldiers were extremely well-trained and motivated. They had the same strength of structure given by a clear chain of command and effective delegation, the same benefit of a clear intent (guard this ammo dump, shoot anyone who tries to cross this bridge that doesn't properly answer the challenge, and so forth), and the added strengths of operating in their real, established units (each German soldier was generally being ordered by his sergeant, with whom he had an existing relationship, and so on up the chain) and being on the defense (which always has certain advantages - knowing the terrain, being dug in, concentration of forces, and so forth). But German military culture (and arguably, the wider culture as well at this point in their history) prioritized obedience, deference to authority, and precise planning and execution to a degree that ornery Americans find wholly alien. Now, I know, the whole stereotype of Germans as robotic order-followers is overblown and mostly wrong, and the kind of flexible, delegation-heavy, commander's intent-focused tactics that I'm extolling here were invented by the Germans at the tail end of WWI. But when put to the test, apparently a dozen random Americans with guns who have never met before dropped into the woods of Normandy at night had a better time than a dozen Germans in the same situation in Crete. The Germans managed to win from such makings, barely, but the Americans thrived in such fighting.

So, why did I want to get into all of this? I think there are some interesting lessons to learn for any organization that wants to thrive in a chaotic, even hostile, environment:

  • First, you need to know your organization's mission - why does it exist? What is it trying to do? What's the overall goal, and what are the intermediate steps to get there? How does this organization solve problems and move towards its goals (very different answers for paratroopers than the staff of a high-end restaurant!)? What is it for? Clarity here will carry through all of the other pieces, but so will muddiness - if an organization doesn't know why it exists, it will soon start trying to be and do whatever it can get some control over, and that makes it harder to actually accomplish anything. A strong leader with a clear purpose is one way to get this, another is having an obvious enemy like the Wehrmacht, but anything that makes it crystal clear what outcomes you're after and how to prioritize them will do the job (note that corporate "mission statements" pretty much never live up to this).
  • Next, and perhaps even more importantly, is that you have to get the right guys - the folks who want what the organization wants, who approach problems the way best suited to the organization, and who think and act the way the organization needs them to. To some degree, you can train this, but a lot of it is likely selection. If you try to stand up an airborne regiment with a bunch of pacifists, you're gonna have a bad time. So pick good people, and then put them through their paces to make sure they're good and reinforce what they're good at and minimize what they're bad at.
  • With a goal and the right people, you're most of the way there already, but as we've seen, it's helpful to have a clear, but not overly rigid structure. Small, organic teams like startups can get away with doing this by "feel" or raw seniority, but really anything over a dozen folks or so likely needs more explicit roles and hierarchy. The more you can count on this structure being present as-is when needed, the less flexibility it needs, but even where you might not anticipate it, you might need more than you think - what happens when the manager of your quality assurance team goes on vacation or leaves for a competitor? Much easier to deal with when someone else can easily step in to take over.
  • Which brings us to the nitty gritty of training. With the right folks going after the right goals, and a clear idea of who is in charge, you need to practice handling things the way you want them handled. As mentioned above, cross-training becomes more helpful the more chaos and friction you expect, but one under-appreciated aspect of training is not just competence in tangible tasks, like marksmanship or calling in a medevac, but practice in making decisions. This becomes especially important when training bleeds over into what HR types like to call "development" - how do you cultivate the kind of leaders you want within an organization? If you want folks who are willing to take risks and think for themselves, you have to a. let them, and b. not punish them for doing so. You can tell your guys "take risks, think for yourself" all you want, but if anyone who sticks his neck out gets his head chopped off, you better believe nobody will again after that. The same principle applies to handling chaos. You can't train in perfectly expected, orderly ways and just say "okay, but when it gets messy, do the best you can." Or rather, you can, but you won't like the outcomes. Going back to our main example, even today, paratroopers get experience forming and acting in LGOPs through the simple expedient of exposing them to the conditions that create them in the wild (jumping out of airplanes in less than ideal conditions with a mission to accomplish). Whatever kind of uncertainty you think your leaders might need to handle, try to give them simulations of it, or even better, put junior leaders in positions where they'll be exposed to real chaos, but with a more limited scope of what they have to handle. Going again to the military, the most fundamental SOP (standard operating procedure) that the infantry learns is Battle Drill 1-Alpha. When bad guys start shooting at you, one fire team (half a squad) lays down and shoots back while the other fire team goes around and tries to get around to the side of the bad guys, hopefully surprising them and wiping them out. Being the leader of the flanking fire team gives you a tiny dose of uncertainty within a framework of order - how far out should I move? How quickly? Where should I tell my guys to take cover? When should I signal the other fire team to shift their fire away from the position we're approaching? Dealing with all of these sources of friction builds the muscle of dealing with the bigger kinds that a squad, platoon, or company leader will need to.
