The "now" is the accumulation/fulfillment of everything that has come before, and so the past is at its "fullest" right now. The idea that things started out perfect and have been getting worse, that the world has been deteriorating in a way that will be washed away/renewed by some future event, seems to be wholly outside of how elder Germanish folks saw things.

This leads to a few implications: first, the future is not set, but it's not wholly unguessable either. One way to put it might be that the elder Germanish folk would look at a batter hitting the ball and hear the bat hit the ball and see the form of the batter and think "wow, that might be a home run" rather than focusing on the outfielder running to catch the ball and wondering if he'll be at the right place at the right time. Secondly, learning what happened in the past is of great worth, because it's the best way you have of learning about how cause and effect work. Thirdly, doing great deeds lays the needed groundwork for great things to come - you renew the well and feed the tree when you leave great things behind you. These three things seem like a lot of why this book has so strongly struck today's heathens, and I can see why.

The Linguistic Evidence - What Future Tense?

Very likely the source of Bauschatz's theory, and I suspect the bit that he was most interested in, is a grammatical observation about the German language family. Namely, grammatically-speaking, no Germanish tongue expresses the future morphologically. In fact, every Germanish tongue only conjugates its verbs into past and non-past. This part gets pretty technical, enough so that even as someone who took linguistics classes in College, majored in Latin and Greek, and has read a lot about the linguistic evidence for the origin and dispersal of Indo-European languages, I found it hard to follow.

Let's take a quick side trip into linguistic concepts and terminology in case the above paragraph read like gobbledygook to you. What do I mean about expressing grammatical concepts "morphologically"? First off, "morphological" is a fancy word for "in the shape of," and when used in linguistics is used to refer to the sounds made in a word, and is most of all used when the sounds of a word change to reflect some change in meaning. For example, "write" is in the present tense, but when I change the vowel to "o", we get "wrote", which is now in the past tense. That's a morphological change. So is making something plural by putting and "-s" on the end - like "kid" and "kids," or weirder changes like "child" and "children." So far, so good?

Most Indo-European languages made/make morphological changes to words to convey what they are doing in a sentence grammatically. If you only speak English, this can be tough to get your head around, because we don't do much of that and instead express grammatical function by putting words next to each other - for example, to show who is writing, we put a pronoun next to the word "I write," "you write," and so forth. To show future tense, we add in "will" - "I will write." There's a variety of historical reasons for this that we can get into another time, but one of the contributing factors is what Bauschatz is getting into here, and we'll talk about that in a second.

To make the idea of morphological changes to show grammatical function a little clearer, let's take a look at another language that does more than English - Latin. Here, videbo means "I will see" - the vide- bit is the root, meaning "see" and the -bo bit says "I will." If I wanted to say "I will be seen" (passive voice) or "if [something happened], I would see" (subjunctive), you'd make more changes to the verb (videbor and videam respectively). Morphological changes like this seem to have been a big part of how proto-Indo-European worked, which is why all Indo-European languages today make at least some morphological changes to words to convey grammatical meaning. What those changes were in proto-Indo-European is a matter of some debate, and harder to describe than the examples above, but Bauschatz goes into it in the book.

The short version is that it seems like proto-Indo-European was doing something similar to tense with morphological changes, but that the various daughter languages evolved in slightly different ways. The Germanish kindred of tongues seems to have evolved to where you had a morphological past and a morphological "not past." Weird as it is to think about, they didn't seem to feel the need to express that something "will happen" in the future until they started being Christian. Take a closer look at how we put something in the future now: "I will write." We don't think about it much, but that "will" is exactly the same word as the will in "willpower." The sense is "I will it to happen," meaning "it is my intention right now to do that thing in the future." Every Germanish tongue has a similar "workaround" for expressing futurity - we slap some kind of helping verb onto a "not past" form of the main verb, and those helping verbs usually mean something like "have in mind" or "intend" or "am obliged to." Fun fact: "shall" as in "I shall do the thing," is etymologically linked with "should," which is the English cognate to the Norn "Skuld."

Anyhow, Bauschatz argues that Germanish tongues lack a morphological "future tense" because the idea that you can talk about things in the future as if they're certain, established, "real," just in a different conceptual "place" was outlandish to the folks who spoke Proto-Germanic. The best they could do was to say "well, this is what I intend to happen" or "given what's happened, the most likely outcome seems to be this." As the speakers of these tongues Christianized, they had to grapple with a worldview that saw the future as a more definite thing, something that held the dearest hope of the new religion.

Some Downsides - Academicese, Lack of Grounding in Ways of Belief

Overall, I rather liked the book and it sparked a lot of thoughts, but it has some downsides. For starters, at times you can tell that this book was written in the 80s by an English professor, because it often (usually?) indulges in post-modern academic jargon when it could just state something plainly. Often enough that it's actually hard to follow at times. I can sympathize that Bauschatz's task is a tough one, trying to understand and describe a different way of understanding time and the world than you and your audience take for granted, but it often feels like he leans too hard into abstract terms and the way of talking about things that his field expected at the time to demonstrate you were a member in good standing. Secondly, Bauschatz is very clearly coming at this stuff from a way of looking at things that takes as given that these stories, these ways of thinking, and so forth are nothing more than stories made up to cope with the world, nor more or less true than anyone else's. When he dives deep, it is into the language used. He doesn't seem to give much weight to the stories as stories, as units of meaning with their own worth. There are pros and cons when a writer is a believer in the field being written about (and when not!), but here, I think Bauschatz's valiant attempts to understand what it was like to see the world as an elder German are undercut by his unwillingness to take seriously "what if some bits of how they saw the world were right? what if those things really are handled by Goddesses?

Closing - Deep and Thought-Sparking, but Clumsy

Overall, I think this book is well worth reading and sheds a lot of light on how time, causality, and "fate" are shown in the Germanish lore. That being said, it doesn't seem to do so in the clearest, most straightforward way it might. There are a lot of times where I found myself going "why don't you just say what you mean?" I had hoped this post might be a start toward re-stating the worthwhile insights in a more straightforward way, but I think there's more work to come on that front.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Jordan Peterson's Framework for Myth

Date: 2023-March-02

Well, after the comments on my List of Germanish Books with Thoughts went rather long and ended up taking a lengthy detour into discussing Jordan Peterson's way of understanding myths, as laid out in his book Maps of Meaning and in loads of lectures since, I reckoned it might be helpful to spell out that framework as clearly and straightforwardly as I might, because this is one area where I think Peterson is not at his strongest. So many of his lines of thinking and research are linked in his head and have implications for each other, he often fares far afield in a way that can be hard to follow, especially if you're new to his thinking.

That being said, I once told a friend that if you listen to enough of Peterson's lectures, in at least one of them, he will spell out his way of thinking about a key topic from the very most bedrock concepts up to the widest implications, and he'll make every step as firmly supported as he knows how. Unfortunately, in every other lecture, he will just refer back to the higher-level implications and how they relate to the topic at hand. His more recent books 12 Rules for Life, and presumably (I've yet to read it) Beyond Order: 12 More Rules for Life, do a decent job of laying things out in an order that makes sense and builds on each other, but with a lot less of the depth than Maps of Meaning, which I found a bit disappointing. At any rate, if I might flatter myself a moment, I've long felt like my (rather boring) super power is to be able to listen to questions folks have about a topic and understand what it is they're actually confused by, and therefore what answer would help resolve their confusion. I wouldn't have thought this was much of a super power, but after years being on both sides of a classroom, sitting through corporate meetings, attending military trainings and debriefs, and so forth, I've found that it's really common for folks trying to explain things to get a question, and then answer something way different, often while missing the fairly easy distinction the questioner was actually looking for. And so I set out, modestly, to try to more clearly set out the thinking of someone who has made himself known worldwide and rather wealthy by explaining things.

We're Not Going to Talk About the Biological Grounding

Okay, so if you dig into Maps of Meaning, a decent chunk of the book will be dedicated to explaining some concepts about neurobiology and animal behavior that Peterson wants to use as the foundation for everything that follows. His goal in laying all of this out is to give as firm a material grounding as he can to all of the symbolic and narrative stuff he talks about later. This section is interesting, impressive, and with what little I know of the field, seems pretty comprehensively argued. That being said, if you are not coming at this from a skeptical standpoint, if you already believe stories and myths include important information about what it means to live and how to do so as well as you might, you can likely skip over this. So that's just what we're going to do here: I'll give the briefest of summaries so that you can decide if you're interested in digging in more, but from this point on, I'll assume that you're okay with the premise "the structures of meaning (symbols, narratives, and so forth) within stories and myths give meaningful insights into how the human mind works and how to live a meaningful, worthwhile life." If you don't agree with that premise, I humbly invite you to read my thoughts on finding meaning in life by following that last link.

The Very Short Rundown of the Biological Grounding

At least in vertebrates (and maybe even in invertebrates, hence Peterson's infamous thing with the Lobsters), animals seem to have two groundmost motivational systems: to move toward good things and away from bad things. Moving toward good things produces a bunch of feel-good reward chemicals, like dopamine, and moving away from bad things seems to relieve a bunch of feel-bad chemicals that cause anxiety and stress, like cortisol. This leads to a world full of known good and bad things, to which we more or less know how to react, but then an even wider world of the unknown, which holds vast amounts of both good and bad things. As such, we can react to "the unknown" with either the "moving toward good things" motivational system, or with "moving toward, not away from, bad things" anti-reward system. For beings with things like symbols and narratives (like us), we can somewhat choose how we conceptualize of the known and unknown in order to get more of what we want and less of what we don't - are we being forced out into the darkness full of monsters ready to eat us by harsh necessity? Or are we striding into a realm of possibility, ready to handle any obstacles along the way? The former will produce a lot of anxiety and little sense of reward/meaning, whereas the latter will feel full of reward/meaning with minimal anxiety.

Got it? Hooray, we just covered roughly the first 13 chapters out of 68 of Maps of Meaning (~84 pages of 469).

Peterson's Biggest Influences Here are Jung and Nietzsche

The next big thing to get out of the way before we talk about the framework itself is that Peterson is first and foremost a synthesizer. He'll be the first to admit that most of the ideas he shares are outgrowths and remixes of the thinking of folks he admires. He has a big ol' recommended reading list if you want to delve deeper into where his thinking is coming from.

The most important thing to know, though, is that Peterson's method of analyzing myth is about 80-90% Jung, with a good seasoning of Nietszche, and then finished out with his other influences. In other words, I mainly think of "Peterson's" analytical framework for myths as a very helpful introduction/guide to understanding myths from a Jungian standpoint. The framework below relies on Jung's concept of "archetypes", patterns of behavior, symbolism, and association that appear to be very deeply embedded in human brains and that show up in a variety of forms across many cultures and throughout time. For example, the father in the story of the Prodigal Son, Jupiter of Roman myth, and Mufasa from the Lion King all share characteristics of the "Father" archetype - they act in ways fathers often act, they symbolize things fathers tend to symbolize, and they are associated with things fathers tend to be associated with, and in all three case, those actions, symbols, and associations have a lot in common (controlled/protective aggression, warmth and indulgence to children, enforcer of rules, and so forth). Where I think Peterson is helpful is in giving an underlying conceptual framework for how the different archetypes interact with each other in a more systematic way than Jung was willing or able to do (more on the pros and cons of this in a second).

Nietzsche maybe does less to create the shape of the framework or the pieces within it, but his thinking and ethos underlie a lot of the application and interpretation of that framework. You might say that Peterson's whole project here, most of all the bit we skipped over so blithely above, with the biological grounding, is a thoroughly Nietzschean undertaking. Nietzsche rather forcibly pointed out "hey guys, if you don't really believe in God, why are you still doing the stuff he told you to? Maybe we should figure something else out instead." Peterson went "huh, but here we are, more than a century later, still doing that stuff - what's driving that? Even if we don't intellectually believe in God, is there something else going on?" So that's why it's helpful to have Nietzsche in mind, even if most of the book is far more directly influenced by Jung (who was, of course, himself influenced heavily by Nietzsche). To put it briefly, the thesis of the book might be something like "if God is dead, why do His stories keep shaping what we find meaningful?"

The Basic Framework is Order, Chaos, and the Mediator

A Quick Word about Abstraction

Alright, so here we are for the main event. First, a word about abstraction. This model is an example of an abstraction - you might even argue an abstraction of abstractions. What do I mean by abstraction? Here, at least, I mean a general label you generate to explain what several specific instances have in common. So, you read the Prodigal Son, you hear a few myths about Jupiter, and you watch the Lion King. You notice that the father figures in these stories have some things in common. You also think about all of the actual fathers you have known in your life - your own, your friends', your own experience with your children, and so forth. You notice that some of the things the story-fathers have in common are also shared, mostly, by these real-life fathers. At this point, you have dozens of specific data points, but if you want, you can take the things that all of them (or at least most of them) have in common and call that the "Father abstraction". No one of these individual fathers will 100% match this abstraction, but all of them will match at least a little, and all of them will match the Father abstraction more closely than, say, the Mother abstraction. So far, so good, right?

Well, what if what you're interested in is the difference between widowed fathers, and fathers married to natural mothers, and fathers married to step mothers? Now, the unifying "fatherness" between these three categories is maybe helpful, but much less so, because it hides the very distinction you want to pay attention to. Or, what if you're interested in the story of your own father, the actual, individual human being? All of his nuance and idiosyncracy. Well, now what he has in common with other fathers is almost useless, because you want to know precisely about what is unique to him - even if he still exhibits almost all of the traits of the "Father Abstraction".

I bring all this up to make clear something about Peterson's approach. There's a general rule with abstractions - the more widely they can be applied, the less accurately the represent any given instance of the abstraction. Let's think about maps. Imagine you have a military-style grid map that covers an area of roughly 500 square kilometers (10 x 5) with a 10 meter contour interval (there are topographical lines on the map showing changes of elevation of 10 meters). This is a fairly detailed map - you can successfully use it to find your way through the woods pretty well if the changes in elevation are distinct enough, or with the help of a compass. Now imagine we zoom out to a map that is roughly 5,000 square kilometers and shows changes in elevation at 100 meter intervals. This map covers a wider area, which is certainly useful, but you're going to have a much harder time working out if you're in this tiny draw or that one. The zoomed-out map tells you about more places, but it tells you less about all of those places than a more zoomed-in map would tell you about any one of them.

TV Tropes tends to work down to some pretty granular "abstractions" - some of the entries may only cover a handful of specific instances, but they analyze what those have in common in a lot of detail. Peterson, on the other hand, zooms way out to try to arrive at the six(ish) archetypes that explain every story ever told. This insight struck me when I was thinking about why I was so irritated by this condescending review of Peterson and specifically Maps of Meaning from Current Affairs. Setting aside the other unfair things this article does, what's relevant to this post is that it makes fun of the diagrams in Maps of Meaning for being so simplistic as to be meaningless. I would argue, instead, they are at the high end of abstraction in order to apply as widely as possible. The good news is that the framework these diagrams represent can be applied to almost any story. The bad news is that without familiarity with a broad set of instances to which that framework applies, it doesn't do much to help you. Imagine that you had never reflected much about the symbolic role of "fathers" in stories or the kinds of roles "fathers" tend to play in real life. Now, imagine someone says to you "okay, so what we're looking at here is clearly an instance of the Father archetype" - if you haven't ever connected the specific instances you've encountered to that abstraction, it's not going to do you much good at all. I think that's part of why Maps of Meaning (and Peterson's lectures) is so sprawling - he sees the abstraction linking many instances, but he realizes that not everyone he's speaking to does, so he's desperately trying to cram a wide survey of specifics into your mind so that the generality abstracted from them will mean something to you.

Order, Chaos, and the Mediator

Based on the biological grounding that we so blithely skipped over above, Peterson argues that our perception of the world, at a very fundamental level, is sorted into stuff that we treat as pretty much settled (Order), stuff that hasn't been explored and could be anything (Chaos), and how we feel about those things, right now, and in general (the Mediator). Order is symbolically masculine (if your hackles are hackling, see the aside below), Chaos is symbolically feminine, and the Mediator is almost neuter, as what's most important about the Mediator is usually being the child of a symbolically masculine and symbolically feminine force. That being said, our history being what it is, most stories have been about dudes, so the Mediator is usually depicted as a guy, with some flavoring of symbolic masculinity. The other important thing to keep in mind is that both Order and Chaos tend to be "static" until the Mediator interacts with them. Even if there's a lot of "change" within Chaos, it's not significant change - it's "sound and fury, signifying nothing". Think of a pot of water boiling - lots of movement, no real change. Until you put the pasta in!

A Quick Aside on Gender

Okay, I know gender is a hot topic these days, so I want to make a few things clear about the very simplified presentation here:

  1. The symbolic "masculine" and "feminine" here described are not one-to-one with our biological sex, or even the gender we identify with. Everyone has both masculine and feminine elements within them, and folks like Jung and Peterson argue that to be a fully-developed, healthy person, you need to be comfortable with both, and integrate both wholly into your personality. Whether "masculine" symbolic traits have some fundamental link to male biological sex, and if so, to what degree, is not really important to the functioning of this framework, so if it helps, treat it as wholly arbitrary (see 2 below)
  2. What characteristics get considered "masculine" or "feminine" in this framework are largely derived from looking at lots and lots of myths and seeing what kind of characters are depicted as male and which as feminine. There are a few challenges here: a. the corpus of myths drawn on is almost entirely from the Mediterranean and Europe, from Ancient Egypt through early modern times, and so the myths of other cultures around the world might consistently assign different traits to masculine or feminine archetypes, b. even within the cultures ancestral to the modern West, what gets considered "masculine" and "feminine" has some variation - for example, the Egyptians had a Father Earth and Mother Sky, and to the Germanic folks, the Sun was a beautiful lady and the Moon a macho man. All of which is to say, we're talking in broad brushstrokes here, but ones that are the most useful for understanding the myths and stories of the Ancient Near East, Mediterranean, and Europe through the Early Modern period.

The Good Side and the Bad Side of the Three Basic Categories

Each of the three basic categories (Order, Chaos, and Mediator) has a good side and a bad side. These bring us back to our basic motivational systems that we briefly summarized in the Biological Grounding above (you see why he went to the trouble to make sure you believed him on that stuff?) The good side of each symbol represents what about it draws us toward it and rewards us if we do indeed go there - Good Order provides helpful predictability, Good Chaos provides new possibilities, and the Good Mediator allows for these things to be balanced dynamically, adjusted as needed. The bad side, then, reflects what about these categories causes anxiety if you can't get away with it - Bad Order is controlling and stifling, Bad Chaos is wild and unpredictable, the Bad Mediator is too absorbed in him/herself to balance the others and makes things worse. Putting this Good/Bad valence together with the three basic categories gives us six main archetypes, which Peterson argues represent a fairly complete, coherent view of how the world works and how to find meaning within it.

The Good King and the Tyrant - Order, Good and Bad

If you've grown up playing D&D like me, and even more so if you've delved into the Poul Anderson and Michael Moorcock fiction that inspired its alignment system, you're likely used to thinking of Order as "basically good". Peterson argues this is only half-right. Civilization and society are heavily associated with Order, especially it's good side. The good side of Order is represented by the Good or Just King. Laws basically uphold what is right, good, competent people usually do better than wicked ones, if you need help, there are folks to turn to who can give it, if you have something you need to do, someone can tell you how to do it.

On the other hand, too much Order, or the wrong sort, or even Order that used to be helpful, but now no longer applies, can all become the bad side of Order, the Tyrant. Laws catch you in a tangled web that makes it impossible to do anything without breaking one of them, folks advance more for knowing which boxes to check and what forms to fill out than from competence, if you need help, only properly licensed, authorized, and monitored officials can help you, and if you have something you need to do, you damn well better do it the way everyone else does, or else. If you have ever navigated an automated customer service menu to try to handle a straightforward request, only to have every choice you try take you back to the same (wrong) answer (or even worse, this happened with a live human slavishly following a script), then you know what Bad Order can look like.

The Kind Mother and the Devouring Beast - Chaos, Good and Bad

Again, we're facing a bit of bias from the language we use, as we tend to default to "Chaos is bad". The good side of Chaos, the "Kind Mother" archetype, we might instead call "possibility," or "fertility," or even "creativity". The idea is that the only place new things can come from is the unknown, the not-fully-organized, thus, the Chaotic. Good Chaos is also receptive in the good sense - it welcomes you, it responds to your exploration of it, it reveals knowledge and treasures when you ask politely.

The bad side of Chaos, the Devouring Beast/Mother, is everything bad about the unknown, the unorganized, the untamed. Beasts in the wilderness, dragons in caves, child-eating witches in gingerbread houses, all of these are manifestations of Bad Chaos. But then, so is the criminal, the outlaw, the raider. Bad Chaos is also receptive in the bad sense - it envelops you, it gives you somewhere to get lost in, it reveals how little you truly know and how insecure your treasures are.

Interestingly, the earth (as in, the ground) plays both of these roles. The earth is where the plants we eat grow out of, where the animals we eat roam, and it holds the water we drink. On the other hand, it's also where forests full of lions, tigers, and bears grow, where outlaws and invaders lurk, and where our bones disappear into when we die. The sea can also play both roles (fish come from it, but you can drown in it).

The Hero and the Villain - The Mediator, Good and Bad

Standing between Order and Chaos (whether Good, Bad, or Both) is the individual, the Mediator. This person stands for each of us as we read the story - he makes choices that we can reflect on, undergoes trials that we can sympathize with, and teaches us lessons about achieving goals (or failing to tragically). The Good Mediator is the Hero - an individual who shows wisdom, compassion, generosity, bravery, or any other noble qualities. The Hero recognizes and values the gifts of Good Order and Good Chaos, and bravely confronts the depredations of Bad Order and Bad Chaos. Maybe most importantly, the Hero balances Order and Chaos appropriately - if things have become too rigid, he brings in the rejuvenation of Chaos, if things have become too wild, he brings in the steadying of Order.

The Bad Mediator is then, of course, the Villain, the flip side of the same coin. There's a reason for the stereotype of "we're not so different, you and I. . ." - in a good story, the Hero and the Villain do have much in common. Both face an uncertain world full of risks and rewards, both see the interaction of Order and Chaos in their world and try to take some action to put it more to their liking, and both serve to remind us, the reader/listener, what people are like. In many old stories, they are literally brothers. Where the hero displays noble qualities, though, the villain shows some or all of the ignoble: folly, cruelty, selfishness, cowardice, and more. Where the Hero finds balance, the Villain is more likely to tilt things further out of whack, or to swing the pendulum too far the other way. Often, the villain sees only the bad side of one, the other, or both of Order and Chaos. At his worst, the Villain believes that Being itself is wrong and should be undone, the ultimate nihilism.

A Couple of Examples, to Make this Clear

Alright, so, like I said, the trouble with abstractions is that if you don't have specific instances to link them to, they can be so vague as to be unhelpful. So let's go through a couple of examples.

Story/Mythic Example

One of Peterson's favorite examples, and a film I've come to appreciate more thanks to his exegesis of it, is The Lion King. If you somehow haven't seen it, I suppose I should warn you that here be spoilers. Simba is obviously the Hero, the Good Mediator figure. Mufasa is obviously the Good King/Kind Father, and thus the positive side of Order. Scar kind of plays double duty as the Bad Mediator (Villain), as well as embodying the Tyrant, Bad Order. Nala somewhat takes on the role of Good Chaos by being one hell of a surprise to Simba when she finds him, and starting him on his path back to Pride Rock. And the hyenas are then Bad Chaos (though interestingly, put to work on behalf of Bad Order). The landscape also takes on some of these roles. The Elephant Graveyard, the barren desert that Simba first escapes to, the Pride Lands when they've been screwed up under Scar's rule, all of these are Bad Chaos. The Pride Lands at the beginning and end of the story and the lush paradise Timon and Pumba take Simba to are places of Good Chaos. You can also see how the different archetypes manifest in the same character at different times - young Simba is brave and loyal (Good Mediaor), but full of himself and a bit foolish (Bad Mediator). Teenage Simba is kind and protective of his friends (Good Mediator), but he's deeply afraid and avoids responsibility (Bad Mediator). Adult Simba acknowledges his responsibility and admits what he has done wrong to try to save his people (Good Mediator), but lets himself fall for Scar's manipulations (Bad Mediator). He also shows alternation between how much Chaos and how much Order he represents, and whether it's good or bad. As a rambunctious, rule-breaking child, he embodies Bad(ish) Chaos, but as the one who brings the rains back, Good Chaos. In his desire to boss people around and have his ego flattered ("I Just Can't Wait to Be King!"), he shows Bad Order, but by deposing the Tyrant and restoring just rule to the Pride Lands, he shows Good Order.

So, you can see how the application of these archetypes in different ways, and the interplay between them, can lead to a fairly rich and nuanced set of insights into a story.

"Real Life" example

Okay, stories are well and good, but if you're not yet convinced that understanding stories better will help us understand ourselves and how to live our lives better, then an example of how to apply these archetypes to a story like the one above won't do much for you. So, let me run through how we could use these to think about situations in our lives.

Let's say you're stuck in a job that makes you miserable. The economy sucks and you're worried about finding another job (Bad Chaos). Your boss is a micromanaging jerk who takes credit for anything good the team does, and passes blame for anything bad (Bad Order). But even worse, the team is a mess - there are no standard procedures to follow, no one knows who is responsible for what, and your boss is constantly dropping surprise last-minute assignments on you (Bad Chaos). You've gotten to the point where you try to avoid as much responsibility as you can and lie about how much work you're doing (Bad Mediator), because trying to do better has just gotten you burned in the past. Your only relief is to spend your weekends either playing video games for hours on end or getting hammered - or both (Bad Mediator).

One day, you've had enough, and you decide you're going to put your life back on a track that suits you better (Good Mediator). You realize that one reason you feel stuck is that you don't have the skills you need to get a job somewhere else, so you sign up for a course (Good Mediator). Through the course, you meet some folks who are also looking for work, and you start to hear about opportunities you'd never considered (Good Chaos). You decide that you're going to create a habit of applying to 5 new jobs a week until you find a new one (Good Order). Once you land the new job, you politely, but firmly, tell your boss that you're leaving and it's because this place is terrible (Good Mediator), and you have a very candid exit interview with HR, hoping that maybe the company can be a little better to work for, even if you're gone (Good Order). As you get ready for your first day on the new job, you're a little nervous, but mostly you're excited, because now you know that if it doesn't work out, you can always find something else (Good Chaos).

Alright, so that wasn't the most detailed or interesting scenario, but hopefully it gives some idea of how these ideas can play out in your life. More importantly, once you've learned to think that way, you can start analyzing situations in your life through this lens - where do you feel stifled (Bad Order)? Where do you feel overwhelmed by uncertainty (Bad Chaos)? Where do you act like a jerk (Bad Mediator)? Where do you help others out (Good Mediator)? Where do you have helpful routines (Good Order)? Where do you feel excited about unexplored possibilities (Good Chaos)?

Some Shortcomings of Peterson's Way, as I See Them

Having spent all these words laying out why I think Peterson's framework is helpful, you might (rightly) guess that I'm a big fan. Even still, no framework is foolproof, and this one is no exception. For me, the biggest challenge in using this framework is the level of abstraction discussed above - the fact that it can be applied to any story means that it's missing some of the nuance that it might be helpful to highlight. One example: Jung identified the archetype of the Magician/Wise Old Man, and Campbell noticed how very common that figure was in the "Hero's Journey" mythic storyline. Where does the Magician fit in here? Well, he's kinda-sorta Good Chaos, because he deals with the unknown, but he's also kinda-sorta Good Order, because he often provides wisdom and guidance to the young hero, and he's kinda-sorta the mediator because he helps the hero understand and deal with balancing Order and Chaos. The point is, having a "Magician" archetype you can talk about is often helpful, and it doesn't fit as neatly into the higher-level abstraction of Peterson's framework.

Perhaps more fundamentally, let's return to the Nietzschean motivation for this whole project in the first place, which we summarized (and somewhat oversimplified) as "if God is dead, why do His stories keep shaping what we find meaningful?" This is making a few pretty big assumptions, though: what about the wide swaths of the world that get by just fine with other bases for their morality? What about folks who still have active, meaningful spiritual experiences and don't feel like (the) God(s) is (are) dead at all? In these cases, I think Peterson's analysis still has much to offer, but his need to ground out this analysis in materialistic explanations compatible with a scientific understanding sometimes bleeds through.

With These Thoughts, Hopefully You Can More Readily Engage with Peterson's Work

So, here we are. Peterson's framework is fairly high-level, fairly abstract, but because of this, it's pretty versatile. It's a bit like a Swiss Army Knife of story/myth interpretation - in the long run, you might get far more out of a myth or story through other ways of looking into it deeply, but this gives you a handy starting place, especially for those stories that otherwise seem opaque. Is there a female character? Maybe she represent Chaos, Good, Bad, or mixed. Can the main character's actions be interpreted as balancing Order and Chaos? What about representatives of Order - are they acting more just and protecting, or more tyrannical and controlling? I like to think of this method as a kind of prybar for getting into the underlying meaning of a story - it might not help you fully unpack it, but it can almost always help you get started.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

[Heathen Rosary] Asking for Help with Hail Idun

Date: 2023-February-26

So, I'm getting close on my "Hail Idun", but I can tell I'm not right there yet. Divination has suggested that I ought to go with a single stanza of Galdralag (two four-line half stanzas), and a few of the images/themes I should/shouldn't include. These poems/prayers are highly personal, but I'm also trying to make sure they work for other folks, so I'm going to share three variants I'm thinking over below, and I'd very much welcome your thoughts on what bits work, what don't, and what I might change. As I've said before, whatever I land on for this prayer will be the beating heart of my Heathen Rosary, so I want to get it right.

Way 1

Hail Idun,
Yggdrasil's Seed,
Life-giving Lady,
Love-giving Lady.

Blessed Idun,
Blossom of Healing,
Goddess ale-giving,
Quench our thirst for thee.

Way 2

Hail Idun,
Heart's Opener,
Lady love-giving,
Lady life-giving.

Bless us with
Blissful drink,
Ale age-helping,
Mead mind-opening.

Way 3

Hail Idun,
Heart Gladdener,
Beloved life-giver,
Lady love-giving.

Blissful Idun,
Bless us with
Thirst quenched with thanks,
Soul awakened to seeking.

Close

Again, it would be a great help if you can share your thoughts on any of the above, most of all if the wording of any bits works better than others - whether to pick one or another, whether to blend them together, or whether to start all over again. Thanks very much, and I hope you find something helpful here.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Opening Thoughts on Beauty

Date: 2023-February-19

This is very much a "start writing to work things out and see where takes you" kind of post, or even more so, series of posts, I'm sure. The more I think about and reflect on the role of aesthetic taste in questions of meaning, metaphysics, and even ethics, the more weighty it seems to be. I know that it's far from an original thought to be like "whoah, maybe beauty is a transcendental virtue" (as in, "Plato talked about this, and it wasn't new then" unoriginal). Even still, it's a line of thinking I'm trying to work out for myself, and I think maybe talking it over with you will help with that. Hopefully you'll at least bear with me, and with any luck, I'll share something you find helpful.

In my head, this feels like a coherent, even simple idea, but whenever I find myself trying to explain it, I see that it is actually huge, messy, and touches nearly everything else. I had been thinking I should read more about this and wait to write about it until I had digested more folks' thoughts, but one of the things I'm trying to make myself do with these weekly blog posts is to do more of my thinking "out loud", both since it lets me get more feedback from others, but also since it makes me get it down in some more-or-less definite form, which often makes it clear where my thinking is fuzzy, derivative, or otherwise not what I'd like it to be. So, here's my attempt at a short version: our sense of what is aesthetic, what is beautiful, what is pleasing is central to our ability to sort out what is best and most meaningful in life. It's not the only thing around that, but it's one of the very weighty things.

What do I mean by this, exactly? If you have a philosophy that makes good sense to you and you can back up logically, but it leaves you cold, it's almost certainly not your path to a truly meaningful and good life. Likewise, if there is something that stirs you deeply, but you can't truly say why, you likely ought to follow it. I suspect, but don't yet have any way to make my case, that our sense of what "looks right" or "feels right" or "is beautiful" is a very deep synthesis of many factors, including some that are very important, but very hard to access consciously. An analogy I can draw on from experience: if you've ever learned to draw human bodies, then there are certain proportions in a drawing that you will just expect to see, and if you don't, you'll be like "something is wrong with this drawing, I don't like it". On the other hand, there are certain ways real human proportions can be exaggerated or manipulated for pleasing artistic effect (think the giant eyes that anime borrowed from Disney cartoons). With enough muscle memory of drawing correctly proportioned anatomy, getting the proportions wrong just "feels" off, even if you can't say exactly why. Now, you might argue that such drawing doesn't carry much moral or spiritual weight, and you're likely right, but it's a very clear cut example of somewhere that a lot of internalized knowledge due to practice, observation, and feedback leads to a situation where that internalized knowledge is perceived as "it just doesn't feel right". I suspect that most aesthetic perception of the sort "I dunno, I just like it" or "that just sounds off to me" is, in fact, the same kind of deeply internalized knowledge from repeated exposure and judgment.

One nice thing about this way of thinking about aesthetics is that it helps us get around the always-present and always-thorny problem of "what about sexual attraction, though?" If you haven't run into this, here's how it goes: "The idea of 'beauty' is clearly somehow related to the concept of sexual attraction, but there are beautiful things that have nothing to do with sex, so what gives?" This is an especially telling point if your primary basis for understanding aesthetics, or even all of human psychology, is an evolutionary one, where sex gets the starring role. So how does my proposal above address this? Well, if we take "aesthetic judgment" to mean something like "the qualitative feeling that something you observe is suitable or not suitable to the purpose for which you're evaluating it, whether or not you can articulate the drivers for that judgment," then all of a sudden the link between sexual attraction and aesthetic beauty becomes easy to define. If a judgment of something as aesthetically "beautiful" is the positive feeling you get for something that you're pretty sure will "work", even if you don't know why, then seeing someone that will "work" for you sexually, even if you can't articulate why, will present in a very similar way. Add in the fact that the sex drive is super important to most folks, and this becomes an area of aesthetic judgment that almost everyone exercises every day, all the time. So, by this logic, it's not that aesthetic beauty is some ramification or epiphenomenon of sexual attraction, it's that your judgment of sexual attractiveness is just your best exercised aesthetic muscle (if you're anything like most folks).

Okay, my thoughts could go a lot of different directions from here, but that actually got me to a new conclusion (I hadn't worked out that judgment of sexual attractiveness is a subset of aesthetic judgment, rather than something foundational or ancestral to it). So, I think I'll wrap things up for now. Some directions I'd like to go here: what to make of evil aesthetic judgments (it is pleasing to torture this person)? Can you arrive at ethically defensible positions without bringing in aesthetics? Can aesthetics lead you astray? What role have aesthetic judgments played in my own spiritual growth? All these and more lead me to want to write many more posts, but I have no idea when they'll come out.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Thoughts on my Thirty Eighth Year

Date: 2023-February-12

Today is my birthday, so I'm going to go ahead and take one of my "steadholders" for the year. I had hoped to get a new take on the Hail Idun prayer in Germanish meter, but my first few drafts aren't doing it for me, and since it will be the beating heart of the Heathen Rosary, I want to get it right. Instead, a few things I've been thinking about:

  • 38 truly feels a lot closer to 40 than 37, but even that was "not my 'mid-thirties' anymore." I've always sought to not get too hung up on youth and my age, and to know and accept my own looming death, but it didn't fully hit me until 2018 when my mother passed away and my first daughter was born within a couple of months of each other. That was one hell of a shot of "you're only one step in the ongoing march of life" all at once.
  • My older daughter is doing her bit to make me feel the full weight of growing older. Yesterday, she asked me "Daddy, are you an old man?" and I said "no, not yet, but I'm on my way there." So, she said "will you be an old man tomorrow?" and again "no, not just yet." "Well, when will you be an old man?" "Not for a while, honey."
  • More earnestly, my deepening spiritual work has been a big help with acknowledging and dealing with my feelings about getting older. I truly don't know where I'd be had the last few years gone otherwise. These days, my only regret is that I didn't find this path sooner, but I keep telling myself it's not a race, there's no prize for "doing more," it's not about what's at the end of the path, it's all about walking it.

With that said, I put forth my blessings to you and hope the coming year treats you wonderfully.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Thoughts on The Way of the Rose

Date: 2023-February-05

The very first book that I dug into after my year with dead writers was The Way of the Rose: The Radical Path of the Divine Feminine Hidden in the Rosary by Clark Strand and Perdita Finn. Someone had spoken well of it on a Magic Monday over on JMG's dreamwidth journal, and it sounded like it would be helpful to me in my Heathen Rosary work. Overall, I found the book helpful and thought-stirring, but below, I share my thoughts in more depth.

In a nutshell, the book makes the case that the Rosary is a very helpful tool for spiritual growth and healing that need not be only for Catholics, or even Christians. The book is written with one chapter for every bead on a stock Rosary, and the chapters are grouped by the old mysteries (so no "Luminous mysteries"). Through these chapters, the writers put forth that the Rosary represents a very, very old strand of Goddess worship squelched by the church that nevertheless found its way into folks' daily practice. They give some slightly changed ways of saying the prayers to make them a bit more welcoming for those who are not Christians. They also give some thoughts on how to pray, such as getting together in "Rosary Groups". The bulk of the book speaks of the writers' own spiritual paths with the Rosary: coming to it through "coincidences" and visions, deepening connection with it, and some "whoah, this [stuff] works" moments. Along the way, they talk about how the Rosary came to be and what has happened with it, of the Church, of religion more broadly, and their own backgrounds in spiritual seeking. If any of this sounds like it might be interesting, read on!

I said at the start that my goal in reading this book was to deepen my understanding of the Rosary as a step on the way to crafting my "Heathen Rosary", and weirdly enough, this book might as well have been written for that very end. Okay, okay, not wholly that, but their way of talking about the Rosary was remarkably helpful to me in a few ways. First, the weight they put on the Rosary as a way of getting a hold of the "Divine Feminine", but matched with calls to the "Divine Masculine", lined up with one of my gut-feelings about what makes the Rosary work so well. Next, my way of working has been to "back-craft" the Rosary, to work on understanding what makes it tick beyond "it's contemplation while saying the same prayers over and over with beads to keep track". As such, their use of a almost the stock Rosary, but with a very unalike theological understanding and goal, meant that a lot of their insights were worthwhile to me. Lastly, the book highlights the slow, steady insight and wisdom that comes from ongoing work, even if you don't know why/how/whether it's working, which matches how spiritual practice has worked out for me so far.

To take these as they were named, the first thing was weighty enough to show up in the under-name (subtitle) of the book: the Rosary is a way of getting in touch with the "Divine Feminine." While this was one of the main ways the book was helpful to me, it also touches on one of the book's biggest drawbacks for me, which is that the writers seem to believe something like "all Goddesses are one Goddess". As such, they see worship of mother Goddesses in the paleolithic caves of France, the Eleusinian Mysteries, and praying the Rosary all as unalike ways of giving prayer and worship to the same holy Being. This is what is sometimes called soft polytheism, which I think is likely an overly shallow take on what's going on in the spiritual world. This hurdle is fairly readily dealt with, but it's also there throughout the whole book. Even so, I think they rightly mark out some threads of what worship for feminine beings is like and bring those threads out clearly in the Rosary and what it has to teach. What kind of things do I mean? Things like kindness, forgiveness, open-heartedness, and wisdom. The book doesn't highlight as much the matching (not to say equal weight) between the masculine and feminine held in the Rosary. Each decade of ten "Hail Marys" opens with an "Our Father" and closes with a "Glory Be" (which calls upon the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost) - so you can see that Mary (the feminine) is very much at the heart of the practice, but with a weighty masculine match. I think it likely that this is a weighty bit of what makes the Rosary so mighty spiritually, and I want to have the same overall take for my Heathen Rosary.

Next, this book is indeed helpful for my "back-crafting" work, since it takes the Rosary earnestly, but is not bound by Catholic theology or doctrine. This opens the writers up to insights about how it works and what it's doing that a Catholic might either not heed or else make match up with the overall shape of their set of beliefs. For one ready showdeal, the set of prayers for the Rosary given in the book leaves out the Apostle's Creed at the beginning, because that is a downright affirmation that "yes, I believe the things Christianity has to teach" and puts the whole prayer in that framework. A Catholic likely deems that a needful bit, where Strand and Finn see it as a "lock" put on the gate to keep out those the Church wouldn't want saying "its" prayer. Likewise, in talking through the mysteries to be contemplated while praying the Rosary, a Catholic like de Montford will strongly ground them in the wider framework of Catholic theology, with a lot of steering on what a right understanding of each mystery might be. This work, on the other hand, looks at the mysteries as one set of tales showing wider spiritual truths. You don't have to believe that 2,000 years ago a Rabbi's dead body woke up and walked out of a cave to find loveliness, meaning, and Truth of a less straightforward kind in the tale of the rebirth. I'm most of all thankful that the writers spelled out how both the mysteries and the words of the "Hail Mary" go from life to suffering to death to rebirth. I may not want my Heathen Rosary to go through the same steps, but I do want the same kind of deep, framing resonances between the prayers themselves and the overall practice. To bring in an overly-leaned-upon forlikening (metaphor): this book has worked like a Rosetta Stone for the Rosary for me - rather than needing to translate from Catholic to Heathen with nothing in between, I can see what translating the Rosary into other spiritual "tongues" looks like, which is helpful.

Thirdly, the book spoke to a way of coming at spiritual growth that I seem to need to work on - steadfast, bit-by-bit unfolding of wisdom and insight through ongoing work. To fully share what I mean, I might have to lay out a bit about myself. Growing up, I was always a "smart kid" - I understood things quickly, soaked up new knowledge, and otherwise was ready to do things with my mind. I say this not to brag, as you'll see, but to highlight that I was (and largely still am) "brainy", maybe to the harm of other ways of knowing and understanding the world. This was made painfully clear to me in the aftermath of my mother passing away from cancer. Mind-wise, I had settled myself with what had happened, what it meant to me, how I should think and feel about it, and I thought I was alright. But I was not alright. My wife at last got me to go talk to a therapist, and through that and some of my own looking back, I had the insight that I was so wont to being able to think my way through things, to use my mind to handle stuff in my life, that I thought my feelings would play by the same rules, to answer to the same ways of doing things. In the same way that as a kid in math class, after doing a few problems I "got" how to bring to bear the principle and found further going over boring and unneeded, I thought that reading a few books, thinking about what happened in a few other folks' lives meant that I "got" grief and could go about my business with that little hardship cleanly worked out. As will no doubt be blindingly clear to you, unless you share the same quirk of which I've been telling, this is not at all how grief or any other weighty feeling works. You have to, you know, truly feel it, and that takes time and cannot be bossed around by the words in your head. What does work is daily, plodding work, over and over again, whether you're "feeling it" this time or not. Whether prayer, meditation, journaling, or whatever other spiritual practice, every time I have buckled down and done it no matter what, that is where I have been gifted with worthwhile spiritual experiences. The book had a lovely quote on coming at the Rosary in this way:

Rosary wisdom tends to grow slowly, building gradually over the course of a lifetime. The rosary isn't a degree program. There are no classes or courses. There's no diploma at the end. There isn't any end. We never stop accumulating the wisdom of the rosary. The beads turn, the seasons pass. The experiences of a lifetime settle within us like fallen leaves and flowers, becoming the top-soil that nourishes and informs our lives.

Overall, I found this book insightful and helpful, and I'm very glad I read it. That being said, it won't grab everyone alike. For starters, if the Rosary holds no spiritual or aesthetic appeal for you, I doubt that this book will change that. For another, Strand and Clark are coming at this from an openly "feminist" outlook, which brings along with it ways of framing and understanding things that you may or may not find helpful. One showdeal is their strong dislike and wariness of hierarchy, most of all those mostly made up of men, as seen when they speak rather harshly of "religion" many times in the book. By "religion" they seem to mean any group with any hierarchy given to spiritual ends. Another showdeal is that in a few steads they treat masculine ways of understanding or dealing with the world as childish or mistaken, things that need to be outgrown or put aside, rather than matched with feminine ways for a healthy whole. For both of these showdeals, they share things they have lived through that make it rather understandable how they would come to this way of looking at the world, including some truly wretched dealings with so-called spiritual teachers, but I still think they've "learned too much" from those happenings. Lastly, they speak in rather apocalyptic words about the way the world is going - it's not so much that I doubt things things are going to go poorly, but rather that I don't foresee the sudden and utter outcomes held in apocalyptic thinking about what may come. I think a slow, ragged descent is a far more likely forecast.

So, if you'd like to learn more about the Rosary from a truly not-Christian way of looking at the world, or maybe work at understanding some of what folks have found in praying the Rosary, this book's a great way to do that.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Mark of the Wells

Date: 2023-January-29

In my ongoing work on a Heathen Rosary, I hit upon the thought that I ought to have something much like the Christian "Sign of the Cross" - a quick prayer and bodily token of self-blessing and warding. As with much of this undertaking, I started from the thought that Christian, most of all older kinds of Christian, tradition has much that works well, and maybe it doesn't only work for Christian beliefs. The things that drew me to the Sign of the Cross were 1. it is rather short, 2. in that short length, it calls upon a whole, balanced holiness, and 3. it is linked with energy centers in the subtle body. These hallmarks let the Sign of the Cross be something that Christians use both day-to-day (before and after longer prayers, when coming to the altar, and so forth) and also "as needed", such as coming across something dreadful or grasping that a statement ought to have been a prayer.

So, I set about coming up with such a short prayer-with-gesture that works for my own beliefs and worship. What I came up with largely came from intuition, meditation, prayer, and divination. I haven't tested it out much yet, so if anyone else finds this helpful, I'd love to hear from you. Let me break down how I matched up the bits I laid out above:

  1. To make it short, I settled on Galdralag meter. I also tried out some others, such as four lines of Anglo-Saxon Long Lines, but those felt a bit long for what I was looking for.
  2. To get a whole, balanced likeness of the spiritual world, I began with the thought of the World Tree, Yggdrasil. As I worked on this and meditated, though, it came to me to instead focus mainly on the three wells from which the World Tree's roots drink - in Old Norse, Hvergelmir, Mimisbrunnr, and Urdabrunnr (more on these below when I talk about the words I picked).
  3. For the energy centers, I drew on those marked out in John Michael Greer's Druidic magical systems, such as that laid out in his Druid Magic Handbook. These are the "womb center" about an inch below the belly button, the "third eye" between the eyebrows, and the heart center (unsurprisingly, at the heart).

Again, I got to much of this in a way I can't wholly spell out in a way I can back up, but it feels pretty strong to me nonetheless.

So, what of the prayer itself? As I said, I used Galdralag, and here's what I came up with:

From seething hwer1,
Woden's drink,
and Wyrd's holy well,
Mighty tree unmatched.

1 An Old English word meaning "boiler, cauldron"

A few thoughts on the words I picked. First, "hwer" was a bit of an odd one, but I couldn't land on a translation of Hvergelmir I liked much. Hwer is the direct cognate with Old Norse hver, a word for a pot or a kettle. The gelmir bit is cognate with "yelling", but "Yelling Pot" just doesn't have much of a ring to it in English, to say nothing of making the alliteration work. The sense of Hvergelmir seems to be something like churning rapids, or a steaming, boiling hot spring. "Woden's Drink" is a pretty straightforward kenning for Meomer's (Mimir's) Well, the well of wisdom that Woden gave his eye to drink from. Wyrd's holy well is, of course, the Old Norse Urdhabrunnr, Wyrd being a direct cognate for Urdh. The "mighty tree unmatched" is, also of course, the World Tree, Yggdrasil.

So, here's how I've been doing it:

  1. Take 2 fingers and put them about an inch below your belly button and say "From seething hwer,"
  2. Move your fingers to the spot between your eyebrows and say "Woden's drink,"
  3. Move your fingers to your heart and say "and Wyrd's holy well, Mighty tree unmatched."

This ought to work for Heathens who'd like an all-around self-blessing/warding to say before and/or after prayer, when running into wicked things, and so forth. I'll start using it, and I'll let you know what I find out.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

List of Books on Germanish Belief with Thoughts

Date: 2023-January-22

I very much like when a writer shares not only the books that they have read, but also what they think of them - an "annotated bibliography". I may not have a book of my own (yet), but I do have a big ol' list of books I have read or want to read on Germanish belief, and I thought I'd share it. As I get to the books I haven't read on this list, I might come back and add my thoughts on them. If you know of any books you think ought to be on the list, kindly let me know! For now, I'll share my thoughts either from reading the book, or what I know about it that makes me want to read it.

Also, it ought to go without saying, but given the times we live in, I'll say it anyhow: my putting a book on the list below does not mean I agree with it in whole or in part - it only means that I think it might have some insights on understanding the field it's about.

Wellsprings of the Lore

These are the elder works that everything else builds upon. Mostly written down by Christians, and mostly written sometime after folks worshiped the Germanish Gods and Goddesses, we are nevertheless lucky to have far more to work with than the beliefs of many other lands. These works show us a tantalizing glimpse of the wider world of Gods, Goddesses, elves, dwarves, and other wights that the folks of Germanish lands lived in before the coming of Christianity.

The Prose Edda

By: Snorri Sturlusson
Have I Read It?: Yes, more than once, from many translators
Thoughts: This is the book to read on Old Norse mythology. If you read nothing else, read this one. Helpfully put-together and makes good sense, maybe too much sometimes, but most of the "summaries of Old Norse Mythology" below are mostly restatements of this. More than one good translation out there, but I like the Jesse Byock one or Jackson Crawford's.

The Poetic Edda

By: Many writers
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: In many ways, this is even more grounded than The Prose Edda, but it's harder to follow if you haven't already read Sturlusson's learned summary. Jackson Crawford's translation is helpfully literal, Lee Hollander's has a delightful Germanish taste thanks to the words he uses, and Maria Kvilhaug's take in her book Seed of Yggdrasil (see below) gives the meaning of the proper names, which is a big help to understanding.

The Sagas of the Icelanders

By: Many writers
Have I Read It?: Some of it
Thoughts: I have a lovely collection of all of the sagas in translation, available here. These works give a lot of hints about what pre-Christian belief and worship looked like, but it takes some amount of combing to make the most of them.

Germania

By: Tacitus
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: This is maybe our oldest written take on what the Germanish folks of the time believed and did for worship. It has the great strength of not being written by Christians, which gives a very different look at things.

Gesta Danorum

By: Saxo Grammaticus
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This re-tells many of the stories found in the Prose Edda and tells a few others not known elsewhere, but through the "euhemerization" lens. Basically, Saxo believes that the Heathen lore was a garbled way of talking about normal humans that lived in the world. So, he needs to be taken with lots of salt, but he shares a lot that can't be found elsewhere.

Heimskringla

By: Snorri Sturlusson
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This is a history of the kings of Norway and Sweden written by the same heavy hitter who gave us the Prose Edda. Though written as a "history," the older bits likely draw on beliefs from before Christianity. For translations, Lee Hollander's is good, but there are very many.

Beowulf

By: Unknown, translated by Howell D. Chickering
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: The one, best-known poem from Old English times, it was written down by a Christian monk, but it holds many beliefs from older times. This translation comes in dual-language edition that shows the Old English text, and on the facing page.

Grove and Gallows: Greek and Latin Sources for Germanic Heathenism

By: James Chisholm
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: This is the very kind of workhorse book that everyone else is lucky to have when someone goes to the trouble to put it together. It brings together short outcuttings (excerpts) from Classical and Medieval Christian sources on Germanish Heathens (so, pretty much everything other than the Germanish Poetry that we have about the Heathenry of elder times). My one gripe is that it doesn't give the Latin or Greek, only the words wended (translated) into English.

The Legend of Sigurd and Gudrun

By: Unknown, translated by J.R.R. Tolkien
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Not only a translation, this tells a coherent version of the story of Sigurd and Gudrun, which are told in multiple places in multiple languages. Tolkien put it together following the rules of Old Norse/Old English poetic meter in modern English, which makes for a lovely read. Mark that it's a bit of a stretch to call this a "wellspring", since Tolkien did much to work together bits that didn't readily fit together, and the words are his own poetry.

Other Old English Works

There's a fairly large body of work in Old English, much of it poetry, but all written down by Christians. Even so, there are hints and clues to older belief salted throughout, and if nothing else, you can get an understanding of the folkways that kept going after switching over to Christianity that might help us understand what folks were like before Christianity..

The Complete Old English Poems

By: Many Writers, Translated by Craig Williamson
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: Lots of stuff to work with, but it is a big body of lore, which may not be of as much help as things like the Prose Edda, as much of it is very Christian. Still, the good news is there is a lot of it, and that means lots of small hints and glimpses scattered throughout.

The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle

By: Many Writers, Translated by Michael Swanton]] Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Written down to keep track of what happened during which King's rule, this is another thing written down by Christians, but with bits to help out those who want to know more about beliefs before the Christians.

Learned Works (Academic Works)

These books are written by men and women building upon earlier writings by the learned and working hard to back up what they say with evidence. Most of the books below sit right on the line between those written for other learned men and women and those written for everyday folks.

This may well end up the longest bit of this list, so I've broken it up by fields. Many of these books could rightly be put in more than one of these fields, but I've put them where they seem most fitting to me.

Works on Gods, Goddesses, Worship, and Lore (Religion, Mythology, and Folklore)

These works are all about the Gods, Goddesses, other Beings without bodies, and their worship and lore. These works take the wellsprings above and try to put them together with things dug up from the past, looking at the ways of worship of other Indo-European folks, and so forth.

Myths of the Pagan North

By: Christopher Abram
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: One of the many overviews of Old Norse lore. I have to confess that I have many of these, but have not much read them, as I feel like I already know most of what they hold. That being said, besides their main use (helping folks new to the lore get to know it), they are also helpful to more knowledgeable folks since they bring together in one stead what we know of the tales, beliefs, and worship about each God, the evidence for which might be spread across many works of elder times.

The Poetic Edda (Commentary)

By: Paul Acker and Carolyne Larrington
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A gathering of the thoughts of learned folks on the poems of the Poetic Edda. I haven't dug in yet, but an Ecosophia reader spoke well of it. I gather that Larrington brings an at least somewhat "feminist" lens to looking at Germanish lore, which is rather unlike most of the other folks I read, and so ought to give some new ways of understanding things.

The Well and the Tree

By: Paul Bauschatz
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: I'm reading this at the time of putting this list together, and I'm finding it rather interesting. It seems that Bauschatz mostly uses linguistic evidence to argue that the speakers of Germanish tongues thought about time in a rather unalike way to how we do now or how Roman and Christian writers did, and that we misunderstand what myths meant when we put today's way of looking at time on to them. Very hard to find, but try your nearest university bookhoard.

The Lost Gods of England

By: Brian Branston
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Unlike many of the books on this list, this one looks more to old things rather than old words - it goes over the archaeological evidence for the Gods of pre-Christian England. Some online reviews say that Branston is overly ready to see what he wants to see, but even if so, I would often rather have a writer willing to do that than one who is so careful with finding meaning that you are left with nothing useful for someone seeking to shape their own worship.

Gods and Myths of Northern Europe

By: Hilda R. Ellis Davidson
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Once again, an overview, but this one by a writer who is one of the best known in the field. Davidson was one of the first folks coming from the field of speechlore (philology) to look also at what can be known from digging up old things (archaeology).

The Lost Beliefs of Northern Europe

By: Hilda R. Ellis Davidson
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: While Gods and Myths is more about the tales of the Gods, this book seems to look more at what we know about how they were worshipped.

Myths and Symbols in Pagan Europe

By: Hilda R. Ellis Davidson
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: I am very much looking forward to reading this one, as it looks at both Germanish and Celtic lore and talks through some of the likenesses between them and how those might have come about. This one hits right in the middle of the Venn diagram overlap of my interest in Germanish Lore and my work with Celtic lore through Revival Druidry.

The Road to Hel

By: Hilda R. Ellis Davidson
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Maybe the most thoroughgoing breakdown of what the Germanish folks of elder times seemed to have believed about death, dying, and the afterlife. Pretty much every book below written by today's believers for worship draws heavily on this.

A Companion to the Fairy Tale

By: edited by Hilda R. Ellis Davidson and Anna Chauduri
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A gathering of articles on the "fairy tale" from many ways of looking at this body of folklore, some seeing more of a link with earlier lore, others less. Looks to be interesting and helpful for working out how to think about the wider and better-documented body of tales that might give us insight into the smaller body of for-sure Germanish lore of those who believed in many Gods.

Lady with a Mead Cup

By: Michael J. Enright
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: I started reading this and had to put it down for my year reading only books by the dead, but I think it will be very worthwhile to get back to. Enright lays out the evidence that Celtic and Germanish warbands of the volkerwanderung times had a role for a woman as seeress and initiator, and that you can see hints of this throughout the later lore, even as late as Beowulf. This seems rather weighty for understanding Germanish Goddesses, maybe Freyja most of all.

Gods and Worshipers in the Viking and Germanic World

By: Thor Ewing
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: It's been a while since I read this, but I remember finding it very interesting. The name is maybe overly-broad for what the book is truly about, which is making the case that berserkers and valkyries were real-life groups of worshippers of Odin. I remember thinking that maybe it went a bit too far into "explaining" mythical elements as real-life things done by worshippers, but I think the book is largely right.

The Interpretation of Fairy Tales

By: Marie-Louise von Franz
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A student of Carl Jung's, von Franz wrote rather a lot books. I've pulled out the two that I am most looking forward to reading and that seem to have the most bearing on Germanish belief. This one gives an overall take on understanding fairy tales as expressions of Jung's archetypes, which I have found a very helpful way of getting more meaning out of such tales.

Shadow and Evil in Fairy Tales

By: Marie-Louise von Franz
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: Much like the above, but focused on the "Shadow" archetype, and how that shows itself in evil beings in fairy tales.

Aspects of Anglo-Saxon Magic

By: Bill Griffiths
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This seems to be a gathering of the evidence for how the Anglo-Saxons did magic - written charms, things dug up, bits of folk belief that seem to have old roots, and so forth.

Teutonic Mythology

By: Jacob Grimm (translator Jason Stallybrass)
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: You can say with much fairness that this monster work is the granddaddy of the whole field. Most folks only know about Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm for the fairy tales they gathered, and don't know that they were mostly gathering those tales to find hints about the Gods, lore, and beliefs of elder Germanish folks. While some of what Grimm puts forward has been deemed wrong by later writers, much of it holds up, and if nothing else, his writing is a nearly unbelievable wealth of clues to Germanish folkways, beliefs, lore, and worship beyond the obvious ones from the Eddas and Sagas.

Grimm's Fairy Tales

By: Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Though having less bearing on the beliefs and worship of the Germanish folks of elder times than Jacob's great work, there are nonetheless lots of clues scattered throughout. Also, these tales are fun to read!

The Culture of the Teutons

By: Vilhelm Gronbech
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Many of the works for today's worshipers below mark out this book as somewhere to learn much about how the Germanish folks of elder times thought about the world. From what I've read, it seems that it is very much an outgrowth of its time, and holds a lot of the ways of thinking of the late 19th and early 20th century. All that being said, it seems to be a thoroughgoing take on getting at the thoughtworld of pre-Christian Germanish folks, rather than only understanding their tales or folkways.

English Heroic Legends

By: Kathleen Herbert
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Herbert has written tales about heroes from English lore, told again in a way that is meant to draw on what we know about Elder times and that makes sense and reads well to today's readers, rather than the often patchy bits of poetry or mentions in the Chronicle or the like.

Trees in Anglo-Saxon England

By: Della Hooke
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This seems to be what it says on the tin: a thoroughgoing look at how trees were written about, crafted, and so forth amongst the Anglo-Saxons. I don't think it homes in on worship or belief most of all, but trees were very weighty in Anglo-Saxon belief, even in Christian times (see "The Dream of the Rood" for a showdeal, which is a poem about the crucifixion the way the tree that became the cross saw it).

Odin - The One-Eyed God and the (Indo) Germanic Mannerbunde

By: Kris Kershaw
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: This is maybe the most insightful book on Odin and where his historical worship came from and how it changed. I haven't read widely enough to know how much weight to give to those who set aside Kershaw's claims, but much was made clear to me through reading this, and I still need to meditate on it more.

Demons and Spirits of the Land

By: Claude Lecouteux
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Lecouteux is a French thinker who has pulled together much work on "folklore" rather than on the writings of elder times above, which makes him a helpful complement. Many of his books have only been translated into English in the last ten years or so, so I think he hasn't hit the English-speaking world as hard as the amount and worth of his work maybe should. I'm still only dipping my toes into his stuff, but it is wonderful to find someone talking about things I want to learn about, but coming at it from a wholly different grounding than what I already know.

Encyclopedia of Norse and Germanic Folklore, Mythology, and Magic

By: Claude Lecouteux
Have I Read It?: Much of it
