Thoughts: This is Lecouteux's book I've read the most of so far. It helps shore up some of the gaps in Simek's Dictionary of Northern Mythology, again, with far more weight given to folklore.

The Hidden History of Elves and Dwarfs

By: Claude Lecouteux
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: Another book that I started in on and then had to set aside for my year of reading only books by dead writers. Even though the name of this book has the ugly "dwarfs" instead of the lovely and rightful "dwarves", I am very much looking forward to digging back into this book. It seems to shed a lot of light on why it is that elves and dwarves have something to do with barrows and forebearers, which is something I look forward to working out my own take on.

The Tradition of Household Spirits

By: Claude Lecouteux
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Another of Lecouteux's with bearing on my own belief and worship, as I would like to build strong bonds with the wights of my own house.

Norse Mythology

By: John Lindow
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Still another "overview" book, I don't know much about Lindow, but his research seems to include the beliefs and worship of the folks around the Germanish, such as the Sami and Inuit, which might give him some insight into things that shaped their belief outside of the Proto-Indo-European wellspring.

Heathen Gods in Old English Literature

By: Richard North
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This work goes through where the pre-Christian Gods are named in the Old English writings, and seems to make the case that Ing (likely the same as Ingvi-Freyr) held a very high standing in the beliefs and worship of the Anglo-Saxons. Some folks seem to think he might read too much into what is there, but as I said above, I'd rather have folks speculating wildly than not sharing insights that might turn out worthwhile.

Rites and Religions of the Anglo-Saxons

By: Gale R. Owen
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: It sounds like this is a pretty thorough look at the wide field of evidence for what the Anglo-Saxons believed and how they worshipped. Unlike many books in this field, it also seems this one doesn't hold itself only to Germanish many-godded (polytheist) worship, but also looks at Roman and Celtic many-godded worship and Christianity.

The Elder Gods

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: Much of it
Thoughts: Pollington has become one of my best-loved writers on all things Anglo-Saxon. His work is thorough, with wide-faring citations and careful bringing together of widespread threads. He also strikes a balance between sharing what implications a bit of evidence might have, while being careful to call out what is well-grounded and what is more out-there. This book does a wonderful job of finding the links between the Old English evidence (often scant) and the Nordic lore that is so much more thorough. If your interest in Germanish lore, belief, or worship is at all Anglo-Saxon flavored, this book is well worth your time.

Leechcraft

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: All of the good things I say about The Elder Gods hold true here as well, but this time in a book about the healing ways of the Anglo-Saxons, which were made up of wortlore (herbalism), eating right, charms, prayer, and other fields. Amongst other things, has a thorough run through of the "Nine Herbs Charm" and the whole body in Old English and New of three main works: the Lacnunga, Bald's Third Leechbook, and The Old English Herbarium.

Woden

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Pollington's latest work, I'm very excited about this one, since Woden is the God to whom I feel closest and give the most active worship. This seeks to be a comprehensive overview of the evidence for the God across different Germanish folks and through time. Given Pollington's thoroughness, I suspect this will become a key reference for me.

Essays on Germanic Religion

By: Edgar C. Polome
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Written by the co-founder of the Journal of Indo-European Studies, Polome was a long-time professor at my own alma mater, The University of Texas at Austin. As his journal name might make you think, Polome's strength is bringing insights from comparative Indo-European work to bear on Germanish belief, to help fill in gaps and unriddle things that make us scratch our heads in the lore.

The Turnip Princess

By: Franz Xaver von Schonwerth (Translated by Erika Eichenseer)
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: Another gathering of fairy tales, this was put together by another German at the same time as the Grimms were doing their work - they all knew each other - but Schonwerth's work ended up in a small town's bookhoard until the early 21st century, when it was translated and published. I find it most helpful for giving me another way of looking at the better known fairy tales, as many of the tales in this work are almost familiar, but unalike enough to strike you as weird.

Dictionary of Northern Mythology

By: Rudolf Simek
Have I Read It?: Much of it
Thoughts: One of the mainstays of this field, this book is often my first stop when I can't call to mind everything I might want about a God, Ettin, sword, or what have you. At times not quite as thorough as I might hope for, it still makes for a great springboard into other works on any given entry. Fair warning: so that entries might be brief, Simek sometimes gives his own thoughts as if they are settled even when learned folks might still be thrashing it out.

The Monsters and the Critics and Other Essays

By: J.R.R. Tolkien
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: These days most of us forget that Tolkien was, in fact, one of the leading learned men in the field of Old English. This book holds some of his thoughts on how to think about Beowulf and other Old English works.

The Viking Spirit

By: Daniel McCoy
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Written by the fellow who put together Norse Mythology for Smart People, this book gives an overview of the tales and what we know of the worship and belief around them. I don't hold with all of his interpretations these days, but early on I found his site one of the most helpful resources for getting grounded in the lore that I knew, and I keep on finding it helpful even as my own understanding deepens and changes.

The Norse Myths

By: Kevin Crosley-Holland
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Recommended by Ocean Keltoi as a prose retelling of the myths.

Works on Foretimes (History)

To get the most out of works on belief and ways of worship, it is often helpful to know more about what life was like and what things were going on when those ways were widespread.

The Meadhall

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: As you'll no doubt tire of hearing on this list, I look well upon just about everything by Pollington and buy his books whenever I can find them. This one looks at what we know about "meadhall culture" - the archaeology and reconstruction of the buildings, the social and cultural functions of what went on inside, and what echoes we see in the lore.

The English Warrior from Earliest Times to 1066

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Another Pollington work less-directly related to worship and belief, this looks at what we know about English warrior culture and technique throughout Anglo-Saxon times, and so talks about both Heathen and Christian warriors. Especially interesting to anyone with a more martial bent.

The Germanization of Early Medieval Christianity

By: James C. Russell
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This one comes highly spoken of by very many learned folks as well as believers, and takes an interesting approach: rather than looking at our scanty pre-Christian evidence mainly, it instead looks at the much better-documented Christianity of Germanish lands after conversion, compares that to what we know of earlier, more Mediterranean Christianity, and uses what changed as a source of inferences about the Germanish folkways and worldview that to which the Church shaped itself. A kind of historical/religious "diff tool," if you like computer programming metaphors.

Laughing Shall I Die

By: Tom Shippey
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A book of short biographies of well-known Vikings written by the man who held Tolkien's chair at Oxford in English after him. I haven't read this yet, but Shippey is a good writer and knows his stuff, and the lives of men who grew up in a culture is one of the best ways to come to know that culture.

The Viking Way

By: Neil Price
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Another book that comes up time and time again, I can say from skimming through the copy I have that it's one of those rare books that is both lovely to look at (full-color, lots of photographs) as well as scholarly rigorous. From what I know of it, a good synthesis of literary, archaeological, and anthropological sources to give a feel for what Heathen Germanish culture was like.

Legal Systems Very Different from Our Own

By: David Friedman, Peter T. Leeson, and David Skarbek
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A bit of an outlier for this list, this book was written from a Libertarian point of view to look more deeply at what we take for granted about how "law" works, as a way of suggesting it doesn't have to work that way. THe reason I've included it here is that one of the key case studies is Iceland of the Middle Ages.

The Rise of Magic in Early Medieval Europe

By: Valerie I.J. Flint
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This book looks at the role magic played in shaping, and changing, belief in early Medieval Europe. A key point in its thesis is that much of the success of Christianity was due to its priests and converts being seen to have better and stronger magic than those following the old ways.

Language and History in the Early Germanic World

By: Denis Howard Green
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This book looks to put together what we know from historical sources and can infer from historical linguistics to give an overview of the Germanish folk from the earliest times we believe them to have been distinct through when they started being better documented post-conversion.

Anglo-Saxon Food & Drink

By: Ann Hagen
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Maybe of more interest to the stricter reconstructionist than me, this book looks at what we know about how the Anglo-Saxons ate and drank. Still, food and drink are important parts of culture and belief, and there might be some unlooked for insights here.

Works on Tongues (Language)

This bit could likely be built out far more, most of all if I ever settle on taking on Old Norse or today's German. For now, this is weighted toward my liking of Old English. Mark also that this bit hold works on Runes as a way of writing rather than as a tool for magic. It's helpful to know that many "serious" folks whose field of learning is the Runes lean toward putting very little weight on their use for magic at all, ever, since they do not wish to be overly linked with folks today who seek to use the runes for magic. Make of that what you will.

Runes: A Handbook

By: Michael P. Barnes
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A work that puts together many (most?) of the findings of runes written on things and what those writings might mean. Open to magical and religious interpretations, but careful not to speculate beyond what can be shown in the inscription itself.

Concise Anglo-Saxon Dictionary

By: J.R. Clark-Hall
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: A short(ish) work of Old English words and what they mean in today's English. It doesn't hold every word in Old English, but does have those you're most likely to find most often.

Old English Grammar and Reader

By: Robert E. Diamond
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A short guide to how Old English speechcraft (grammar) works, and some works to go through to learn it better.

Runes

By: R.I. Page
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Page is one of those learned men who is strongly against magical or estoeric readings of the runes, but his book gives a helpfully cut-and-dried take on runic inscriptions, most of all those in Old English.

The Rune Primer

By: Sweyn Plowright
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: A very short grounding in the meaning of the names of the runes of the Elder Futhark, it holds itself to a very "bare bones" take on rune meanings.

Rudiments of Rune Lore

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: A very short grounding in the runes of the Elder Futhark - what they look like, what the name of each Rune is, what sound it stood for, and so forth. Grounded in the Rune Poems, it gives a bit of thought to what the runes might have "meant" beyond their names as a way to remember the sound they made.

Runes and Literacy in the Germanic Iron Age

By: Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: As always, I can't speak highly enough of Pollington's care and hard work in his books. This is an overview of what we know about how Runes came to be and were put to use through the "Migration Era".

Wordcraft

By:Stephen Pollington
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: A book that goes from today's English to Old English, meant to help with writing poetry in Old English. A niche book, but very helpful in that niche.

Works on the Proto-Indo-Europeans

While not straightforwardly about Germanish belief, these works look into what we might know or guess about the forebearers that Germanish folks shared with other folks of Eurasia. These can be a wellspring of surprising insights, but should also be taken with the right amount of salt, for almost the whole field comes from folks going "this thing calls this other thing to mind", whether that be words that sound alike, tales that go along the same lines, or Gods that took similar worship. Professional men and women of learning work very hard to put these likenesses on the strongest footing they might, but at the end of the day, they make a call on what they deem believable and what not, so be careful taking any of their conclusions without giving them your own thought. Mark that if you start going down this path, then works of lore for every other Indo-European folk might have a bearing on what you can work out, but I've deemed those out of scope for this list, lest it grow to even more laughable length.

The Horse, the Wheel, and Language

By: David W. Anthony
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: A wonderful pulling-together of everything we had at the time this was printed on "where did the speakers of proto-Indo-European come from?" A lot of the genetic evidence hadn't been published yet, but this pulls together linguistic, archaeological, and comparative means to argue that the speakers of Proto-Indo-European came from the steppe just north of the Black Sea (modern-day Ukraine and Western Russia). Also a great example of how to make a multi-disciplinary argument thoroughly and fairly straightforwardly.

In Search of the Indo-Europeans

By: J.P. Mallory
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: An earlier take on putting together the comparative evidence for the Proto-Indo-Europeans, this gives a bit more of a picture (based on speculation, of course) of what the Proto-Indo-Europeans looked like.

Mitra-Varuna

By: Georges Dumezil
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Dumezil first put forward the now widely-held thought that the speakers of Proto-Indo-European had a three part society: Wizard-Priest-Kings, Warriors, and Makers, and that these three "functions" show up in the mythology of the folks that grew out of the Proto-Indo-Europeans. This take meets with some skepticism, but I haven't ever read it for myself to weigh it, which I ought to do.

How to Kill a Dragon

By: Calvert Watkins
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A book of "comparative poetics", rather than focusing only on similar thematic elements in the myths of unalike Indo-European folks, Watkins looks at the likenesses in how these folks came up with poems (mostly oral, but later, written down). He argues that you can arrive at a Proto-Indo-European myth about killing a dragon, that had common poetic elements that left traces for hundreds of years after.

The Family of the Gods

By: William G. Davey
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Unluckily, this seems hard to find these days - not all of the volumes were available on Amazon for Kindle last I looked. These are a fairly in-depth look at the kinship links between Gods/Goddesses/heroes and so forth across many Indo-European folks, looking to land on a myth we might understand through familial research. Helpful for fleshing out some corners of thought, but maybe not as carefully researched as some others.

The Indo-Europeans

By: Jean Haudry
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A take on summarizing what we think we can know about the speakers of Proto-Indo-European culturally, linguistically, religiously, and so forth. Any such work will have a lot of speculation.

Other Works with Thinner Links

These works are not straightforwardly about Germanish belief, but have links or likenesses that might be worth digging into anyhow.

The History of Religious Ideas

By: Mircea Eliade
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: A beast of a four-part series, Eliade draws upon a great wealth of stories, belief, and so forth from very unalike folks, lands, and ways of worshiping to try to give an overall look at what belief/worship look like around the world and through time. His biggest problem seems to be wanting to squeeze everything into a sequence of "primitive –> better –> best".

The Sacred and the Profane

By: Mircea Eliade
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: One of Eliade's foundational works, but much shorter than his mammoth four part series, I've been meaning to read this for years. Lays out what seems to be common amongst folks of very different lands and ways of worship for what counts as "hallowed" and what as "to do with normal life".

Shamanism

By: Mircea Eliade
Have I Read It?: About halfway.
Thoughts: Eliade uses "shamanism" fairly broadly and looks at what he thinks might have been the common way of working with Gods and spirits before "religions" arose. He has the strength of great knowledge of the breadth and depth of religious practice, but is maybe too ready to fit it into neat conceptual schemes.

World Full of Gods

By: John Michael Greer
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: This book is the one best laying-out of theology for the belief in and worship of many Gods that I have yet come across. Well worth reading!

The Shaman: Patterns of Siberian and Ojibway Healing

By:John A. Grim
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: It seems that this book is mostly about the author's anthropological study experience with the Ojibway, and a later edition cuts out all the stuff on the Yakutia and other Siberian tribes, but the similarities are interesting and useful if you think that much of what underlies "shamanic" ways of doing things goes all the way back to the folks from whom sprang the Indo-Europeans as well as Native American Indians, the "Ancient North Eurasians" as they're called in genetic science papers.

Works by and for Believers

These books are written by folks who worship the Germanish Gods and/or do magic founded in Germanish ways. Unlike the Learned Works above, these often lean more heavily on what the writers themselves have seen, thought, felt, or done. For folks who want to work out their own way of worshiping or doing magic, these helpfully fill in the gaps left by the Lore

Gods and Beliefs

The books below all home in on how to think about the Gods and how to worship them today, rather than trying to understand what folks thought and did in the past.

The Book of Troth

By: Edred Thorsson
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: One of, if not the, first "How to Heathen" books written for today's worshipers, this is the main book for the Heathen group "The Troth," or at least it was - I'm not sure, since they ended up kicking out Edred Thorsson at some point. Much of what has come to be accepted as standard for holding blot (ritual offering to the Gods) among today's Heathens was first spelled out here. Takes an explicitly Scandinavian tack, which makes sense considering the sources we have to work with.

A Modern Guide to Heathenry

By: Galina Krasskova
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: I've found this book to have a good blend of groudning in the lore and the gnosis of believers. Like most "how to Heathen" books, one of its chief virtues is giving you something to get going with, even if you later decide you don't wholly agree with it. Especially useful for setting out in a thorough and even-handed way some of the break-lines amongst today's Heathens ("folkish" or "universalist," syncretic/open or exclusive, and so forth).

Northern Tradition for the Solitary Practictioner

By: Galina Krasskova and Raven Kaldera
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Like the Modern Guide to Heathenry, this is extremely helpful as a guide for how to go about actually worshiping, most of all if you find yourself doing so alone, as many (most?) of today's Heathens do. I find myself coming back to this often for thoughts on how to set up my godshelf (altar), what color candles to burn for prayers, and other little practical details.

True Hearth

By: James Chisholm
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Where many Heathen books focus on the warrior culture of our forebears, as that is exciting, this book dives into the arguably more practical side of how to run a household as a Heathen, with rites for naming children, mourning the dead, and taking ownership of a new home, among others. Also gives some helpful tips on how different Gods might relate to jobs and other mundane aspects of your life.

True Helm

By: Sweyn Plowright
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Though the title is a an open homage to True Hearth, this book leans fully into the warrior side of things, with a lot of practical advice on how to incorporate a modern martial arts practice into Heathen beliefs.

Seed of Yggdrasil

By: Maria Kvilhaug
Have I Read It?: And How!
Thoughts: Not only did I read this one, I wrote up my thoughts in rather a lot of detail. My short take is that Kvilhaug has a lot of interesting thoughts, and brings together many threads of the myths for a thoroughgoing look at Heathen lore as a guide to esoteric practice. I have some qualms with her pantheistic theology and its implications, but if you bethink (meditate) on Heathen lore, you'll find this book a treasure trove of threads to work with. Worth it for her literal translations of God and hero names alone.

The Trickster and the Thunder God

By: Maria Kvilhaug
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Though I have found Kvilhaug very interesting and useful, I had to take a break from her writing for a bit. I haven't yet tackled how to think about Loki in my worldview, but when I do, I think this book will give much food for thought.

The Goddess Idunn in Myth and Poetry

By: Maria Kvilhaug
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Wonderful short resource for those interested in Idun, as I very much am. Again, the list of translated names and kennings is very helpful, as is Kvilhaug's stanza-by-stanza analysis of the two main poems that tell about Idun.

The Teutonic Way: Religion

By: Kveldulf Gundarsson
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: As I talk about in the magic section, I have found Gundarsson helpful, even if I haven't engaged with his work as deeply as some of these other writers. This book shares much with the Book of Troth, as Gundarsson learned much from Thorsson early on, but with a slightly different take.

The Place of the Earth-Goddess Cult in Pagan English Religion

By: Gary Stanfield
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: I have not read this yet, but given how thorough and deep I have found Stanfield's analysis in The Stanzas of the Old English Rune Poem, I think this will prove very helpful indeed.

Three Basic Concepts for Early Medieval English Religions

By: Gary Stanfield
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Once again, I'm excited to read this due to my respect for what I have read of Stanfield's. This looks at three words that are hard to translate into today's English: Metod, Os, and drohtian, which I suspect I will find helpful when I go deeper into working out a more thorough "Modern Heathen Philosophy."

Theodisc Geleafa

By: Swain Wodening
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: One of the earliest books on Theodish belief. Theodry/Theodism is a flavor of Heathenry that focuses on the Anglo-Saxons, as does my own worship, but it grounds much of its approach in the role of the "tribe" and a sacral king for that tribe. I've come to believe that such an approach tends to be too fake for most of us in today's world, leading to a kind of LARPing, but Theodish writers have a lot of good stuff, especially if you are alive to the differences in the Scandinavian material most common amongst Heathens and the Old English.

Hammer of the Gods

By: Swain Wodening
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Wodening's books kind of run together for me, and it's a bit hard to say what each is doing differently from the other. Where Theodisc Geleafa focuses more on "why a tribe and why a king?" Hammer of the Gods is more practical "how to worship," and my own practice has kept some elements I found here rather than elsewhere (such as circling a ritual or prayer space with a fire before beginning).

Path to the Gods

By: Swain Wodening
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Again, much overlap with Hammer of the Gods, but this one was written to be more beginner-friendly, which is helpful if that's where you are.

We Are Our Deeds

By: Eric Wodening
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Written by Swain's brother, this book has become something of a touchpoint among today's Heathens, as it tries to spell out a set of ethics for Heathens grounded in their beliefs, and not only a light re-skinning of Christian morality. This is on my list for a deep dive into ethics that is a project I plan to tackle in the near-to-medium term.

To Hold the Holytides

By: Thorbeorht Ealdorblotere
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Remember how I said the Theodish were a treasure trove of in-depth knowledge on Old English belief and worship? Thorbeorht might be the gold standard for this (I use his first name, as his religious last name has changed a few times as his role has changed). This book gives a complete liturgical year for today's worshipers grounded in what we know of Old English holy tides (See By the Sun, the Moon, and Stars for more). This is especially helpful if you are looking for a rich, full holy year that is not the "Eight Point Year" that dominated Wiccan and Neopagan practice for the last few decades (not that there's anything wrong with that calendar, either - it's what I currently celebrate as part of my training from John Michael Greer's Druidry Handbook and Druid Magic Handbook.

By the Sun, the Moon, and Stars

By: Thorbeorht Ealdorblotere
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Where To Hold the Holytides tells how to worship on the holy days of the year, this book goes deep into the lunar-solar calendar used to determine those days, as interpreted from the writings of the Venerable Bede.

Gesitha Handbook

By: Garman Lord
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: A gathering of short essays by the founder of Theodism, one of the most interesting things about Lord and Theodism in general is that it pre-dates the Wiccan/Neo-Pagan revival that really gathered steam in the 1980s. As I'e said, I don't hold with everything they do, but it's a deep, thoughtful position with a lot of respect for beliefs of our forebears, and I find it a helpful point of view.

Ghosts and Godpoles

By: Thorbeorht Linleah
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Same Thorbeorht as above, different last name. Another gathering of essays on some of the less-known corners of Anglo-Saxon beliefs about the otherworld, I haven't checked this one out yet, but it's sure to be interesting.

The Duergarbok

By: Susannah Ravenswing
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: This book leans much more heavily on personal gnosis than some of the others, which means it likely needs to be taken with an appropriate amount of salt, but it goes deep into how to bring the dwarves into worship, and not only as characters in the lore. In my own scrying, I've had some encounters with some dwarves, and I think there's worth in exploring this side of things.

Hearth and Field: A Heathen Prayer Book

By: Hester Butler-Ehle
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: A gathering of prayers to various Gods for various occasions. As an aspiring writer of prayers, I find it helpful to see examples of what has worked for others.

The Nordic Animist Year

By: Rune Hjarno Rasmussen
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Written by the creator of the Nordic Animism Youtube channel, I find Rasmussen interesting for taking a fairly different take than most Heathens. He's trained as an anthropologist, and most of his work has been with African-diaspora religions, and he brings that perspective to his approach to Germanish belief, which is, as I said, interestingly different.

Heathen Soul Lore Volumes 1 & 2

By: Winnifred Hodge Rose
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: I've had some interactions with Rose online, and she's unfailingly gracious, knowledgeable, and friendly. Her website has a ton of writings that masterfully blend deep research and personal practice. I haven't tackled these books yet, as to do so properly will involve a lot of bethinking (meditating), and right now my queue of bethinking threads is very full. She explores the Germanish belief in multiple souls per person, and how to build a relationship with these different bits of the "self."

Freyja, Lady, Vanadis

By: Patricia M. Lafayllve
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: I haven't read any of Lafayllve's work yet, and I know she sometimes gets pooh-poohed for coming from a Wiccan-ish background, but books I've found helpful have mentioned this book as also helpful, and it's wholly about one of the Goddesses important to my practice, so I look forward to giving it a read.

A Practical Heathen's Guide to Aasatru

By: Patricia M. Lafayllve
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Recommended by Ocean Keltoi, according to whom it has pretty good information and sourcing, but not perhaps not the best rituals.

Worshipful Speechcraft (Religious Poetry)

The following couple of books (at the time of first writing this, both by Eirik Westcoat) are about poetry written for worship and/or magic. They also include some help in coming up with such poetry for yourself, which I have put to good use in my own soul-work.

Viking Poetry for Heathen Rites

By: Eirik Westcoat
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Greatly helpful work on prayers written following the ways of old Germanish poetry. Also holds many prayers written following such ways. A big help if you want to know either a) some prayers you might say to the Germanish Gods, or b) how to write your own prayers as a kind of poetry much like what pre-Christian worshippers used to the same ends.

Eagle's Mead

By: Eirik Westcoat
Have I Read It?: Much of it, but not Cover-to-Cover
Thoughts: Much like his earlier work above, Westcoat here writes a lot of poetry to do with going through the course of study in The Nine Doors of Midgard. Especially helpful for those going after magical learning and/or worshiping Odin most of all.

Runework and Magic

These books are more about "making stuff happen" and/or "learning about what might happen" using means that come from Germanish belief. Mostly that means the Runes used for divination or magical purposes, but there are some other linked ways of going about things as well.

Runes and Magic

By: Dr. Stephen Flowers, PhD.
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Dr. Flowers's (otherwise known as Edred Thorsson) doctoral dissertation, this is a fairly dry, academic look the historical record for magical uses of the Runes. Due to his own magical practice, it's not well-thought-of in academic circles, but much of the modern Runic revival builds on it.

Futhark

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Thorsson/Flowers's first book on Runes for divination and magic, this is a brief "one stop shop" for all such things. M

The Runecaster's Handbook

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Smaller and more focused than Futhark, this book is my go-to for doing divination with the Runes.

Runelore

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: This book digs deeper into the esoteric meaning of the Runes and is very helpful as a source for threads to bethink (mediate) on.

Alu: Advanced Operative Runology

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: If Futhark is a great "intro to Rune magic," this is the follow-up. It makes some of the implications of Runelore for Rune magic explicit and goes more into the theory behind the practice, as well as incorporating insights from more time working with the Runes.

The Big Book of Runes and Rune Magic

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Much of It
Thoughts: Largely putting together what can be found in Futhark, The Runecaster's Handbook, Runelore and Alu: Advanced Operative Runology, but with some further things added, if you only want one book on Runes for magic and divination, you could do much worse than this.

The Rune Poems

By: Dr. Stephen Flowers, PhD.
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Flowers's (Thorsson's) translations of the Old Norwegian, Old Icelandic, and Old English Rune poems, which are our most important primary sources on the literal and esoteric meanings of the Runes.

The Rune Poems

By: P.D. Brown and Michael Moynihan (eds)
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: A gathering of modern Rune poems, mostly written by practitioners of today's Runic revival. I anticipate this being very helpful when I get to crafting my own Rune poem to capture my understanding of the Runes.

Stanzas of the Old English Rune Poem

By: Gary Stanfield
Have I Read It?: Mostly
Thoughts: This book is insanely in-depth. It goes through each Stanza of the Old English Rune Poem and discusses the meanings of the words, the poetic technique and structure, and possible esoteric interpretations. I have found it very helpful as a source of deep insights into the Runes and threads for bethinking (meditating) on them.

Long Branches

By: Ann Groa Sheffield
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Unlike most books of the modern Runic revival books, this focuses on the Younger Futhark, which was used by the speakers of Old Norse (i.e. the Vikings), rather than the Elder Futhark, which was used from the time of Proto-Germanic and into the early stages of the differentiation of the different families of Germanic tongues. I haven't read it yet, but I've heard good things from some other practitioners I've spoken with online.

Living Runes

By: Galina Krasskova
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Another I haven't read yet, but given my respect for Krasskova's other work, I suspect I'll find much to help here. Krasskova explicitly treats the Runes as spirits with their own agency and personality, and approaches working with them as spirit allies and partners, rather than impersonal forces, which is rather different from how most Rune books treat them.

Helrunar

By: Jan Fries
Have I Read It?: Mostly
Thoughts: A more free-wheeling book grounded far more in personal experience and tenuous associations than in stringent historical reconstruction, this book is helpful for its perspective, but isn't where I would recommend to start.

Nordic Runes

By: Paul Rhys Mountfort
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Another very solid introduction to the Runes, most of all for divination, I especially value the associations with tales from the lore that it provides.

Nine Doors of Midgard

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: This book was written as a course of ceremonial magical study for the Rune Gild, so to get the most out of it, you'll need to commit to a couple of years or more of daily practice. This was the first magical system I tried, but I bounced off of it after most of a year of daily work, I suspect now due to the beliefs I held then that the Gods and magic were merely processes of the deep mind (subconscious). It gets some flack for incorporating a lot of the Western esoteric/magical tradition, which is not attested among the Heathens of elder times, but that's not much of a concern of mine. I'm considering giving it a workthrough when wrap up my work with The Druid Magic Handbook and The Dolmen Arch.

Northern Magic

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Less structured and rigorous than Nine Doors of Midgard, this book holds something of a grab-bag of magical practices rooted in various strands of Germanish lore and folkways, and from what I can tell, was written to be congenial to folks of the Neopagan movement who were drawn to the Germanish Gods.

The Galdrabok

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: This and Icelandic Magic both deal mostly with the medieval to early modern grimoire tradition in Iceland. This book focuses more on the historical grimoires and what we know about them, where Icelandic Magic is more of a practical guide. Thorsson draws some fairly speculative links with the older Heathen tradition and Runes, but it's chock full of interesting techniques and concepts to explore.

Icelandic Magic

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: Again, there's much overlap with The Galdrabok, but this book is more of a "how to" guide to doing magic inspired by the Icelandic grimoire tradition, rather than an examination of that tradition from a more academic standpoint. Again, Thorsson's proposed links with Runes and Heathen belief of elder times are speculative, as the grimoires all date to after conversion and show clear similarities to the wider European grimoire tradition, but it has some interesting techniques to explore and experiment with. Possibly most interesting to me is as a starting point for sigils/amulets with a Germanish flavor.

Rune Might

By: Edred Thorsson (Stephen Flowers)
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: This book explores the Armanen Rune system from the early 20th century Runic revival of Guido von List's ariosophy movement. Ariosophy gets a bad name these days as it was associated with German nationalism, and so some of its adherents ended up involved with the Nazis. Though List's approach was, hmm, idiosyncratic, to put it gently, a lot of the modern Runic revival drew on his work, whether directly or indirectly, not least because Thorsson went to Germany and learned it before becoming the biggest popularizer of the Runes in the late 20th century. In terms of interesting practical techniques, perhaps the two most interesting are "Runic Yoga" (body postures for each Rune) and the handstodhur, which are hand gestures for each Rune. Thorsson adapted these to the Elder Futhark, which can be found in Futhark and Nine Doors of Midgard.

Pagan Magic of the Northern Tradition

By: Nigel Pennick
Have I Read It?: A Bit
Thoughts: Pennick looks at both Germanish and Celtic sources, since these cultures had a lot of contact with and influence upon each other, and derives modern practices from them. Maybe a bit "loosey-goosey" for the stricter reconstructionist, these are nonetheless thoroughly researched and grounded in personal experience.

Norse Goddess Magic

By: Alice Karlsdottir
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: This book focuses mainly on Frigg and her attendants, and even more specifically on contacting them through trancework. It's interesting for presenting a far more positive view of "unverified personal gnosis" than you usually found in books coming out around the same time, and has both some worthwhile insights into the Goddesses discussed, as well as some practical tips on one method to try to come to know Them better.

A Handbook Saxon Sorcery & Magic

By: Alaric Albertsson
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: I picked this one up because it sounded reasonably congenial to my interests, and I wanted to give the local magic shop some business. I haven't checked it out yet, but it seems to be a kind of "recipe book" for magical workings including spells and herbal mixtures inspired by what we know of Anglo-Saxon techniques.

Sorcerer's Screed

By: Skuggi (Jochum Magnus Eggertsson)
Have I Read It?: A Bit
Thoughts: This is one of those Icelandic Grimoires mentioned above, apparently originally published by the man who put it together, but clearly drawing on a lot of earlier texts and traditions. Like the other Icelandic grimoires, it is a bit like a "recipe book" of spells, some of which with some rather out-there ingredients or practices spelled out, which may need to be taken with a grain of salt, as it was common in older books of magic to include traps for the unwary who wanted results without putting in the work. The edition I have was published by the Icelandic Magic company and is very lovely - all of the sigils and other illustrations were redrawn by a professional artist, and the layout and typesetting is top notch.

The Teutonic Way: Magic

By: Kveldulf Gundarsson
Have I Read It?: Mostly
Thoughts: Though I haven't done a lot of work with this book, it holds a special place in my heart because it was while going through its "pathworkings" (guided visualization meditations) on the Runes that I had my this stuff is really real religious experience. While I find un-guided visualization meditation (scrying) more helpful these days, this was a great "training wheels" way to get to some genuine spiritual insights and experiences in my early days of practice.

The Hanged God

By: Shani Oates
Have I Read It?: Yes
Thoughts: First book of the "Odhinn Trilogy," which is meant to be the first of a nine-book grouping called "The Northern Otherworld Series." Though it puts forth some interesting takes, I found it somewhat wanting overall.

Wolfshead

By: Shani Oates
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Second book of the "Odhinn Trilogy," looking mostly at the tales of skinchangers and berserkers and their links to Odhinn. Less what I'm focused on right now, so I've skipped it to read the next book.

The Search for Odhinn

By: Shani Oates
Have I Read It?: Some
Thoughts: Third book of the "Odhinn Trilogy." I put together my full thoughts on the book here. Oates puts forth that "Odhinn" and "Woden" are too readily conflated and that both figures are better seen as later syncretizations of earlier tutelary and ancestral beings. It made it much clearer where Oates and I might differ theologically, and overall, I don't wholly buy her argument, but she has a lot of deep research on the archaeological record of finds thought to relate to this God/these Gods.

Shamanism

As I said above, "shamanism" is a word that gets used for many unalike things, but the ways of the folks who live about the North pole gave us the name, and I think it likely those ways left some mark on the ways of the Norse at least, and maybe the wider Germanish world. The books below are all by Raven Kaldera and/or Galina Krasskova, and they have a way of looking at things that is rather unlike other folks, so take with as much salt as seems right to you.

Neolithic Shamanism

By: Raven Kaldera & Galina Krasskova
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Their take is that the beliefs and ways of working with Gods and spirits of the Germanish folks were shaped by shamanic ways of working, and this is meant to be a "how to" for a modern seeker.

Wyrdwalkers: Techniques of Northern Tradition Shamanism

By: Raven Kaldera
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: My understanding is that this is building on Neolithic Shamanism with further ways of working.

Wightridden: Paths of Northern Tradition Shamanism

By: Raven Kaldera
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: Again, building on Neolithic Shamanism, but this time with thoughts on how to learn more about the nine worlds of Germanish lore and the ways to and from them.

The Jotunbok: Working with the Giants of the Northern Tradition

By: Raven Kaldera
Have I Read It?: No
Thoughts: One thing that makes Kaldera somewhat controversial amongst the worshipers of Germanish Gods is his worship of and working with the Jotnar, the "giants" of Norse myth. Most folks see these as hostile or at least indifferent beings, and worship of them as not a good idea, but Kaldera says otherwise.

The Northern Shamanic Herbal

By: Raven Kaldera
Have I Read It?: Bits
Thoughts: Linked with the all of the other books in this bit of the list, but with a focus on the use of plants for healing and magical work. Seems very thorough, worth setting against other guides to herbalism.

Closing Thoughts

This is a big field, and the list above is already rather long, but I know there's much that I've left off. I look forward to finding more great works I haven't even heard of yet!

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. You can also comment on the dreamwidth post.

Thoughts on Spending a Year with the Dead

Date: 2023-January-15

The Rules

For all of 2022, I set myself the goal of reading only books by writers who had died before I began reading it, unless the book was 1. needed for work, 2. about a hands-on skill that I put to work in 2022, or 3. written by a friend or kin.

I'm glad I did it, I think it was good for me, and now I'd like to share a bit about how it went and what I learned.

What Went Well

First off, I met my goal, so huzzah! Since I made this boast publicly and told my friends and family about it, it helped very much whenever I found myself wanting to bend or break my rules. One of my goals for the year was to read more old books, and this helped me do so. I also wanted to use it as a spur to read more "great" or otherwise intimidating books, and it helped me there as well - among others, I read Spengler's The Decline of the West (both volumes) and Goethe's Faust.

This also drove me to think more about my reading and where I might look to answer a question - if I wanted to read about a something, I had to try to find a book about it by someone who was dead. Brand new field like the blockchain? Too bad, maybe this isn't the year for cutting edge stuff.

When I found myself wanting to read books by living authors, I had to stew on it for a while. Sometimes I found that my yearning for a book cooled after a few weeks, but with a handful, I was literally counting the days to the New Year. I've already read two short books I'd been wanting to get to for months now, and it felt like a real treat to get to them at last.

Another of my main goals was to open myself up to ways of thinking not tangled up in the trends and prejudices of today. Sure enough, these books were at times refreshing, shocking, or both.

Altogether, I think this was great New Year's goal. It could bend to fit my changing tastes, needs at work, and even having a baby. On the other hand, it was spelled out well enough to make it easy to know if I was following it or not and binding enough to get me to act differently than I would have without it. If any of that grabs you, consider giving a shot sometime.

What Might Have Gone Better

While I think the goal was a good one and the year went well, there were a few less-thrilling things. First off, I read a lot less: 17 books against 46 in 2021 (not including comics). To be fair to my goal, I don't think it's the only, or even the main, driver of why I read less - I would put that more on a larger teaching load, long books to read, a new note-taking system, and most of all, having a new baby for the last few months of the year. I also got deeper into my spiritual practice and took up a bit of leatherworking over the summer, so there were those as well.

Also, and this one might be thanks to my goal, it was much harder for me to get into most of the fiction I chose. When I really love a novel, I'll pick it up whenever I get a spare moment, whereas if I merely like it, it'll only get 10-15 minutes before bed, if I don't just fall face first into bed. I also missed comics and graphic novels. It seems my tastes run much more with the times with fiction than non-fiction. Of course, there are lots of comics whose authors have died and every kind of fiction imaginable, but for whatever reason, this bit was less successful for me.

I also could have set my rules more clearly for edge cases: does looking up an entry in a reference book count? How about finding a saying from something I've already read? Or checking a book's index for a key word? How about the book I'm getting meditation themes from? Or an art book where I'm looking at the pictures?

I ended up settling on "referencing" not counting as "reading", and a small amount of skimming to get the gist of a book was okay, as long as I didn't linger too long on any bits. I counted meditation themes as "learning a hands-on skill" and looking at art books didn't count as "reading", though it was a good reminder to go look for older stuff instead of only looking at the latest art.

I felt like all of this was in keeping with my why I set the goal, which was mostly for books I would read cover-to-cover but I would have felt better about it if I wasn't asking myself if I was "cheating."

Likely the closest I came to fudging the goal was spending a lot of time reading blogs. Maybe too much time. Maybe time that would have been given to books if not for the goal.

For example, I read the whole archive of Unqualified Reservations and Gray Mirror by Curtis Yarvin, the former of which includes many series that have been sold as e-books. I ended up counting it as okay so long as I read it "as a blog" - in my browser, post-by-post, and in the order they were posted, not how they were put together for publication.

This was more a case of sticking to the letter of my goal while bending the spirit a fair bit - I spent hours and hours reading long-form prose by living folks, about the same things I would have read books about if not for my goal. So, as much as the goal was meant to take away distractions so I could read stuff I might otherwise put off, reading blogs so much went against that.

What I'm Doing This Year

This year (2023) I settled on a goal for output instead of input: every week I will put up a blog post. I'd like to post here to my webstead weekly, but in a crunch, I will count shorter/less polished pieces on my [dreamwidth journal] as meeting my goal.

The thinking here is to get myself used to writing and sharing it with others often. If anyone bothers to read it, that's gravy.

To meet this goal, I'll be treating the "week" as Monday to Sunday, though I'd like to get to where I'm posting in the middle of the week anyway and the point will be moot. Since consistency is my goal, "make up" posts are better than nothing, but more than 5 will be a loss. Likewise, more than 5 posts that are only placeholders (like one or two sentences that don't say much worth reading) will be a loss.

Hopefully you'll join me for this trek, and we'll both find it worthwhile!

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com or comment on the dreamwidth comment thread, and I'll add your thoughts below.

The Open-Minded Materialist's Gentle Introduction to Spirituality

Date: 2023-January-08 Edited: 2023-February-21 - Fixed a few typos and cleaned up some wording, added a link to "Hotel Concierge"

I've always liked learning about mythology and religion, but most of my tries at prayer or worship left me cold. I gave it a shot for a bit in college, but by a few years ago, I had pretty well settled into a scientific materialistic atheism, or at least a pretty hard-edged agnosticism - I thought there was nothing reasonable you could say about things that weren't available to the five senses, so why speculate. Then, much to my surprise, about a year and a half ago (mid 2021), I had what seems to have been a pretty classic religious experience. Since then, I've been taking a new look at much of how I think about the world, and it's been a wild ride. At this point, I can still remember how the world looked as a materialist, but now I see things differently. Standing astride these two worldviews, I think I might be able to help out anyone looking across that chasm and wondering what's on the other side, and if it's worth finding a way over.

This Post is for Those Who Feel Something is Lacking

The reader I have in mind for this post is someone with a pretty firm grounding in how the world works - likely you know a basic outline of history, some understanding of physics and biology, and enough psychology that folks' day-to-day foibles don't surprise you too much. Maybe one of these fields grabs you more, and you've gone deeper there, but basically, you don't look at history, or technology, or politics and feel totally perplexed. Things may not be where you'd like, but they at least make sense. Amongst all of that, though, something's under-developed: a sense of meaning. Very likely you've read some philosophy, some self-help, maybe you've tried out meditation or gratitude journaling or the like. If your mostly-good-enough worldview falls short precisely at the most important questions ("what's it all about?", "what should I do with my life?", and so forth), then I hope this post might help you out.

By "Spiritual", I Mean Whatever Makes Life Worth Living

Before we go further, I wanted to pin down what I mean by "spiritual," since I'll be talking about it a lot below. Trying to define "spiritual" or "spirituality" is notoriously tough, so I'm going to go with an open-ended definition for this post. When I say "spiritual" (in this post at least), what I mean is whatever beliefs, experiences, and practices that strengthen the feeling that life is fundamentally good and worth living over the long-term. That last bit is important, because otherwise we might rope in a lot of short-term enjoyable experiences, like drugs or casual sex, that few folks would give much weight to as "spiritually significant". Also, I use the word "strengthen", because I don't think many things are well-served by a binary of "spiritual/not-spiritual." Maybe having an enchanting encounter with an attractive member of your preferred sex is "spiritual" if you've been feeling cold and lonely, but it is likely to be less spiritually weighty than building a life-long partnership with someone and raising a family. So, for my definition, "spiritual" is continuous, not categorical.

One Way to Go About Things

Start From Where You Are

The most important thing on the spiritual path is to take your own experience seriously. Questions of meaning and spiritual significance are deeply personal, and your answers are likely to be even more so. First, take stock of why you're even asking these questions - are you feeling bitter, depressed, or angry? Is life going "fine", but it feels like something is missing? Are there niggling little edges of your model of the world that don't quite work? Have you had an experience you can't wholly explain? Wherever you're starting, be honest with yourself. Folks often use "I'm just being honest" as an excuse to be overly harsh, even towards themselves. So don't do that, but also don't try to pretend everything is fine if it isn't.

Wherever you and your beliefs are, though, there are very likely things you can do to move your life toward something you like better. If you just can't take religious claims as anything other than wishful thinking for stupid people, if you try to pray or do rituals, it's going to feel hollow and dumb. So, if that's you, don't start there. Maybe something like reading philosophy and meditating on it could work for you. Maybe even that feels too "woo woo" for you: if so, try looking for some scientifically validated practices like gratitude journaling or getting regular exercise. If you feel like your mental/emotional state could be better, you're almost certainly right, but your path to get there is unlikely to be the same as anyone else's. Down the way, it might take you to some funky places, but for now, you have to start from where you are.

Find Credible Folks Rather than Believable Claims

Okay, let's imagine that you've taken a good, hard look at your life and what you believe about it, and you're thinking something like "this isn't quite working for me."

So, you settle on widening your outlook, and you start reading some folks outside of your comfort zone - self-help gurus, philosophers, religious folks, maybe even occultists. As you do, you run into things that leave you scratching your head at best or scoffing in disbelief at worst. One of the pitfalls of spiritual writers, especially alternative spiritual writers, is a whole lot of "woo". If you're coming from any kind of rationalist background, it's easy to run into stuff that you just can't take seriously at all. They are operating from an utterly different epistemological/metaphysical basis, and they take for granted things about the world that seem obviously wrong to you. You end up finding yourself in a wilderness of wild claims about how the world works and what might make your life better. Let's take a common example: most religious folks believe in the actual, external reality of one or more sentient beings that happen not to have bodies (Gods, angels, spirits, and so forth). If you are coming from a materialist viewpoint, this claim is patently nonsense. Those religious people then claim that talking to some of these non-physical beings can make your life much better. So, how do you handle this recommendation to start praying?

Here's my take: look for writers that you find credible about something, and work on holding off judgment on the weirder, woo-woo-ier stuff they talk about. Look for fields where their judgment and reasoning make sense to you. Over time, you might find yourself going "this person is smart, grounded, and reasonable about just about everything, why does he believe this crazy stuff?" With a truly open mind, that's a helpful stead to find yourself in. If you think about it, you pretty much do this all the time - everyone you know has a quirky set of beliefs about the world, some of which you'll hold with and some you won't. For one easy example, I'm willing to bet you have someone among your friends or kinsfolk that you like and think well of, but with whom you will not talk politics.

So, when weighing the worth of spiritual writers, look at those of their beliefs about the world which you can more readily evaluate. Do they talk about history, or politics, or psychology, or literature, or other non-spiritual matters? Do they make sense when they do? The goal here is to ask yourself "does this person seem trustworthy overall?" If they seem nuts about everything, chances are good they're nuts about spiritual matters too. On the other hand, if they seem like calm, thoughtful folks with a clear outlook on the world, and yet they happen to believe something that seems obviously impossible to you, well, now that's interesting, isn't it? These are the folks you'll want to pay attention to.

"By Their Fruits Ye Shall Know Them"

Since the definition we're using for spirituality here grounds out in how you live your life, there's a helpful rule of thumb you can apply to would-be spiritual teachers that comes from one of the best-known spiritual teachers of all time, Jesus: "by their fruits ye shall know them." In other words, look at what kind of outcomes this guy has in his own life. How does he treat others? Is he surrounded by scandal? Is his life a raging dumpster fire? It's always helpful to think through these questions when taking someone's advice, but it's even more weighty for philosophical or spiritual things, since their whole point is making your life better. Look out for folks who seem to make sense, but whose lives are a mess.

Consciousness is Not Available to the Five Senses

One rationalist argument that I always found convincing was that you can't meaningfully reason about things that are not available to the five senses. In other words, if there are things about the world that we can't experience with our senses, we have no way of knowing about them for sure, so we shouldn't bother speculating. Further, since the world can seemingly be explained pretty darn well by those things that are available to the senses, it's very likely extraneous to assume there's anything else. This post by Eric S. Raymond is a good example of that kind of reasoning.

I was pretty comfortable with such reasoning until I read A World Full of Gods by John Michael Greer. He made a point that blew a big hole in that comfortable line of reasoning. We do in fact have an important element of experience that is not available to the five senses: the contents of our consciousness. Thoughts, imaginations, emotions. These are obviously important parts of our experience, but they are not accessible to anyone's senses. The typical materialist explanation is that these experiences are just epiphenomena of the matter in our skulls, but that "just" is doing an awful lot of heavy lifting. If there's one hugely important area of our experience that is not amenable to the five senses, then there might be others. One area worth giving some consideration is one that every single human culture we have a record of (except ours recently) has found self-evident: the reality of spiritual beings.

Reason is a Helpful Tool, but Some Things are Subjective

What all of the above led me to is that reason is an incredibly helpful tool, but it's not the end-all, be-all for understanding the world and our experience of it. If you begin any kind of spiritual practice, even just journaling or meditating, you will run into a lot of experiences that you can't verify or validate with other folks - they will be wholly subjective to you. Some of those wholly subjective experiences might feel tremendously important, but you won't be able to confirm them empirically or through formal rationality. Does that mean you should ignore them or discount them?

Practice Beats Belief

Okay, the above points were about the sources you check out and how you think about them, but this one is for you. From my own experience, what you think is true about the world is much less important than what you do. You might believe that it's great to treat everybody with loving-kindness, but if you keep acting like a dick, that's not worth much. I have some thoughts on what practices might be most helpful, but the core idea is regular practice - pick something you think will be good for you to do, and then do it every day. Meditation is a good choice, but there are others - like a gratitude journal, volunteering, yoga, prayer, and more. The okay thing you will do regularly is way better than the great thing you give up on.

You May Not Be Able to Make Pascal's Wager

Some folks say that you should give spiritual practices a shot even if you don't believe they're "really real." Something like "pray even if you don't think anyone is listening." In my case, a few years back, I was convinced that rituals and spiritual practices were a useful way to get in touch with the archetypes of the unconscious, but I thought it was "all in my head." It seems that this works for some folks (see this post from Eric S. Raymond for one example). So I tried it out - I called on Gods, did rituals, and so forth, but all while believing their "reality" was something wholly metaphorical. I felt silly. I couldn't get past feeling like I was talking to myself, so even though I kept at it for a while, it never stopped feeling like an empty waste of time. All of this is to say, if you can't get yourself to at least thinking "maybe there's somebody/something else out there," you might not have much luck with more explicitly religious practices like prayer, and maybe you should start with something else, like meditation.

Where You Might Start

As I've stressed above, any grappling with spiritual matters you do will be deeply your own, and thus what works for you won't be what works for others. That being said, it can be hard to know where to start, so I'd like to share some ways of thinking about meaning that I have found helpful along the way.

Existentialism Says to Make Your Own Meaning

I've listed existentialism first, as it begins with a presupposition wholly in keeping with modern materialism: nothing is meaningful in and of itself. Instead, it is up to you to work out what is meaningful to you and why that matters. It can be a harsh pill to swallow, and it's one that I have since found doesn't meet my own spiritual needs, but existential thinkers tend to approach the problems with meaning with brutal clarity and how to tackle them with admirable courage. The single best work here has got to be Man's Search for Meaning by Viktor Frankl. Nothing quite like a holocaust survivor's tale to put life's problems in perspective.

Self-Help Shows You How to Get Things Done

I spent years very into self-help stuff, mostly stuff by Tim Ferriss, Ryan Holiday, Mark Manson, and so forth. I learned a lot about myself and a lot of helpful ways of dealing with stress, staying healthy, and being productive. Even so, you might say that I wouldn't even be writing this post if I had found the meaning I was looking for in this field. Most self-help seeks to appeal to a wide audience, and so takes few stands on deeper matters of meaning, instead either holding itself to smaller, more pragmatic things ("get in shape!" or "manage your finances!") or else grounds out in vague, woo-woo stuff of the "do what feels right to you!" kind.

The other big flaw in a lot of self-help is that it's mostly about solving problems. Don't get me wrong, solving problems is great, but it's not always the right way to come at things. Is grief that your mother died a "problem" to be solved? If every Sunday night you have a gnawing sense of dread, does that mean you should learn the best strategy for getting a promotion, or might it be a token of something deeper? All that being said, I think The War of Art by Steven Pressfield is very worthwhile, and Tim Ferriss's work is still top notch for learning how to get real world stuff done.

Stoic Philosophy Tells You to Take the Reins of Your Feelings

Unlike Existentialism, Stoic philosophy still pulls a lot of weight in my outlook. It is often pitched as fully in keeping with materialist belief, which it largely is, due to one of its main teachings: you can't control what happens in the world around you, but you can control how you think about it. Put enough work into steering how you think about what happens to you, and you can begin steering how you feel about things. Already, that's pretty worthwhile, and nothing about it goes against a materialist outlook.

The other main teaching of the stoics follows from this and is a bit harder to square with materialism, but you can if you wrangle it hard enough: since you can not control the world around you, no outside measures of "a good life" can withstand everything that might happen. Instead, you should steer your thoughts (and feelings) by "virtue". The reason this is harder for a materialist is that it turns out it's really hard, maybe even impossible, to come up with a truly bullet proof definition of "virtue" on purely empirical grounds. You can certainly get to good enough for living your life, but if you're looking for epistemic certainty, it can leave some gnawing doubts. The classical stoics didn't have this problem, because they believed virtue came from a universal divine source.

If you want to get started with Stoic philosophy, there are two good options: 1. Meditations by Marcus Aurelius and 2. Letters from a Stoic by Seneca. Meditations was the personal diary of a thoughtful and disciplined man, whereas Letters from a Stoic was the avuncular advice of a successful mentor helping a younger friend work out his life. You can't really go wrong with either, but Meditations comes off more like maxims and helpful self-talk, whereas Letters from a Stoic is more conversational and more understanding of the occasional misstep. Pick whichever of those grabs you more.

Meaningness Explores the Ambiguity of "Meaning"

This is an online "book" that tries to tackle the problem of meaning, meaninglessness, and everything in between from a materialist-friendly Buddhist stand point. I think he does about as good a job as you possibly can if you take materialism as a key assumption. The heart of his argument is that most religious approaches put too much meaning on every damn thing, whereas nihilism puts too little meaning on stuff that everyone sees as meaningful unless you stop and think too hard about it. Instead, his take is that "meaning" is something rather ambiguous that all humans experience, partly by creating it and partly by responding to things in the outside world. Thorough, well-argued, and helpfully nuanced, maybe the best thing this book does is to make a telling, materialist-compatible case that nihilism is dumb and rationalism isn't an unassailable metaphysical/epistemological truth.

An adjacent couple of sets of writing I have found helpful is sam[]zdat by Lou Keep and Hotel Concierge. These blogs begin with the same intellectual and cultural starting places as the wider "Rationalist" community, but wrestle much more with how far scientific evidence and logical reasoning can go when it comes to values and with the sometimes bad outcomes of reasonable courses of action with good intentions. Sadly, neither has posted in a long time.

Religion Might Take You Some Places You Didn't Know About

Or, maybe you've come a bit farther than I've been thinking, and you're at least open to the thought that all of this "spiritual" stuff is not only metaphorical, not just a pithy way to sum up thorny psychological, sociological, and cultural factors, but instead there might be something outside of yourself that you'd be better off coming to know. Given who I reckon is reading this, it's fairly likely that when I say "religion," what comes to mind is something that looks a lot like Protestant Christianity - either in its Fundamentalist Evangelical flavor or its Progressive Social Justice flavor. Either that, or some kind of westernized Buddhism, as I have heard humorously, but not wrongly, called "Richard Gere Buddhism". Notwithstanding my less-than-kind likenesses, if any of that grabs you, by all means, go forth and delve into that thing!

For this post, though, I'm not going to say much on these, since I think you likely wouldn't be here if the ready-to-hand religious options did much for you. Instead, I'd like to draw your awareness to some very unalike choices. You see, religion of some kind is found amongst the folks of all lands, but between those lands, there are wildly unalike ways to deal with the spiritual world, many of which you might not have given much thought to. Here's a handful:

  • Does Christianity hold some weight with you, but the kinds you know don't work for you? Consider poking around "Tradcath" (Traditional Catholic) or Orthodox Christianity. C.S. Lewis and G.K. Chesterton are some worthwhile writers here, and there are loads of writings, podcasts, and so forth to check out online, but it's not a field I've looked deeply into, so I don't know which to steer you toward.
  • What if you can't get the claims of monotheism to make sense? The afore-said World Full of Gods does a wonderful job of spelling out why polytheism is worth taking earnestly, but if you'd like to give it a try yourself, check out The Soul's Inner Statues and pair with whatever mythology most speaks to you.
  • India and Japan have thriving home-grown religions in the shape of Hinduism and Shintoism/Buddhism (they often run together in Japan). Both have a very wide set of practices, prayers, rituals, and so forth, most of which are deeply linked with the neighborhoods from which they spring - so much so that you likely need to go and see them in the flesh to fully get them, but if something grabs you from afar, why not at least read about it?
  • Or how about the religious thinking and folkways of the sundry indigenous folks around the world? God is Red by Vine Deloria, Jr. is a great starter for Native American Indian spirituality, and Sand Talk by Tyson Yunkaporta is one for Australian aboriginal people.
  • If you're really quirky, you might think about looking into some of the West's alternative spiritual paths of the last few hundred years - Theosophy, Occultism, the Druidry Revival, and so forth.

I've shared all of the above since I think a lot of folks feel like their lives are lacking spiritually, but the [options] they know about leave them cold. If neither megachurch Christianity nor Yoga-studio Buddhism do it for you, it turns out there's a lot more out there, some of which just might grab you.

Heed Your Own Experience

Whatever you find on your spiritual journey, remember that it is your journey. If religious or spiritual practices aren't working for you, then hey, they're not what you need right here and right now. On the other hand, if you find them worthwhile, don't let the fact that they seem weird or don't make sense to other people stop you from doing what works for you. It's hard enough to deal with your own doubts and those of your friends and kin if you find yourself drawn to Christianity or Buddhism or other widely-practiced religions, but it's even tougher if you find yourself drawn to something more out there. Praying to multiple Gods? Lighting incense? Putting on funny robes and walking around in circles? You might find yourself feeling a bit self-conscious, or worse. Whatever you do, the whole point of spiritual practice is to make better sense of yourself and your experience, and to enrich your life, so pay attention to how your practice makes you feel and what impact it has on your life, and don't let any hangups get in the way of that.

It might turn out to be a long, weird ride, but it's worth it.

Did this post spark any thoughts? Have anything to ask or share? Feel free to send me an email at jeff DOT powell DOT russell AT gmail.com, and I'll add your thoughts below. Or feel free to comment on the dreamwidth post.

Rules of Germanish Meter

Date: 2022-November-20

I'm writing this post as much as a reference for me and as a place to point to whenever I make use of traditional Germanish metrical forms as anything else. For all of this, I am greatly indebted to Eirik Westcoat who has written a great deal of poetry in modern English using these forms for Heathen religious purposes, and lays out the rules very clearly in his book Viking Poetry for Heathen Rites. Note that this post has nothing to say about the other great thread in Germanish poetic tradition, which is the use of formal, stylized metaphors known as kennings, like the "whale road" for the sea or "flame of battle" for a sword.

Rules Common to All Germanish Meters

Once you start learning the meters given below, it becomes clear that they are all variations on a theme. That "theme" was likely an ancestral form of poetry practiced by the speakers of Proto-Germanic that speakers of all of the Germanish languages took with them and changed over time. The most complex forms are all from Old Norse, which retained an unbroken native language poetic tradition until the latest time. I find it easier to remember a few key "lego pieces" that all of the meters are made of:

  • Alliteration and syllable counts are the main focus of Germanish meters - other poetic considerations like rhyming, placement of stress, and so forth are sometimes found, but distinctly secondary in importance
  • Only stressed syllables are counted for alliteration. In today's English, this is usually the first syllable, but not always, and it can be helpful to consult a dictionary, where stress is usually indicated with a "`" or similar symbol before the stressed syllable. Prefixes, like on-, be-, up-, un-, and so forth are often not stressed.
  • Note that the above allows a lot of flexibility in stress placement, compared to Latin and Greek poetic forms, but you do still get some interesting rhythm from following the rules given below
  • Consonant clusters that are pronounced as a single sound (th, ch, sk, sp, and so forth) alliterate with each other, rather than with the initial letter used in spelling. For example, "spelling" does not alliterate with "see", but does alliterate with "speak".
  • All vowels alliterate with each other (or "assonate" with each other if you want to be picky)

Rules for Fornyrdhislag - "Old Song Meter"

This was one of the most common verse forms in Old Norse, and given its similarity to attested Anglo-Saxon and continental Germanish verse forms, it's likely pretty close to the Proto-Germanic kind of poetry from which all of these kinds sprang. Most of the other verse forms can be told of as changes to this one.

  • Usually written in eight-line stanzas
  • The main unit of composition is the short line/half line, which must have 2 stressed syllables and usually has 4+ total syllables
  • The alliteration is between pairs of these short lines (A and B), where the first stressed syllable of the second short line (B1) alliterates with either or both of the first or second stressed syllable of the first short line (A1 or A2)
  • The second stressed syllable of the second short line (B2) must not alliterate with the first stressed syllable in that short line (B1), but it may optionally alliterate with either of the stressed syllables in the first short line (A1 OR A2). Due to the above rule, this means that if B2 alliterates, it may only alliterate with whichever A syllable B1 does not alliterate with

Fornyrdhislag Example

O wise Woden,
Well-helped you are
by ravens quick-flying,
Flying around,
and steed eight-legged,
Stepping lively.

Rules for Anglo-Saxon Long Lines

So far, this is the meter I have the most experience with, as it is fairly straightforward and bendsome, as well as coming from the same background as the Gods and Lore that I draw on the most. Almost the same as Fornyrdhislag, but with these changes:

  • Usually, two "half lines" are written/printed together to form the single "long line" of the verse name. These follow the same alliteration rules as the pairs of short lines in fornyrdhislag
  • Half lines must have 4+ syllables each
  • Write as many lines as needed to tell what you're trying to say - they are not broken into stanzas

Anglo-Saxon Long Lines Example

Standing at shoulder, | with shield steadfast,
Battle we welcome | with warriors bold.

Rules for Ljodhahatt - "Song Meter"

This is a very common Old Norse meter. It's name implies that it would have been "sung," perhaps in contrast to more of a "chanting" approach to the older fornyrdhislag.

Here's the rules for it:

  • Comes in two half-stanzas of three lines, for a six-line stanza
  • The first two lines of each half stanza follow the same rules as the short lines from fornyrdhislag, though the first line can be as short as two or three syllables
  • The last line, called a "full line," is longer, with three stressed syllables, any two of which alliterate

Ljodhahatt Example

Hail Thunor
Hallow kindly
This drighten's draught of ale.

Thanks we give
To Thunderer mighty
For blissful blessings this day.

Rules for Galdralag - "Magic Spell Meter"

This ones a bit trickier than either of the above, but relies on the same fundamentals as the above.

  • This is a variation of Ljodhahatt, but it comes in two half-stanzas of four lines each
  • The first three lines are the same as Ljodhahatt
